01:01:05,040 --> 01:01:07,509
Oh, don't worry.
I'm not gonna ask you where else...

994
01:01:07,720 --> 01:01:09,712
you think she might spend her nights.

995
01:01:10,560 --> 01:01:12,119
We're all grown-ups here.

996
01:01:14,160 --> 01:01:15,958
[]

997
01:01:18,520 --> 01:01:20,113
This is nice.

998
01:01:21,040 --> 01:01:23,760
You said you were having
trouble at work, huh?

999
01:01:23,920 --> 01:01:26,560
- With Cachet?
- Yeah.

1000
01:01:26,720 --> 01:01:28,951
It's just that...

1001
01:01:29,160 --> 01:01:30,879
I actually can't get into it.

1002
01:01:31,080 --> 01:01:32,400
No, no, no, of course.

1003
01:01:32,560 --> 01:01:34,313
But if you wanted to talk about it...

1004
01:01:34,480 --> 01:01:36,949
talk it through, you know,
you could always use...

1005
01:01:37,120 --> 01:01:40,192
hypotheticals, you know?
And Naomi did mention that...

1006
01:01:40,360 --> 01:01:43,797
she'd hit some kind of snag
with due diligence.

1007
01:01:45,760 --> 01:01:46,989
Naomi said that?

1008
01:01:47,160 --> 01:01:48,514
Yeah.

1009
01:01:48,720 --> 01:01:51,315
Well, she didn't go
into details, obviously.

1010
01:01:51,520 --> 01:01:55,070
You know, we like to think
that it's, uh...

1011
01:01:55,240 --> 01:01:58,916
It's helpful, you know,
talk things through, find a...

1012
01:01:59,080 --> 01:02:00,594
different perspective.

1013
01:02:00,760 --> 01:02:04,913
You're telling me Naomi
brings you across the wall?

1014
01:02:05,080 --> 01:02:07,276
Not officially, no.

1015
01:02:09,280 --> 01:02:11,476
Come on, sit down.
Those shoes must be killing you.

1016
01:02:14,680 --> 01:02:16,751
You're quite the gentleman.

1017
01:02:16,960 --> 01:02:20,670
But, you know, Naomi told me
you always have an agenda.

1018
01:02:21,200 --> 01:02:25,558
Yes, well... She would. Heh.

1019
01:02:29,040 --> 01:02:35,355
You know, Erin, everyone has an agenda.

1020
01:02:37,280 --> 01:02:38,873
You're trying to make promotion.

1021
01:02:39,040 --> 01:02:41,271
You know that. I know that.

1022
01:02:41,520 --> 01:02:45,799
You do good work. You kiss up to Naomi.

1023
01:02:46,000 --> 01:02:50,040
And then you keep hoping that this year...

1024
01:02:50,240 --> 01:02:53,119
will be the one.

1025
01:02:53,280 --> 01:02:57,991
And if it's not the one,
then eventually...

1026
01:02:58,160 --> 01:03:02,871
you have to start thinking
about other avenues.

1027
01:03:04,600 --> 01:03:06,637
You seem to think
I'm gonna be giving you...

1028
01:03:06,840 --> 01:03:09,309
some information about my IPO.

1029
01:03:09,480 --> 01:03:11,836
We both know how...

1030
01:03:12,040 --> 01:03:14,316
How these things happen.

1031
01:03:16,200 --> 01:03:20,592
You know, Erin, I've been working
at Remson a very long time.

1032
01:03:20,760 --> 01:03:23,992
It might surprise you, but...

1033
01:03:24,160 --> 01:03:27,836
people there respect my opinion.

1034
01:03:41,280 --> 01:03:42,919
[PHONE RINGING AND BUZZING]

1035
01:03:54,680 --> 01:03:57,115
- Hi.
- I just got your messages.

1036
01:03:57,280 --> 01:03:58,760
What kind of problem do we have?

1037
01:03:58,920 --> 01:04:02,470
Naomi, can you just hang on...
Hang on a sec.

1038
01:04:02,640 --> 01:04:04,552
- Erin.
- Hold on.

1039
01:04:04,720 --> 01:04:05,870
"Hold on"?

1040
01:04:06,040 --> 01:04:08,236
Don't tell me to hold on. I'm your boss.

1041
01:04:08,400 --> 01:04:11,234
What the hell happened this time?

1042
01:04:11,800 --> 01:04:14,031
Wait, are you still with Ed?

1043
01:04:14,240 --> 01:04:15,879
No.

1044
01:04:16,080 --> 01:04:17,753
I'm at my place.

1045
01:04:18,760 --> 01:04:20,717
Okay, so...

1046
01:04:22,320 --> 01:04:26,314
Erin, I need to know what's going on here.

1047
01:04:28,560 --> 01:04:30,552
Yeah, sorry.

1048
01:04:33,080 --> 01:04:35,959
Yeah, so Ed did let go
of a few people last week.

1049
01:04:36,120 --> 01:04:38,351
[OVER SPEAKER]
Yes, that was the recommendation.

1050
01:04:38,560 --> 01:04:40,074
And?

1051
01:04:40,240 --> 01:04:43,199
I know, but one of them was Marin.

1052
01:04:44,960 --> 01:04:47,031
Are you fucking kidding me?

1053
01:04:47,200 --> 01:04:50,750
She is a liability if she starts making
claims about holes in the network.

1054
01:04:50,920 --> 01:04:53,560
I know. Look, I got her number here.

1055
01:04:55,840 --> 01:04:56,956
Marin Gold.

1056
01:04:57,160 --> 01:04:58,913
Okay, hang on.

1057
01:04:59,120 --> 01:05:00,395
Go.

1058
01:05:00,560 --> 01:05:06,750
415-555-0192.

1059
01:05:06,960 --> 01:05:08,679
Got it.

1060
01:05:23,160 --> 01:05:27,234
Well, Erin, hasn't this been lovely?

1061
01:05:29,400 --> 01:05:31,119
What are you gonna do?

1062
01:05:34,600 --> 01:05:36,512
With what?

1063
01:05:36,680 --> 01:05:37,796
You fired Marin? Now?

1064
01:05:37,960 --> 01:05:39,235
Look, it wasn't my call.

1065
01:05:39,400 --> 01:05:40,800
Everything is your call.

1066
01:05:40,960 --> 01:05:42,599
But we've got it under control.

1067
01:05:42,760 --> 01:05:46,231
She got a very nice severance
and Legal had her sign all kinds of shit.

1068
01:05:46,400 --> 01:05:48,312
Ed, I am extremely concerned about this.

1069
01:05:48,480 --> 01:05:51,314
- I wish you had consulted me before...
- Hey, Naomi, news flash:

1070
01:05:51,480 --> 01:05:52,880
I don't work for you.

1071
01:05:54,000 --> 01:05:55,912
- I'm...
- Let me tell you something.

1072
01:05:56,080 --> 01:05:58,754
These doubts and second-guessing,
I'm getting tired of it.

1073
01:05:58,920 --> 01:06:02,152
- We've got orders pouring in?
- Yeah, because I've been doing my job.

1074
01:06:02,320 --> 01:06:04,676
But it is also my job to be thorough.

1075
01:06:05,120 --> 01:06:06,315
Oh, yeah?

1076
01:06:06,520 --> 01:06:09,080
- I thought it was your job to be inspiring.
- You know, Ed...

1077
01:06:09,240 --> 01:06:10,594
[PHONE DISCONNECTS]

1078
01:06:11,200 --> 01:06:12,600
[SCOFFS]

1079
01:06:14,080 --> 01:06:15,639
All right, hungry?

1080
01:06:15,800 --> 01:06:17,154
Let's go.

1081
01:06:21,120 --> 01:06:23,112
[]

1082
01:07:06,400 --> 01:07:08,392
[FAUCET RUNNING]

1083
01:07:22,240 --> 01:07:23,913
Where you been?

1084
01:07:24,080 --> 01:07:26,311
Sorry, something came up at work.

1085
01:07:40,960 --> 01:07:42,952
[PHONE BUZZING]

1086
01:07:44,600 --> 01:07:46,592
[GRUNTING SOFTLY]

1087
01:08:07,120 --> 01:08:09,237
[PHONE BUZZING]

1088
01:08:12,720 --> 01:08:13,756
Hello.

1089
01:08:13,920 --> 01:08:15,639
CORY: Fuck you!

1090
01:08:15,800 --> 01:08:17,314
This must be Cory.

1091
01:08:17,480 --> 01:08:18,550
I Googled you!

1092
01:08:18,720 --> 01:08:20,040
Of course you did.

1093
01:08:20,240 --> 01:08:22,038
You're a fucking prosecutor?

1094
01:08:22,240 --> 01:08:25,358
I'm eager to hear more about
your contact with Dr. Sobel.

1095
01:08:25,520 --> 01:08:29,799
- You can talk to my lawyer!
- I look forward to it.

1096
01:08:40,760 --> 01:08:42,752
[MELANIE SNORING]

1097
01:08:48,200 --> 01:08:50,351
SAM: We both know your client
crossed a line.

1098
01:08:50,560 --> 01:08:53,155
CAHN: Heh. Would you look at him?

1099
01:08:53,320 --> 01:08:55,516
He works 80 hours a week.

1100
01:08:55,680 --> 01:08:58,878
He's a dad, raises money
for leukemia research.

1101
01:08:59,040 --> 01:09:00,235
- I mean...
- Oh, I'm sorry.

1102
01:09:00,400 --> 01:09:02,790
Does he plant daffodils too?

1103
01:09:02,960 --> 01:09:05,714
Well, he's got no history.

1104
01:09:05,880 --> 01:09:08,714
He's never been flagged
by you guys or the SEC.

1105
01:09:09,520 --> 01:09:11,398
Are you saying he doesn't know any better?

1106
01:09:12,080 --> 01:09:15,756
I have 6-year-old twins who know better.

1107
01:09:16,920 --> 01:09:22,712
When you, your boss and your friends
decide to sabotage a company...

1108
01:09:22,920 --> 01:09:25,196
when you have information
that Joe Investor...

1109
01:09:25,360 --> 01:09:29,036
couldn't possibly have,
and you use that information...

1110
01:09:29,200 --> 01:09:35,117
to profit while Joe Investor loses 65
percent of his retirement fund...

1111
01:09:35,280 --> 01:09:38,751
- ...you know better.
- Are you gonna charge my client or not?

1112
01:09:38,920 --> 01:09:40,877
That depends.

1113
01:09:41,920 --> 01:09:43,673
CAHN: He's not the one you want.

1114
01:09:43,840 --> 01:09:46,036
There are bigger fish at Titanite.

1115
01:09:46,240 --> 01:09:47,435
SAM: That's the point.

1116
01:09:47,600 --> 01:09:49,671
And he's willing to cooperate?

1117
01:09:53,080 --> 01:09:54,196
[NAOMI CLEARS THROAT]

1118
01:09:54,360 --> 01:09:57,637
I'd like to thank you all for your patience
as we've been processing...

1119
01:09:57,800 --> 01:10:01,237
this tremendous surge in orders
from institutional investors.

1120
01:10:01,400 --> 01:10:05,189
Our book is closed,
and we have our offering price.

1121
01:10:05,360 --> 01:10:06,396
Thirty-five.

1122
01:10:07,640 --> 01:10:09,836
We just raised $250 million?

1123
01:10:10,000 --> 01:10:11,957
Congratulations.

1124
01:10:12,880 --> 01:10:16,715
We'll see how the market trades
tomorrow, but I feel very confident.

1125
01:10:17,920 --> 01:10:19,877
- Great, great.
- Good work.

1126
01:10:23,520 --> 01:10:24,874
Hm?

1127
01:10:28,400 --> 01:10:30,437
Where did you get that pen?

1128
01:10:30,600 --> 01:10:32,080
[]

1129
01:10:32,240 --> 01:10:33,594
I don't know.

1130
01:10:54,440 --> 01:10:56,397
Big pain in the ass.

1131
01:10:56,600 --> 01:10:57,875
- Hey.
- Hey.

1132
01:10:58,840 --> 01:11:02,754
Cory and I were taking bets on how much
you'd spend on my birthday present.

1133
01:11:03,120 --> 01:11:04,952
To many more.

1134
01:11:07,320 --> 01:11:08,913
Nice.

1135
01:11:09,720 --> 01:11:11,996
[CHUCKLES]

1136
01:11:12,560 --> 01:11:13,789
What are you drinking?

1137
01:11:13,960 --> 01:11:15,280
SAM: Like a porcupine?

1138
01:11:15,440 --> 01:11:18,433
Hedgehog, but cute, fuzzy. Get it?

1139
01:11:18,600 --> 01:11:20,114
Hedge fund, money hog.

1140
01:11:20,280 --> 01:11:22,954
- It's a...
- Yeah, I get it. And Benji took it with him?

1141
01:11:23,120 --> 01:11:26,477
- CORY: Yep.
- SAM: So what does the hedgehog mean?

1142
01:11:26,640 --> 01:11:29,553
CORY: I don't know what it means.
It's a hedgehog.

1143
01:11:29,760 --> 01:11:31,513
These guys just fuck with each other.

1144
01:11:31,720 --> 01:11:33,359
Probably doesn't mean anything.

1145
01:11:33,600 --> 01:11:35,592
[]

1146
01:11:42,880 --> 01:11:44,712
So, am I done?

1147
01:11:45,000 --> 01:11:46,354
Are you fucking kidding me?

1148
01:11:47,720 --> 01:11:49,074
We own you.

1149
01:11:55,880 --> 01:11:57,473
[SIGHS]

1150
01:11:58,880 --> 01:12:00,314
[PHONE CHIRPS]

1151
01:12:02,320 --> 01:12:03,754
[SIGHS]

1152
01:12:09,720 --> 01:12:11,712
[]

1153
01:12:31,320 --> 01:12:34,438
[LINE RINGING]

1154
01:12:34,680 --> 01:12:35,830
MARIN: Hello?

1155
01:12:36,000 --> 01:12:38,117
Marin, it's Naomi Bishop.

1156
01:12:38,920 --> 01:12:41,151
Do you understand what's happening here?

1157
01:12:41,320 --> 01:12:42,754
Cachet can sue you.

1158
01:12:42,960 --> 01:12:44,952
No, they said they would
take care of that.

1159
01:12:45,120 --> 01:12:47,476
Who? Who did?

1160
01:12:49,440 --> 01:12:51,636
Are they paying you?

1161
01:12:54,360 --> 01:12:57,637
Marin, you need to tell me who...

1162
01:12:57,800 --> 01:12:59,234
I'm sorry, I have to go.

1163
01:12:59,400 --> 01:13:01,073
Marin.

1164
01:13:01,240 --> 01:13:03,232
[LINE DISCONNECTS]

1165
01:13:13,280 --> 01:13:15,078
[SCOFFS]

1166
01:13:20,600 --> 01:13:22,000
[LINE RINGING]

1167
01:13:22,160 --> 01:13:23,276
WOMAN: Hello?

1168
01:13:23,440 --> 01:13:26,000
Get me a car to Brooklyn, South Slope.

1169
01:13:27,880 --> 01:13:29,394
[HORNS HONKING]

1170
01:13:31,880 --> 01:13:33,394
[DOORBELL RINGS]

1171
01:13:33,560 --> 01:13:34,914
[CLEARS THROAT]

1172
01:13:36,200 --> 01:13:37,793
[SIGHS]

1173
01:13:41,040 --> 01:13:42,633
Hi. I'm Naomi.

1174
01:13:42,800 --> 01:13:44,917
I'm a friend of Sam's.

1175
01:13:48,720 --> 01:13:50,439
Nice shoes.

1176
01:13:50,600 --> 01:13:52,319
Is she home?

1177
01:13:53,880 --> 01:13:55,394
Come on. I'll get her.

1178
01:13:55,560 --> 01:13:57,119
Thank you.

1179
01:14:00,600 --> 01:14:01,954
[DOOR CLOSES]

1180
01:14:09,200 --> 01:14:10,634
Hello there.

1181
01:14:10,840 --> 01:14:12,638
You must be...

1182
01:14:12,840 --> 01:14:16,436
Sophie and... And William, right?

1183
01:14:16,600 --> 01:14:18,432
I don't talk to strangers.

1184
01:14:18,640 --> 01:14:20,950
Oh. Right. Yeah.

1185
01:14:21,120 --> 01:14:25,558
Well, it's really your friends
that'll stab you in the back, so...

1186
01:14:25,720 --> 01:14:28,110
- Hey. Uh...
- Oh.

1187
01:14:28,840 --> 01:14:30,115
What's up?

1188
01:14:30,920 --> 01:14:32,434
I...

1189
01:14:33,920 --> 01:14:36,355
I want you to tell me what you know...

1190
01:14:36,960 --> 01:14:38,474
about Michael.

1191
01:14:38,640 --> 01:14:40,632
[]

1192
01:14:48,480 --> 01:14:50,312
You've been investigating him?

1193
01:14:51,120 --> 01:14:52,679
I can't really comment on that.

1194
01:14:52,880 --> 01:14:55,349
Somebody leaked a rumor about my IPO.

1195
01:14:55,520 --> 01:14:57,477
We go public tomorrow, and somebody...

1196
01:14:57,680 --> 01:14:59,034
I know.

1197
01:14:59,760 --> 01:15:01,399
The tech blogger who posted the story...

1198
01:15:01,600 --> 01:15:04,911
he's an old friend of Michael's
from Stanford.

1199
01:15:06,400 --> 01:15:07,993
It had to be him, right?

1200
01:15:09,400 --> 01:15:11,073
Do you think it was?

1201
01:15:13,800 --> 01:15:15,837
Look, as far as this IPO goes...

1202
01:15:16,000 --> 01:15:20,358
we have no specific link
to Michael at this time.

1203
01:15:22,800 --> 01:15:24,120
Except you.

1204
01:15:25,160 --> 01:15:27,959
Wait, are you saying
I gave him information?

1205
01:15:28,120 --> 01:15:29,713
I am not saying anything.

1206
01:15:31,080 --> 01:15:32,355
I should go.

1207
01:15:32,520 --> 01:15:35,035
Naomi, wait. I can help you.

1208
01:15:35,400 --> 01:15:39,519
- Okay, did Michael have access?
- He did not get this from me.

1209
01:15:39,720 --> 01:15:40,915
Do you understand?

1210
01:15:41,080 --> 01:15:44,471
That is not who I am.

1211
01:15:49,280 --> 01:15:50,794
Fuck.

1212
01:15:52,600 --> 01:15:53,920
[DOOR OPENS]

1213
01:15:56,440 --> 01:15:57,999
Are you tanking my IPO?

1214
01:15:58,680 --> 01:15:59,830
Should I be?

1215
01:16:03,760 --> 01:16:07,071
Don't fuck with me, Michael.
Don't fuck with me now.

1216
01:16:07,240 --> 01:16:08,390
Did you leak this thing?

1217
01:16:09,280 --> 01:16:10,396
Is it true?

1218
01:16:10,560 --> 01:16:13,029
It doesn't matter if it's fucking true!

1219
01:16:13,200 --> 01:16:16,272
- You know that. Once the rumors start...
- Hey, hey.

1220
01:16:16,440 --> 01:16:17,794
Start your own rumors.

1221
01:16:17,960 --> 01:16:19,519
Do you know how to play this game?

1222
01:16:19,720 --> 01:16:22,315
What the fuck is wrong with you?

1223
01:16:22,480 --> 01:16:23,880
What did you do?

1224
01:16:24,040 --> 01:16:26,430
Did you take my phone?

1225
01:16:28,520 --> 01:16:30,113
Are you wearing a wire?

1226
01:16:30,280 --> 01:16:31,794
What do you think?

1227
01:16:31,960 --> 01:16:33,872
Let's take our clothes off and find out.

1228
01:16:34,040 --> 01:16:35,793
Jesus.

1229
01:16:40,800 --> 01:16:42,996
It's all just a big game to you, isn't it?

1230
01:16:44,800 --> 01:16:46,871
What else is there?

1231
01:16:51,360 --> 01:16:52,714
[SIGHS]

1232
01:16:57,040 --> 01:16:59,680
Hey, listen, whatever happens tomorrow...

1233
01:17:01,320 --> 01:17:02,800
you're gonna be fine.

1234
01:17:02,960 --> 01:17:05,680
Fuck, I don't want to be fine!

1235
01:17:05,880 --> 01:17:08,236
I was never supposed to be fine!

1236
01:17:09,200 --> 01:17:12,318
I was supposed to be
a motherfucking rainmaker.

1237
01:17:12,560 --> 01:17:14,392
[]

1238
01:17:17,720 --> 01:17:21,031
[DOOR OPENS THEN SLAMS]

1239
01:17:23,280 --> 01:17:25,237
No, that's... No, that's for PR to handle.

1240
01:17:25,400 --> 01:17:27,915
They have a long reach. So...

1241
01:17:28,120 --> 01:17:29,634
Hold... No.

1242
01:17:29,800 --> 01:17:31,234
Wait. Hold on.

1243
01:17:31,400 --> 01:17:34,234
Tell Ed not to make
a public statement, okay?

1244
01:17:34,400 --> 01:17:37,677
I appreciate his enthusiasm, but just...

1245
01:17:37,880 --> 01:17:40,349
Look, wake the fuck up and call me.

1246
01:17:41,160 --> 01:17:43,152
[]

1247
01:17:56,280 --> 01:17:59,034
So this is a big day
for you and your shareholders.

1248
01:17:59,200 --> 01:18:01,556
- Absolutely.
- Now, over the last 12 hours...

1249
01:18:01,720 --> 01:18:04,633
reports have surfaced that show
hackers may be attempting...

1250
01:18:04,800 --> 01:18:06,792
to access this secure network.

1251
01:18:06,960 --> 01:18:08,952
ED: So here's the thing.
When people hear...

1252
01:18:09,160 --> 01:18:11,356
the word "hackers," they get scared.

- You employ hackers?

1502
01:36:47,600 --> 01:36:49,592
[INDISTINCT CHATTERING]

1503
01:36:49,880 --> 01:36:51,030
MAN: Finally today...

1504
01:36:51,240 --> 01:36:52,993
tech company Cachet
is back in the spotlight...

1505
01:36:53,200 --> 01:36:56,193
with another surge in share price
this week, as the stock...

1506
01:36:56,360 --> 01:36:58,750
continues to rally
following a disappointing IPO.

1507
01:36:58,920 --> 01:37:00,639
WOMAN: Cachet, whose stock
has been steadily climbing...

1508
01:37:00,840 --> 01:37:03,150
after that terrible debut
earlier this year...

1509
01:37:03,320 --> 01:37:05,960
has by now made a lot
of its investors very wealthy...

1510
01:37:06,120 --> 01:37:08,919
if they were able to hold on
tight during that steep drop.

1511
01:37:09,080 --> 01:37:11,595
MAN: ...saw this with Facebook
and Square where a stock rallies...

1512
01:37:11,800 --> 01:37:12,995
and the IPO fades into the distance...

1513
01:37:13,160 --> 01:37:15,880
as investors track the growth
of the company over time.

1514
01:37:16,040 --> 01:37:18,555
What seemed like a disaster
at the initial offering...

1515
01:37:18,720 --> 01:37:22,555
could turn out to be just a speed bump
on the road to enormous gains.

1516
01:38:11,360 --> 01:38:13,352
[]

title: InsideJob
script:
1
00:01:08,734 --> 00:01:10,634
Iceland is a stable democracy

2
00:01:10,803 --> 00:01:12,430
with a high standard of living,

3
00:01:12,604 --> 00:01:14,071
and, until recently,

4
00:01:14,239 --> 00:01:17,436
extremely low unemployment
and government debt.

5
00:01:19,545 --> 00:01:23,208
We had the complete infrastructure
of a modern society.

6
00:01:23,582 --> 00:01:26,073
Clean energy, food production.

7
00:01:26,251 --> 00:01:28,685
Fisheries with a quota system
to manage them.

8
00:01:28,854 --> 00:01:33,188
Good healthcare, education,
clean air.

9
00:01:33,492 --> 00:01:35,016
Not much crime.

10
00:01:35,194 --> 00:01:37,492
It's a good place for families to live.

11
00:01:37,663 --> 00:01:41,360
We had almost
end-of-history status.

12
00:01:42,234 --> 00:01:47,035
But in 2000, Iceland's government
began a broad policy of deregulation

13
00:01:47,206 --> 00:01:49,868
that would have
disastrous consequences,

14
00:01:50,042 --> 00:01:54,001
first for the environment
and then for the economy.

15
00:01:54,179 --> 00:01:57,979
They started by allowing multinational
corporations like Alcoa

16
00:01:58,150 --> 00:02:00,516
to build giant
aluminum-smelting plants

17
00:02:00,686 --> 00:02:05,555
and exploit Iceland's geothermal
and hydroelectric energy sources.

18
00:02:06,024 --> 00:02:08,925
Many of the most beautiful areas
in the highlands

19
00:02:09,094 --> 00:02:13,622
with the most spectacular colors
are geothermal.

20
00:02:14,399 --> 00:02:16,424
So nothing comes
without consequence.

21
00:02:55,106 --> 00:02:56,334
At the same time,

22
00:02:56,507 --> 00:03:00,170
the government privatized
Iceland's three largest banks.

23
00:03:00,344 --> 00:03:02,835
The result was one of
the purest experiments

24
00:03:03,014 --> 00:03:05,983
in financial deregulation
ever conducted.

25
00:03:11,322 --> 00:03:14,655
We have had enough.
How could all of this happen?

26
00:03:15,860 --> 00:03:20,593
Finance took over and more
or less wrecked the place.

27
00:03:21,532 --> 00:03:24,330
In a five-year period,
these three tiny banks,

28
00:03:24,502 --> 00:03:26,970
which had never operated
outside of Iceland,

29
00:03:27,138 --> 00:03:30,039
borrowed 120 billion dollars,

30
00:03:30,207 --> 00:03:33,301
10 times the size
of Iceland's economy.

31
00:03:33,477 --> 00:03:35,707
The bankers showered money
on themselves,

32
00:03:35,880 --> 00:03:37,780
each other, and their friends.

33
00:03:37,949 --> 00:03:39,610
There was a massive bubble.

34
00:03:39,784 --> 00:03:43,151
Stock prices went up
by a factor of nine.

35
00:03:43,321 --> 00:03:45,516
House prices more than doubled.

36
00:03:52,029 --> 00:03:56,796
He borrowed billions to buy up
high-end retail businesses in London.

37
00:03:56,968 --> 00:03:59,197
He also bought
a pinstriped private jet,

38
00:03:59,369 --> 00:04:01,132
a 40-million-dollar yacht

39
00:04:01,304 --> 00:04:03,397
and a Manhattan penthouse.

40
00:04:03,573 --> 00:04:05,404
Newspapers
always had the headline:

41
00:04:05,575 --> 00:04:08,601
This millionaire bought
this company

42
00:04:08,778 --> 00:04:13,943
in the U.K. Or in Finland
or in France or wherever,

43
00:04:14,117 --> 00:04:15,414
instead of saying:

44
00:04:15,585 --> 00:04:19,351
"This millionaire took
a billion-dollar loan

45
00:04:19,522 --> 00:04:23,856
to buy this company,
and he took it from your local bank."

46
00:04:24,027 --> 00:04:25,995
The banks set
up money market funds,

47
00:04:26,162 --> 00:04:29,359
and the banks advised
deposit-holders to withdraw money

48
00:04:29,532 --> 00:04:31,762
and put them
in the money market funds.

49
00:04:31,935 --> 00:04:34,369
The Ponzi scheme needed
everything it could.

50
00:04:34,537 --> 00:04:37,631
American
accounting firms like KPMG

51
00:04:37,807 --> 00:04:40,275
audited the Icelandic banks
and investment firms

52
00:04:40,443 --> 00:04:42,240
and found nothing wrong.

53
00:04:42,412 --> 00:04:46,041
And American credit-rating agencies
said Iceland was wonderful.

54
00:04:46,216 --> 00:04:48,650
In February 2007,

55
00:04:48,818 --> 00:04:54,848
the rating agency upgraded the banks to
the highest possible rate, triple-A.

56
00:04:55,025 --> 00:04:59,928
It went so far as the government here
traveling with the bankers

57
00:05:00,096 --> 00:05:02,963
as a PR show.

58
00:05:05,168 --> 00:05:08,763
When Iceland's banks collapsed
at the end of 2008,

59
00:05:08,938 --> 00:05:12,237
unemployment tripled
in six months.

60
00:05:15,311 --> 00:05:18,747
There is nobody
unaffected in Iceland.

61
00:05:24,421 --> 00:05:26,321
A lot of people lost their savings.

62
00:05:26,489 --> 00:05:28,582
Yes, that's the case.

63
00:05:28,758 --> 00:05:32,591
Government regulators who
should've been protecting the citizens

64
00:05:32,761 --> 00:05:34,592
had done nothing.

65
00:05:35,597 --> 00:05:39,124
You have two lawyers from
the regulator going down to a bank

66
00:05:39,301 --> 00:05:41,201
to talk about some issue.

67
00:05:41,370 --> 00:05:42,997
When they approach the bank,

68
00:05:43,172 --> 00:05:48,474
they would see 19 SUVs
outside the bank.

69
00:05:48,644 --> 00:05:49,804
You enter the bank,

70
00:05:49,978 --> 00:05:54,176
and you have the 19 lawyers
sitting in front of you, right,

71
00:05:54,349 --> 00:05:59,719
very well prepared,
ready to kill any argument you make.

72
00:05:59,888 --> 00:06:02,982
And then, if you do really well,
they'll offer you a job.

73
00:06:03,459 --> 00:06:06,451
One-third of Iceland's
financial regulators

74
00:06:06,628 --> 00:06:09,028
went to work for the banks.

75
00:06:10,265 --> 00:06:12,256
But this is
a universal problem, huh?

76
00:06:12,434 --> 00:06:15,164
In New York,
you have the same problem, right?

77
00:06:46,401 --> 00:06:49,199
What do you think of
Wall Street incomes these days?

78
00:06:49,371 --> 00:06:50,861
Excessive.

79
00:06:53,175 --> 00:06:56,235
I've been told it's
extremely difficult for the IMF

80
00:06:56,411 --> 00:06:58,436
to criticize the United States.

81
00:06:58,614 --> 00:06:59,740
I wouldn't say that.

82
00:07:06,554 --> 00:07:10,354
We deeply regret our breaches
of U.S. Law.

83
00:07:14,061 --> 00:07:17,997
They're amazed at how much
cocaine these Wall Streeters can use

84
00:07:18,166 --> 00:07:20,327
and get up
and go to work the next day.

85
00:07:23,237 --> 00:07:27,264
I didn't know
what credit default swaps are.

86
00:07:27,441 --> 00:07:29,068
I'm a little bit old-fashioned.

87
00:07:34,448 --> 00:07:36,916
Has Larry Summers
ever expressed remorse?

88
00:07:37,084 --> 00:07:38,881
I don't hear confessions.

89
00:07:53,568 --> 00:07:55,468
The government's
just writing checks.

90
00:07:55,636 --> 00:07:58,901
That's plan A, that's plan B
and that's plan C.

91
00:07:59,073 --> 00:08:02,941
Would you support
legal controls on executive pay?

92
00:08:03,611 --> 00:08:04,805
I would not.

93
00:08:08,449 --> 00:08:10,337
Are you
comfortable with the

94
00:08:10,350 --> 00:08:12,249
level of compensation
in financial services?

95
00:08:12,420 --> 00:08:13,887
If they've earned it,
yes, I am.

96
00:08:14,055 --> 00:08:16,114
Do you think they've earned it?
I think so.

97
00:08:19,560 --> 00:08:22,290
And so you've helped
these people blow the world up?

98
00:08:22,463 --> 00:08:23,487
You could say that.

99
00:08:33,074 --> 00:08:37,738
They were having massive
private gains at public loss.

100
00:08:45,385 --> 00:08:48,479
When you think you can
create something out of nothing

101
00:08:48,655 --> 00:08:50,122
it's difficult to resist.

102
00:09:05,038 --> 00:09:08,166
I'm concerned people
want to go back to the old way,

103
00:09:08,341 --> 00:09:11,003
the way they were operating
prior to the crisis.

104
00:09:21,821 --> 00:09:25,188
I was getting a lot of anonymous
e-mails from bankers saying:

105
00:09:25,358 --> 00:09:28,122
"You can't quote me,
but I'm really concerned."

106
00:09:34,167 --> 00:09:35,862
Why do you think there isn't

107
00:09:36,036 --> 00:09:38,732
a more systematic investigation
being undertaken?

108
00:09:38,905 --> 00:09:40,873
Because then
you'll find the culprits.

109
00:09:44,210 --> 00:09:46,479
You think
Columbia Business.

110
00:09:46,492 --> 00:09:48,772
School has any
conflict-of-interest problem?

111
00:09:49,149 --> 00:09:51,777
I don't see that we do.

112
00:10:00,126 --> 00:10:02,788
The regulators
didn't do their job.

113
00:10:02,963 --> 00:10:06,899
They had the power to do every case
that I made. They just didn't want to.

114
00:10:25,117 --> 00:10:27,278
Lehman Brothers, one
of the most venerable

115
00:10:27,453 --> 00:10:30,820
and biggest investment banks,
was forced to declare itself bankrupt.

116
00:10:30,990 --> 00:10:34,084
Another, Merrill Lynch,
was forced to sell itself today.

117
00:10:34,259 --> 00:10:38,423
World financial markets are way down,
following dramatic developments.

118
00:10:47,172 --> 00:10:48,764
In September 2008,

119
00:10:48,941 --> 00:10:51,933
the bankruptcy of the U.S.
Investment bank Lehman Brothers

120
00:10:52,111 --> 00:10:56,343
and the collapse of the world's
largest insurance company, AIG,

121
00:10:56,515 --> 00:10:58,039
triggered a global crisis.

122
00:10:58,217 --> 00:11:00,412
Fears gripped markets overnight.

123
00:11:00,586 --> 00:11:02,076
Stocks fell off a cliff.

124
00:11:02,254 --> 00:11:05,087
The largest single point drop
in history.

125
00:11:05,257 --> 00:11:07,225
Share prices continued to tumble

126
00:11:07,393 --> 00:11:10,590
in the aftermath
of the Lehman collapse.

127
00:11:12,798 --> 00:11:14,663
The result was a global recession,

128
00:11:14,833 --> 00:11:17,700
which cost the world
tens of trillions of dollars,

129
00:11:17,870 --> 00:11:20,100
rendered 30 million people
unemployed

130
00:11:20,272 --> 00:11:23,537
and doubled the national debt
of the United States.

131
00:11:23,709 --> 00:11:28,874
With the destruction
of equity and housing wealth,

132
00:11:29,048 --> 00:11:31,539
the destruction of income,
of jobs,

133
00:11:31,717 --> 00:11:37,155
50 million people globally could
end up below the poverty line again.

134
00:11:38,023 --> 00:11:41,857
This is just a hugely,
hugely expensive crisis.

135
00:11:42,728 --> 00:11:45,288
This crisis was not an accident.

136
00:11:45,464 --> 00:11:48,661
It was caused
by an out-of-control industry.

137
00:11:48,834 --> 00:11:50,027
Since the 1980s,

138
00:11:50,201 --> 00:11:53,295
the rise of the U.S. Financial sector
has led to a series

139
00:11:53,471 --> 00:11:56,565
of increasingly severe
financial crises.

140
00:11:56,808 --> 00:11:59,800
Each crisis has caused
more damage,

141
00:11:59,977 --> 00:12:03,811
while the industry has made
more and more money.

142
00:12:11,956 --> 00:12:13,480
After the Great Depression

143
00:12:13,658 --> 00:12:16,525
the United States had 40 years
of economic growth

144
00:12:16,694 --> 00:12:18,992
without a single financial crisis.

145
00:12:19,163 --> 00:12:22,030
The financial industry
was tightly regulated.

146
00:12:22,200 --> 00:12:24,566
Most regular banks
were local businesses

147
00:12:24,735 --> 00:12:26,862
prohibited from speculating

148
00:12:27,038 --> 00:12:28,938
with depositors' savings.

149
00:12:29,407 --> 00:12:32,376
Investment banks, which handled
stock and bond trading,

150
00:12:32,543 --> 00:12:35,239
were small, private partnerships.

151
00:12:35,546 --> 00:12:39,107
In the traditional
investment banking model,

152
00:12:39,283 --> 00:12:41,513
the partners put the money up,

153
00:12:41,686 --> 00:12:45,122
and they watch that money
very carefully.

154
00:12:45,289 --> 00:12:46,756
They wanted to live well,

155
00:12:46,924 --> 00:12:49,722
but they didn't want to bet the ranch
on anything.

156
00:12:49,994 --> 00:12:52,519
Paul Volcker served
in the Treasury Department

157
00:12:52,697 --> 00:12:57,600
and was chairman of the
Federal Reserve from 1979 to 1987.

158
00:12:57,768 --> 00:12:59,395
Before going into government,

159
00:12:59,570 --> 00:13:02,767
he was a financial economist
at Chase Manhattan Bank.

160
00:13:03,074 --> 00:13:08,569
When I left Chase
to go in the Treasury in 1969,

161
00:13:08,746 --> 00:13:11,613
my income was in the neighborhood
of $45,000 a year.

162
00:13:11,782 --> 00:13:13,716
Forty-five thousand dollars a year.

163
00:13:13,885 --> 00:13:17,048
Morgan Stanley, in 1972,

164
00:13:17,221 --> 00:13:21,851
had approximately
110 total personnel,

165
00:13:22,026 --> 00:13:26,428
one office,
and capital of 12 million dollars.

166
00:13:26,596 --> 00:13:31,056
Now Morgan Stanley
has 50,000 workers

167
00:13:31,234 --> 00:13:35,227
and has capital of several billion

168
00:13:35,405 --> 00:13:37,965
and has offices all over the world.

169
00:13:38,141 --> 00:13:41,577
In the 1980s,
the financial industry exploded.

170
00:13:41,745 --> 00:13:43,576
The investment banks
went public,

171
00:13:43,747 --> 00:13:47,046
giving them huge amounts
of stockholder money.

172
00:13:47,217 --> 00:13:50,550
People on Wall Street
started getting rich.

173
00:13:51,521 --> 00:13:54,490
I had a friend
who was a bond trader

174
00:13:54,658 --> 00:13:58,651
at Merrill Lynch in the 1970s.

175
00:13:58,828 --> 00:14:02,594
He had a job as a train conductor
at night

176
00:14:02,766 --> 00:14:06,202
because he had three kids
and couldn't support them

177
00:14:06,369 --> 00:14:07,768
on what a trader made.

178
00:14:07,938 --> 00:14:11,601
By 1986,
he was making millions of dollars

179
00:14:11,775 --> 00:14:14,471
and thought
it was because he was smart.

180
00:14:15,212 --> 00:14:17,806
The highest order of business
before the nation

181
00:14:17,981 --> 00:14:20,347
is to restore
our economic prosperity.

182
00:14:20,517 --> 00:14:25,011
In 1981, President Ronald
Reagan chose as Treasury secretary

183
00:14:25,188 --> 00:14:28,680
the CEO of the investment bank
Merrill Lynch, Donald Regan.

184
00:14:28,858 --> 00:14:32,123
Wall Street and the president
see eye to eye.

185
00:14:32,829 --> 00:14:34,797
I've talked to leaders of Wall Street.

186
00:14:34,965 --> 00:14:37,695
They say, "We're behind
the president 100 percent."

187
00:14:37,867 --> 00:14:39,334
The Reagan administration,

188
00:14:39,502 --> 00:14:42,266
supported by economists
and financial lobbyists,

189
00:14:42,439 --> 00:14:46,375
started a 30-year period
of financial deregulation.

190
00:14:47,711 --> 00:14:50,271
In 1982,
the Reagan administration

191
00:14:50,447 --> 00:14:52,938
deregulated
savings-and-loan companies,

192
00:14:53,116 --> 00:14:56,677
allowing them to make risky
investments with depositors' money.

193
00:14:56,853 --> 00:14:58,285
By the end of the decade,

194
00:14:58,454 --> 00:15:01,548
hundreds of savings-and-loan
companies had failed.

195
00:15:01,724 --> 00:15:05,660
This crisis cost taxpayers
$ 124 billion

196
00:15:05,995 --> 00:15:08,793
and cost many people
their life savings.

197
00:15:08,964 --> 00:15:12,195
It may be the biggest bank heist
in our history.

198
00:15:12,368 --> 00:15:16,566
Thousands of executives went to jail
for looting their companies.

199
00:15:16,739 --> 00:15:19,333
One of the most extreme cases
was Charles Keating.

200
00:15:19,508 --> 00:15:20,839
Mr. Keating, got a word?

201
00:15:21,010 --> 00:15:25,276
In 1985, when federal regulators
began investigating him,

202
00:15:25,447 --> 00:15:29,076
Keating hired an economist
named Alan Greenspan.

203
00:15:29,251 --> 00:15:30,912
In this letter to regulators,

204
00:15:31,086 --> 00:15:34,647
Greenspan praised Keating's
sound business plans and expertise

205
00:15:34,823 --> 00:15:39,624
and said he saw no risk in allowing
Keating to invest customers' money.

206
00:15:40,796 --> 00:15:44,960
Keating reportedly
paid Greenspan $40,000.

207
00:15:46,535 --> 00:15:49,003
Keating went to prison
shortly afterwards.

208
00:15:49,571 --> 00:15:50,833
As for Alan Greenspan,

209
00:15:51,674 --> 00:15:55,110
Reagan appointed him
chairman of America's central bank,

210
00:15:55,277 --> 00:15:56,835
the Federal Reserve.

211
00:15:57,012 --> 00:15:58,536
Greenspan was reappointed

212
00:15:58,714 --> 00:16:02,411
by presidents Clinton
and George W. Bush.

213
00:16:03,252 --> 00:16:05,152
During the Clinton administration,

214
00:16:05,321 --> 00:16:07,585
deregulation continued
under Greenspan

215
00:16:07,756 --> 00:16:10,316
and Treasury secretaries
Robert Rubin,

216
00:16:10,492 --> 00:16:13,859
the former CEO of the
investment bank Goldman Sachs,

217
00:16:14,029 --> 00:16:17,521
and Larry Summers,
a Harvard economics Professor.

218
00:16:17,700 --> 00:16:20,760
The financial sector,
Wall Street being powerful,

219
00:16:20,936 --> 00:16:22,904
having lobbies, lots of money,

220
00:16:23,072 --> 00:16:26,564
step by step,
captured the political system.

221
00:16:26,742 --> 00:16:29,678
Both on the Democratic
and the Republican side.

222
00:16:30,546 --> 00:16:34,106
By the late 1990s, the
financial sector had consolidated

223
00:16:34,282 --> 00:16:37,774
into a few gigantic firms,
each of them so large

224
00:16:37,952 --> 00:16:40,978
that their failure could threaten
the whole system.

225
00:16:41,155 --> 00:16:44,750
And the Clinton administration
helped them grow even larger.

226
00:16:45,326 --> 00:16:48,693
In 1998,
Citicorp and Travelers merged

227
00:16:48,863 --> 00:16:50,228
to form Citigroup,

228
00:16:50,398 --> 00:16:53,265
the largest financial services
company in the world.

229
00:16:53,568 --> 00:16:56,002
The merger violated
the Glass-Steagall Act,

230
00:16:56,170 --> 00:16:58,502
a law passed
after the Great Depression,

231
00:16:58,673 --> 00:17:01,005
preventing banks
with consumer deposits

232
00:17:01,175 --> 00:17:04,406
from engaging in
risky investment-banking activities.

233
00:17:04,579 --> 00:17:07,412
It was illegal
to acquire Travelers.

234
00:17:07,582 --> 00:17:09,345
Greenspan said nothing.

235
00:17:09,517 --> 00:17:12,452
The Federal Reserve gave them
an exemption for a year,

236
00:17:12,620 --> 00:17:14,417
then they got the law passed.

237
00:17:14,722 --> 00:17:18,419
In 1999,
at the urging of Summers and Rubin,

238
00:17:18,593 --> 00:17:21,221
Congress passed
the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act,

239
00:17:21,396 --> 00:17:24,422
known to some
as the Citigroup Relief Act.

240
00:17:24,599 --> 00:17:26,726
It overturned Glass-Steagall

241
00:17:26,901 --> 00:17:29,893
and cleared the way
for future mergers.

242
00:17:38,446 --> 00:17:39,674
Why do you have big banks?

243
00:17:39,847 --> 00:17:43,874
Because banks like monopoly power,
lobbying power.

244
00:17:44,051 --> 00:17:48,545
Because banks know
that when they're too big,

245
00:17:48,723 --> 00:17:49,985
they will be bailed.

246
00:17:50,158 --> 00:17:52,626
Markets are inherently unstable.

247
00:17:52,794 --> 00:17:55,228
Or at least potentially unstable.

248
00:17:55,396 --> 00:17:59,230
An appropriate metaphor
is the oil tankers.

249
00:17:59,400 --> 00:18:00,697
They are very big,

250
00:18:01,035 --> 00:18:03,731
and therefore,
you have to put in compartments

251
00:18:04,205 --> 00:18:07,401
to prevent
the sloshing around of oil

252
00:18:07,574 --> 00:18:09,405
from capsizing the boat.

253
00:18:09,576 --> 00:18:12,909
The design of the boat
has to take that into account.

254
00:18:13,079 --> 00:18:16,048
And after the Depression,

255
00:18:16,216 --> 00:18:21,916
the regulations actually introduced
these very watertight compartments.

256
00:18:22,556 --> 00:18:28,392
And deregulation has led
to the end of compartmentalization.

257
00:18:29,162 --> 00:18:31,426
The next crisis
came at the end of the '90s.

258
00:18:32,399 --> 00:18:35,891
The investment banks fueled
a massive bubble in Internet stocks,

259
00:18:36,069 --> 00:18:38,765
which was followed by a crash
in 2001

260
00:18:38,939 --> 00:18:41,840
that caused $5 trillion
in investment losses.

261
00:18:42,409 --> 00:18:45,606
The Securities and Exchange
Commission, the federal agency

262
00:18:45,779 --> 00:18:49,237
created during the Depression
to regulate investment banking,

263
00:18:49,416 --> 00:18:51,077
had done nothing.

264
00:18:51,251 --> 00:18:54,880
In the absence of meaningful
federal action,

265
00:18:55,055 --> 00:18:57,580
and given the clear failure
of self-regulation,

266
00:18:57,757 --> 00:19:00,282
it's become necessary for others
to step in

267
00:19:00,460 --> 00:19:02,360
and adopt the protections needed.

268
00:19:02,529 --> 00:19:05,692
Eliot Spitzer's investigation
revealed the investment banks

269
00:19:05,866 --> 00:19:09,302
promoted Internet companies
they knew would fail.

270
00:19:09,469 --> 00:19:13,030
Analysts were being paid based on
how much business they brought in.

271
00:19:13,206 --> 00:19:17,540
What they said publicly was quite
different from what they said privately.

272
00:19:17,711 --> 00:19:20,179
Infospace, given the
highest possible rating,

273
00:19:20,347 --> 00:19:22,872
dismissed by an analyst
as a "piece of junk."

274
00:19:23,049 --> 00:19:27,110
Excite, also highly rated,
called "such a piece of crap."

275
00:19:27,287 --> 00:19:33,624
The defense that was proffered
by many of the investment banks

276
00:19:33,960 --> 00:19:36,520
was not "you're wrong,"

277
00:19:36,696 --> 00:19:40,154
it was, "Everybody's doing it,
everybody knows it's going on."

278
00:19:40,332 --> 00:19:42,459
Nobody should rely
on these analysts anyway."

279
00:19:42,935 --> 00:19:44,960
In December, 2002,

280
00:19:45,137 --> 00:19:49,665
10 investment banks settled
the case for a total of $ 1.4 billion

281
00:19:49,842 --> 00:19:52,572
and promised
to change their ways.

282
00:19:52,978 --> 00:19:56,846
Scott Talbott is the chief lobbyist for
the Financial Services Roundtable,

283
00:19:57,016 --> 00:19:59,416
one of Washington's
most powerful groups,

284
00:19:59,585 --> 00:20:03,453
which represents nearly all of the
world's largest financial companies.

285
00:20:03,622 --> 00:20:07,524
Are you comfortable with the
fact that several of your member companies

286
00:20:07,693 --> 00:20:10,685
have engaged
in large-scale criminal activity?

287
00:20:10,863 --> 00:20:12,922
L... You'll have to be specific.
Okay.

288
00:20:13,098 --> 00:20:16,966
And first of all, criminal activity
shouldn't be accepted, period.

289
00:20:25,477 --> 00:20:28,810
Since deregulation began,
the world's biggest financial firms

290
00:20:28,981 --> 00:20:32,178
have been caught laundering
money, defrauding customers

291
00:20:32,351 --> 00:20:36,287
and cooking their books
again and again and again.

292
00:20:47,132 --> 00:20:50,795
Credit Suisse helped funnel money
for Iran's nuclear program

293
00:20:50,970 --> 00:20:53,461
and for Iran's
Aerospace Industries Organization,

294
00:20:53,639 --> 00:20:55,402
which builds ballistic missiles.

295
00:20:55,574 --> 00:20:59,806
Any information that would identify it
as Iranian would be removed.

296
00:20:59,979 --> 00:21:03,039
The bank was fined $536 million.

297
00:21:03,215 --> 00:21:07,151
Citibank helped funnel $ 100 million
of drug money out of Mexico.

298
00:21:07,319 --> 00:21:09,879
Did you comment
that she should, quote:

299
00:21:10,055 --> 00:21:12,888
"Lose any documents connected
with the account"?

300
00:21:13,058 --> 00:21:16,515
I said that in a kidding manner.
It was at the early stages of this.

301
00:21:16,694 --> 00:21:18,059
I did not mean it seriously.

302
00:21:20,398 --> 00:21:23,231
Between 1998 and 2003,

303
00:21:23,401 --> 00:21:26,734
Fannie Mae overstated it's earnings
by more than $ 10 billion.

304
00:21:26,904 --> 00:21:29,031
These accounting standards
are complex

305
00:21:29,207 --> 00:21:33,041
and require determinations
over which experts often disagree.

306
00:21:33,211 --> 00:21:37,375
CEO Franklin Raines, who used to be
President Clinton's budget director,

307
00:21:37,548 --> 00:21:40,540
received over $52 million
in bonuses.

308
00:21:45,289 --> 00:21:48,622
When UBS was caught helping
wealthy Americans evade taxes,

309
00:21:48,793 --> 00:21:51,318
they refused to cooperate
with the government.

310
00:21:51,496 --> 00:21:53,794
Would you be willing
to supply the names?

311
00:21:54,332 --> 00:21:57,426
If there's a treaty framework.
No treaty framework.

312
00:21:57,602 --> 00:21:59,695
You've agreed
you participated in a fraud.

313
00:21:59,871 --> 00:22:00,895
Hm.

314
00:22:11,315 --> 00:22:13,715
But while the companies
face unprecedented fines,

315
00:22:13,885 --> 00:22:17,753
the investment firms do not
have to admit any wrongdoing.

316
00:22:17,922 --> 00:22:22,120
When dealing with this many products,
this many customers, mistakes happen.

317
00:22:22,293 --> 00:22:24,699
The financial
services industry

318
00:22:24,712 --> 00:22:27,128
seems to have a level
of criminality

319
00:22:27,298 --> 00:22:29,266
that is somewhat distinctive.

320
00:22:29,434 --> 00:22:33,131
You know, when was the last time
that Cisco

321
00:22:33,304 --> 00:22:37,434
or Intel or Google or Apple or IBM,
you know...?

322
00:22:37,608 --> 00:22:40,304
I agree about high-tech
versus financial services...

323
00:22:40,478 --> 00:22:43,879
So how come?
High-tech is a creative business

324
00:22:44,048 --> 00:22:45,948
where the value generation

325
00:22:46,117 --> 00:22:49,352
and income derives from
actually creating something new.

326
00:22:50,620 --> 00:22:52,019
Beginning in the 1990s,

327
00:22:52,189 --> 00:22:54,885
deregulation
and advances in technology

328
00:22:55,058 --> 00:22:59,222
led to an explosion of complex
financial products called derivatives.

329
00:22:59,396 --> 00:23:02,832
Economists and bankers
claimed they made markets safer.

330
00:23:02,999 --> 00:23:06,457
But instead,
they made them unstable.

331
00:23:06,636 --> 00:23:08,934
Since the end of the Cold War,

332
00:23:09,106 --> 00:23:12,098
a lot of former physicists,
mathematicians,

333
00:23:12,275 --> 00:23:14,436
decided to apply their skills,

334
00:23:14,611 --> 00:23:17,341
not on, you know,
Cold War technology,

335
00:23:17,514 --> 00:23:19,379
but on financial markets.

336
00:23:19,549 --> 00:23:21,676
And together
with investment bankers...

337
00:23:21,852 --> 00:23:23,149
Creating different weapons.

338
00:23:23,320 --> 00:23:24,344
Absolutely.

339
00:23:24,521 --> 00:23:27,490
You know, as Warren Buffett said,
weapons of mass destruction.

340
00:23:27,657 --> 00:23:30,990
Regulators, politicians,
business people

341
00:23:31,161 --> 00:23:34,756
did not take seriously
the threat of innovation

342
00:23:34,931 --> 00:23:37,627
on the stability
of the financial system.

343
00:23:38,235 --> 00:23:39,532
Using derivatives,

344
00:23:39,703 --> 00:23:42,501
bankers could gamble
on virtually anything.

345
00:23:42,672 --> 00:23:45,334
They could bet on the rise or fall
of oil prices,

346
00:23:45,509 --> 00:23:48,376
the bankruptcy of a company,
even the weather.

347
00:23:49,112 --> 00:23:50,807
By the late 1990s,

348
00:23:50,981 --> 00:23:55,975
derivatives were a 50-trillion-dollar
unregulated market.

349
00:23:56,319 --> 00:24:00,881
In 1998,
someone tried to regulate them.

350
00:24:01,057 --> 00:24:04,959
Brooksley Born graduated first
in her class at Stanford Law School

351
00:24:05,128 --> 00:24:08,461
and was the first woman
to edit a major law review.

352
00:24:08,632 --> 00:24:11,760
After running the derivatives practice
at Arnold & Porter,

353
00:24:11,935 --> 00:24:13,800
Born was appointed by Clinton

354
00:24:13,970 --> 00:24:16,837
to chair the Commodity Futures
Trading Commission,

355
00:24:17,007 --> 00:24:19,601
which oversaw
the derivatives market.

356
00:24:19,776 --> 00:24:23,336
Brooksley Born asked
me if I would come work with her.

357
00:24:23,946 --> 00:24:27,677
We decided that this was a serious,

358
00:24:27,850 --> 00:24:31,183
potentially destabilizing market.

359
00:24:31,353 --> 00:24:36,791
In May of 1998, the CFTC issued
a proposal to regulate derivatives.

360
00:24:36,959 --> 00:24:40,156
Clinton's Treasury Department
had an immediate response.

361
00:24:40,329 --> 00:24:44,891
I happened to go
into Brooksley's office,

362
00:24:45,067 --> 00:24:49,094
and she was just putting down
the receiver on her telephone,

363
00:24:49,271 --> 00:24:53,002
and the blood had drained
from her face.

364
00:24:53,175 --> 00:24:56,542
And she looked at me and said,
"That was Larry Summers."

365
00:24:56,712 --> 00:24:59,909
He had 13 bankers in his office.

366
00:25:00,316 --> 00:25:04,082
He conveyed it
in a very bullying fashion,

367
00:25:04,253 --> 00:25:07,518
sort of directing her to stop.

368
00:25:07,957 --> 00:25:11,449
Banks were now reliant for earnings
on these activities.

369
00:25:11,660 --> 00:25:17,997
And that led to a Titanic battle
to prevent this from being regulated.

370
00:25:18,167 --> 00:25:20,533
Shortly after the phone call
from Summers,

371
00:25:20,703 --> 00:25:24,935
Greenspan, Rubin,
and SEC chairman Arthur Levitt

372
00:25:25,107 --> 00:25:27,507
issued a joint statement
condemning Born

373
00:25:27,676 --> 00:25:32,272
and recommending legislation
to keep derivatives unregulated.

374
00:25:32,715 --> 00:25:35,616
Regulation of
derivatives transactions

375
00:25:35,784 --> 00:25:40,653
that are privately negotiated
by professionals is unnecessary.

376
00:25:40,823 --> 00:25:45,419
She was overruled, unfortunately.
First by the Clinton administration

377
00:25:45,594 --> 00:25:47,255
and then by the Congress.

378
00:25:47,429 --> 00:25:51,456
In 2000, Senator Phil Gramm took
a major role in getting a bill passed

379
00:25:51,634 --> 00:25:54,694
that pretty much exempted
derivatives from regulation.

380
00:25:54,870 --> 00:25:58,566
They are unifying markets,
reducing regulatory burden.

381
00:25:58,740 --> 00:26:00,537
I believe we need to do it.

382
00:26:07,982 --> 00:26:10,951
It is our very great hope

383
00:26:11,119 --> 00:26:14,555
that it will be possible
to move this year

384
00:26:14,722 --> 00:26:17,816
on legislation that,
in a suitable way

385
00:26:17,992 --> 00:26:24,329
goes to create legal certainty
for OTC derivatives.

386
00:26:30,972 --> 00:26:32,769
I wish to associate myself

387
00:26:32,941 --> 00:26:36,206
with all the remarks
of Secretary Summers.

388
00:26:36,611 --> 00:26:39,444
In December of
2000, Congress passed

389
00:26:39,614 --> 00:26:42,412
the Commodity Futures
Modernization Act.

390
00:26:42,583 --> 00:26:45,518
Written with the help
of financial-industry lobbyists,

391
00:26:45,687 --> 00:26:48,747
it banned the regulation
of derivatives.

392
00:26:49,691 --> 00:26:52,785
After that, it was off to the races.

393
00:26:53,361 --> 00:26:56,489
Use of derivatives
and financial innovation

394
00:26:56,664 --> 00:26:59,030
exploded dramatically after 2000.

395
00:26:59,200 --> 00:27:01,691
So help me God.
So help me God.

396
00:27:01,869 --> 00:27:05,566
By the time George W. Bush
took office in 2001,

397
00:27:05,740 --> 00:27:08,766
the U.S. Financial sector
was vastly more profitable,

398
00:27:08,943 --> 00:27:12,743
concentrated and powerful
than ever before.

399
00:27:12,981 --> 00:27:16,781
Dominating this industry
were five investment banks,

400
00:27:16,951 --> 00:27:19,215
two financial conglomerates,

401
00:27:19,387 --> 00:27:22,049
three securities insurance
companies

402
00:27:22,223 --> 00:27:24,521
and three rating agencies.

403
00:27:25,259 --> 00:27:28,626
And linking them all together
was the securitization food chain.

404
00:27:28,796 --> 00:27:31,662
A new system
which connected trillions of dollars

405
00:27:31,832 --> 00:27:36,326
in mortgages and other loans
with investors all over the world.

406
00:27:36,503 --> 00:27:39,165
Thirty years ago, if you went
to get a loan for a home,

407
00:27:39,339 --> 00:27:43,036
the person lending you the money
expected you to pay him or her back.

408
00:27:43,210 --> 00:27:46,145
You got a loan from a lender
who wanted to be paid back.

409
00:27:46,313 --> 00:27:50,147
We've since developed securitization,
whereby people who make the loan

410
00:27:50,317 --> 00:27:52,751
are no longer at risk
if they fail to repay.

411
00:27:53,220 --> 00:27:57,122
In the old system, when a homeowner
paid their mortgage every month,

412
00:27:57,290 --> 00:27:59,758
the money went
to their local lender.

413
00:27:59,926 --> 00:28:04,920
And since mortgages took decades
to repay, lenders were careful.

414
00:28:05,265 --> 00:28:09,759
In the new system, lenders sold
mortgages to investment banks.

415
00:28:09,936 --> 00:28:13,303
The banks combined
thousands of mortgages and loans,

416
00:28:13,473 --> 00:28:17,534
including car loans, student loans,
and credit card debt,

417
00:28:17,711 --> 00:28:21,875
to create complex derivatives called
collateralized debt obligations,

418
00:28:22,049 --> 00:28:23,778
or CDOs.

419
00:28:23,950 --> 00:28:28,819
The investment banks then sold
the CDOs to investors.

420
00:28:28,989 --> 00:28:31,287
Now when homeowners paid
their mortgages,

421
00:28:31,458 --> 00:28:34,552
the money went to investors
all over the world.

422
00:28:34,828 --> 00:28:37,296
The investment banks
paid rating agencies

423
00:28:37,464 --> 00:28:39,159
to evaluate the CDOs,

424
00:28:39,332 --> 00:28:41,994
and many of them
were given a triple-A rating,

425
00:28:42,169 --> 00:28:44,797
which is the highest possible
investment grade.

426
00:28:44,971 --> 00:28:47,997
This made CDOs popular
with retirement funds,

427
00:28:48,175 --> 00:28:51,941
which could only purchase
highly rated securities.

428
00:28:53,613 --> 00:28:56,446
This system
was a ticking time bomb.

429
00:28:56,616 --> 00:29:00,279
Lenders didn't care anymore about
whether a borrower could repay,

430
00:29:00,454 --> 00:29:03,150
so they started making
riskier loans.

431
00:29:03,323 --> 00:29:05,484
The investment banks
didn't care either.

432
00:29:05,659 --> 00:29:09,389
The more CDOs they sold,
the higher their profits.

433
00:29:09,562 --> 00:29:13,123
And the rating agencies, which
were paid by the investment banks,

434
00:29:13,299 --> 00:29:17,759
had no liability if their ratings
of CDOs proved wrong.

435
00:29:18,904 --> 00:29:23,136
You weren't gonna be on the hook,
there weren't regulatory constraints.

436
00:29:23,309 --> 00:29:26,506
So it was a green light to just
pump out more and more loans.

437
00:29:26,979 --> 00:29:29,812
Between 2000 and 2003,

438
00:29:29,982 --> 00:29:34,749
the number of mortgage loans
made each year nearly quadrupled.

439
00:29:34,920 --> 00:29:37,855
Everybody in this
securitization food chain,

440
00:29:38,023 --> 00:29:40,514
from the very beginning
until the end,

441
00:29:40,693 --> 00:29:43,025
didn't care about
the quality of the mortgage.

442
00:29:43,195 --> 00:29:45,720
They were caring
about maximizing their volume

443
00:29:45,898 --> 00:29:47,661
and getting a fee out of it.

444
00:29:47,833 --> 00:29:49,323
In the early 2000s,

445
00:29:49,502 --> 00:29:54,235
there was a huge increase in the
riskiest loans, called subprime.

446
00:29:54,406 --> 00:29:58,968
When thousands of subprime loans
were combined to create CDOs,

447
00:29:59,145 --> 00:30:02,774
many of them still received
triple-A ratings.

448
00:30:04,984 --> 00:30:09,478
Now, it would have been
possible to create derivative products

449
00:30:09,655 --> 00:30:11,885
that don't have these risks,

450
00:30:12,057 --> 00:30:14,457
that carry the equivalent
of deductibles,

451
00:30:14,627 --> 00:30:19,428
where there are limits on the risks
that can be taken on, and so forth.

452
00:30:19,598 --> 00:30:22,032
They didn't do that, did they?
They didn't.

453
00:30:22,201 --> 00:30:24,066
In retrospect,
they should've done.

454
00:30:24,236 --> 00:30:27,148
So did these guys know
they were doing something dangerous?

455
00:30:27,173 --> 00:30:28,470
I think they did.

456
00:30:46,291 --> 00:30:51,251
All the incentives financial institutions
offered to their mortgage brokers

457
00:30:51,429 --> 00:30:55,024
were based on selling
the most profitable products,

458
00:30:55,200 --> 00:30:56,827
which were predatory loans.

459
00:30:57,168 --> 00:31:01,339
If they make more money,
that's where they'll put you.

460
00:31:07,178 --> 00:31:10,170
Suddenly, hundreds
of billions of dollars a year

461
00:31:10,348 --> 00:31:13,146
were flowing through
the securitization chain.

462
00:31:13,318 --> 00:31:15,183
Since anyone could get
a mortgage,

463
00:31:15,353 --> 00:31:18,379
home purchases
and housing prices skyrocketed.

464
00:31:18,556 --> 00:31:23,016
The result was the biggest
financial bubble in history.

465
00:31:23,194 --> 00:31:25,628
Real estate is real.
They can see their asset.

466
00:31:25,797 --> 00:31:28,925
They can live in their asset.
They can rent out their asset.

467
00:31:29,100 --> 00:31:32,331
You had a huge boom in housing
that made no sense at all.

468
00:31:32,704 --> 00:31:39,041
The financing appetites
of the financial sector

469
00:31:39,377 --> 00:31:42,312
drove what everybody else did.

470
00:31:42,480 --> 00:31:46,348
Last time we had a housing bubble
was in the late '80s.

471
00:31:47,485 --> 00:31:51,615
In that case, the increase in home
price had been relatively minor.

472
00:31:51,990 --> 00:31:56,723
That housing bubble led
to a relatively severe recession.

473
00:31:56,894 --> 00:32:00,955
From 1996 until 2006,

474
00:32:01,132 --> 00:32:03,965
real home prices
effectively doubled.

475
00:32:08,906 --> 00:32:13,366
At $500 a ticket, they've come to
hear how to buy their very own piece

476
00:32:13,544 --> 00:32:15,738
of the American dream.

477
00:32:15,912 --> 00:32:20,076
Goldman Sachs, Bear Stearns,
Lehman Brothers,

478
00:32:20,250 --> 00:32:23,048
Merrill Lynch were all in on this.

479
00:32:23,220 --> 00:32:29,090
The subprime lending alone increased
from 30 billion a year in funding

480
00:32:29,259 --> 00:32:33,195
to over 600 billion a year
in 10 years.

481
00:32:33,363 --> 00:32:34,887
They knew what was happening.

482
00:32:35,265 --> 00:32:38,632
Countrywide Financial,
the largest subprime lender,

483
00:32:38,802 --> 00:32:42,829
issued $97 billion worth of loans.

484
00:32:43,006 --> 00:32:47,568
It made over $ 11 billion in profits
as a result.

485
00:32:48,312 --> 00:32:51,645
On Wall Street,
annual cash bonuses spiked.

486
00:32:51,815 --> 00:32:53,305
Traders and CEOs

487
00:32:53,483 --> 00:32:56,179
became enormously wealthy
during the bubble.

488
00:32:56,353 --> 00:33:00,312
Lehman Brothers was a top
underwriter of subprime lending,

489
00:33:00,490 --> 00:33:02,720
and their CEO, Richard Fuld,

490
00:33:03,060 --> 00:33:06,791
took home $485 million.

491
00:33:06,963 --> 00:33:10,228
On Wall Street,
this housing and credit bubble

492
00:33:10,400 --> 00:33:13,927
was leading to hundreds
of billions of dollars of profits.

493
00:33:14,104 --> 00:33:17,540
You know, by 2006
about 40 percent of all profits

494
00:33:17,708 --> 00:33:21,804
of S&P 500 firms was coming
from financial institutions.

495
00:33:21,978 --> 00:33:24,139
It wasn't real profits or income.

496
00:33:24,314 --> 00:33:29,183
It was money created by the system
and booked as income.

497
00:33:29,353 --> 00:33:32,948
Two, three years down the road
there's a default, it's all wiped out.

498
00:33:33,123 --> 00:33:37,082
I think it was, in fact, in retrospect,
a great big national...

499
00:33:37,260 --> 00:33:39,922
And not just national,
global Ponzi scheme.

500
00:33:40,664 --> 00:33:43,531
Through the Home Ownership
and Equity Protection Act,

501
00:33:43,700 --> 00:33:46,362
the Federal Reserve board
had broad authority

502
00:33:46,536 --> 00:33:48,504
to regulate the mortgage industry.

503
00:33:48,671 --> 00:33:52,300
But Fed chairman Alan Greenspan
refused to use it.

504
00:33:52,475 --> 00:33:55,000
Alan Greenspan said,
"No, that's regulation.

505
00:33:55,177 --> 00:33:56,508
I don't believe in it."

506
00:33:56,679 --> 00:34:00,513
For 20 years, Robert Gnaizda
was the head of Greenlining,

507
00:34:00,683 --> 00:34:03,117
a powerful consumer
advocacy group.

508
00:34:03,285 --> 00:34:06,049
He met with Greenspan
on a regular basis.

509
00:34:06,222 --> 00:34:08,690
We gave him an example
of Countrywide

510
00:34:08,858 --> 00:34:13,921
and 150 different complex
adjustable-rate mortgages.

511
00:34:14,096 --> 00:34:16,929
He said,
"If you had a doctorate in math"

512
00:34:17,099 --> 00:34:19,795
you wouldn't be able
to understand them enough

513
00:34:19,969 --> 00:34:23,302
"to know which was good for you
and which wasn't."

514
00:34:23,706 --> 00:34:26,539
So we thought
he was gonna take action.

515
00:34:26,709 --> 00:34:28,939
But as the conversation continued,

516
00:34:29,111 --> 00:34:31,944
it was clear he was stuck
with his ideology.

517
00:34:32,114 --> 00:34:35,208
We met again
with Greenspan in '05.

518
00:34:35,384 --> 00:34:39,286
Often we met with him twice a year,
and never less than once a year.

519
00:34:39,455 --> 00:34:41,616
And he wouldn't change his mind.

520
00:34:46,695 --> 00:34:50,392
In this world
of global communications,

521
00:34:50,566 --> 00:34:52,591
the efficient movement
of capital

522
00:34:52,768 --> 00:34:56,465
is helping to create the greatest
prosperity in human history.

523
00:35:02,845 --> 00:35:06,713
A hundred and forty-six people were cut
from the SEC Enforcement Division?

524
00:35:06,882 --> 00:35:08,816
Is that what you also testified to?

525
00:35:08,984 --> 00:35:10,281
Yes.

526
00:35:10,453 --> 00:35:15,789
Yeah, I think there has been
a systematic gutting,

527
00:35:15,958 --> 00:35:18,552
or whatever you wanna call it,
of the agency

528
00:35:18,727 --> 00:35:21,821
and it's capability
through cutting back of staff.

529
00:35:21,997 --> 00:35:24,726
The SEC Office
of Risk Management

530
00:35:24,899 --> 00:35:28,858
was reduced to a staff,
did you say, of one?

531
00:35:29,037 --> 00:35:33,167
Yeah. When that gentleman would
go home, he could turn the lights out.

532
00:35:35,143 --> 00:35:38,340
During the bubble, investment
banks were borrowing heavily

533
00:35:38,513 --> 00:35:42,313
to buy more loans
and create more CDOs.

534
00:35:43,117 --> 00:35:46,245
The ratio between borrowed money
and the banks' own money

535
00:35:46,421 --> 00:35:48,286
was called leverage.

536
00:35:48,456 --> 00:35:52,620
The more the banks borrowed,
the higher their leverage.

537
00:35:53,862 --> 00:35:58,356
In 2004, Henry Paulson,
the CEO of Goldman Sachs,

538
00:35:58,533 --> 00:36:02,799
helped lobby the SEC
to relax limits on leverage,

539
00:36:03,238 --> 00:36:07,072
allowing the banks
to sharply increase their borrowing.

540
00:36:07,242 --> 00:36:09,767
The SEC somehow decided

541
00:36:09,944 --> 00:36:13,311
to let investment banks
gamble a lot more.

542
00:36:13,481 --> 00:36:16,609
That was nuts. I don't know why
they did that, but they did.

543
00:36:23,324 --> 00:36:26,724
We've said these
are the big guys, and clearly that's true.

544
00:36:26,728 --> 00:36:32,394
But that means if anything goes wrong,
it's going to be an awfully big mess.

545
00:36:33,535 --> 00:36:36,305
You are
dealing with the most

546
00:36:36,318 --> 00:36:39,098
highly sophisticated
financial institutions.

547
00:36:39,274 --> 00:36:43,074
These are the firms that do
most of the derivative activity.

548
00:36:43,244 --> 00:36:46,680
We talked to some
as to what their comfort level was.

549
00:36:46,848 --> 00:36:51,842
The firms actually thought
that the number was appropriate.

550
00:36:52,020 --> 00:36:56,320
The commissioners vote to
adopt the new rules as recommended.

551
00:36:56,491 --> 00:36:57,684
- Yes.
- Yes.

552
00:36:58,091 --> 00:37:01,862
We do indeed. It's unanimous.
And we are adjourned.

553
00:37:04,698 --> 00:37:07,929
The degree of leverage
in the financial system

554
00:37:08,101 --> 00:37:10,626
became absolutely frightening.

555
00:37:10,804 --> 00:37:15,264
Investment banks leveraging
up to the level of 33-to-1.

556
00:37:15,442 --> 00:37:18,138
Which means that
a tiny 3-percent decrease

557
00:37:18,312 --> 00:37:21,645
in the value of their asset base
would leave them insolvent.

558
00:37:23,951 --> 00:37:27,216
There was another ticking
time bomb in the financial system.

559
00:37:27,387 --> 00:37:30,652
AIG, the world's largest
insurance company,

560
00:37:30,824 --> 00:37:33,315
was selling huge quantities
of derivatives

561
00:37:33,493 --> 00:37:35,324
called credit default swaps.

562
00:37:37,264 --> 00:37:39,459
For investors who owned CDOs,

563
00:37:39,633 --> 00:37:43,160
credit default swaps worked
like an insurance policy.

564
00:37:43,337 --> 00:37:45,965
An investor who purchased
a credit default swap

565
00:37:46,139 --> 00:37:49,131
paid AIG a quarterly premium.

566
00:37:49,309 --> 00:37:51,072
If the CDO went bad,

567
00:37:51,244 --> 00:37:55,374
AIG promised to pay the investor
for their losses.

568
00:37:56,416 --> 00:37:58,350
But unlike regular insurance,

569
00:37:58,518 --> 00:38:02,113
speculators could also buy
credit default swaps from AIG

570
00:38:02,289 --> 00:38:05,884
in order to bet against CDOs
they didn't own.

571
00:38:06,360 --> 00:38:09,454
In insurance, you can only
insure something you own.

572
00:38:09,630 --> 00:38:12,690
Let's say you and I own property.
I own a house.

573
00:38:12,866 --> 00:38:15,232
I can only insure that house once.

574
00:38:15,402 --> 00:38:18,337
The derivatives universe
essentially enables anybody

575
00:38:18,505 --> 00:38:20,473
to actually insure that house.

576
00:38:20,641 --> 00:38:22,973
You could insure that,
somebody else could.

577
00:38:23,143 --> 00:38:25,202
So 50 people might insure
my house.

578
00:38:25,379 --> 00:38:28,109
So what happens is,
if my house burns down,

579
00:38:28,281 --> 00:38:32,114
the number of losses in the system
becomes proportionately larger.

580
00:38:32,685 --> 00:38:35,449
Since credit default swaps
were unregulated,

581
00:38:35,621 --> 00:38:39,955
AIG didn't have to put aside
any money to cover potential losses.

582
00:38:40,126 --> 00:38:44,187
Instead, AIG paid it's employees
huge cash bonuses

583
00:38:44,363 --> 00:38:46,729
as soon as contracts
were signed.

584
00:38:46,899 --> 00:38:49,367
But if the CDOs later went bad,

585
00:38:49,535 --> 00:38:52,163
AIG would be on the hook.

586
00:38:52,338 --> 00:38:56,502
People were essentially being
rewarded for taking massive risks.

587
00:38:56,676 --> 00:39:00,510
In good times, they generate
short-term revenues and profits

588
00:39:00,680 --> 00:39:02,113
and, therefore, bonuses.

589
00:39:02,281 --> 00:39:05,648
But that's gonna lead to the firm
to be bankrupt over time.

590
00:39:05,818 --> 00:39:08,309
That's a distorted system
of compensation.

591
00:39:09,055 --> 00:39:12,081
AIG's Financial Products division
in London

592
00:39:12,258 --> 00:39:16,627
issued $500 billion worth of credit
default swaps during the bubble,

593
00:39:17,329 --> 00:39:21,789
many of them for CDOs
backed by subprime mortgages.

594
00:39:21,967 --> 00:39:24,401
The 400 employees at AIGFP

595
00:39:24,570 --> 00:39:28,597
made $3.5 billion
between 2000 and 2007.

596
00:39:29,375 --> 00:39:32,105
Joseph Cassano,
the head of AIGFP,

597
00:39:32,278 --> 00:39:35,475
personally made $315 million.

598
00:39:35,648 --> 00:39:37,209
It's hard for us,

599
00:39:37,216 --> 00:39:41,880
and without being flippant,
to even see a scenario

600
00:39:42,054 --> 00:39:44,352
within any kind of realm of reason

601
00:39:44,523 --> 00:39:49,426
that would see us losing one dollar
in any of those transactions.

602
00:39:49,762 --> 00:39:53,926
In 2007, AIG's
auditors raised warnings.

603
00:39:54,100 --> 00:39:56,193
One of them, Joseph St. Denis,

604
00:39:56,368 --> 00:39:59,997
resigned in protest after
Cassano repeatedly blocked him

605
00:40:00,172 --> 00:40:03,107
from investigating
AIGFP's accounting.

606
00:40:03,275 --> 00:40:05,231
Let me tell you one
person that didn't get a

607
00:40:05,244 --> 00:40:07,210
bonus while everybody
else was getting bonuses.

608
00:40:07,378 --> 00:40:11,371
That was St. Denis. Mr. St. Denis
tried to alert the two of you

609
00:40:11,549 --> 00:40:14,211
to the fact you were running
into big problems.

610
00:40:14,753 --> 00:40:18,018
He quit in frustration,
and he didn't get a bonus.

611
00:40:18,389 --> 00:40:21,153
In 2005, Raghuram Rajan,

612
00:40:21,326 --> 00:40:24,818
then the chief economist
of the International Monetary Fund,

613
00:40:24,996 --> 00:40:27,624
delivered a paper
at the Jackson Hole symposium,

614
00:40:27,799 --> 00:40:30,461
the most elite banking conference
in the world.

615
00:40:30,635 --> 00:40:32,125
Who was in the audience?

616
00:40:32,303 --> 00:40:37,138
It was the central bankers
of the world,

617
00:40:37,308 --> 00:40:40,675
ranging from
Mr. Greenspan himself,

618
00:40:40,845 --> 00:40:42,039
Ben Bernanke

619
00:40:42,213 --> 00:40:43,339
Larry Summers.

620
00:40:43,615 --> 00:40:45,480
Tim Geithner was there.

621
00:40:45,650 --> 00:40:47,618
The title of the paper
was essentially:

622
00:40:47,919 --> 00:40:51,514
"Is Financial Development
Making the World Riskier?"

623
00:40:51,689 --> 00:40:55,056
And the conclusion was, it is.

624
00:40:57,095 --> 00:40:59,825
Rajan's paper focused
on incentive structures

625
00:40:59,998 --> 00:41:04,230
that generated huge cash bonuses
based on short-term profits,

626
00:41:04,402 --> 00:41:07,667
but which imposed no penalties
for later losses.

627
00:41:07,839 --> 00:41:10,774
Rajan argued that these incentives
encouraged bankers

628
00:41:10,942 --> 00:41:14,537
to take risks that might eventually
destroy their own firms

629
00:41:14,712 --> 00:41:17,943
or even the entire
financial system.

630
00:41:20,518 --> 00:41:24,750
It's very easy to generate
performance by taking on more risk.

631
00:41:24,923 --> 00:41:29,451
So what you need to do is compensate
for risk-adjusted performance.

632
00:41:29,627 --> 00:41:31,891
And that's where
all the bodies are buried.

633
00:41:32,063 --> 00:41:35,191
Rajan, you know,
hit the nail on the head.

634
00:41:35,366 --> 00:41:37,357
What he particularly said was:

635
00:41:37,535 --> 00:41:39,935
"You guys have claimed
you've found a way"

636
00:41:40,103 --> 00:41:42,571
to make more profits
with less risk.

637
00:41:42,739 --> 00:41:45,936
I say you've found a way
to make more profits with more risk.

638
00:41:46,109 --> 00:41:47,474
"There's a big difference."

639
00:41:47,644 --> 00:41:50,238
Summers was vocal.

640
00:41:50,581 --> 00:41:52,776
He basically thought

641
00:41:52,950 --> 00:41:58,217
that I was criticizing the change
in the financial world

642
00:41:58,388 --> 00:42:01,687
and was worried about,
you know, regulation,

643
00:42:01,859 --> 00:42:03,884
which would reverse
this change.

644
00:42:04,061 --> 00:42:06,461
Essentially he accused me
of being a Luddite.

645
00:42:07,531 --> 00:42:11,092
He wanted to make sure
that we didn't bring in

646
00:42:11,268 --> 00:42:13,065
a whole new set of regulations

647
00:42:13,237 --> 00:42:15,728
to constrain the financial sector.

648
00:42:19,843 --> 00:42:23,973
You're gonna make an extra $2 million
a year, or $ 10 million a year,

649
00:42:24,147 --> 00:42:26,741
for putting your financial institution
at risk.

650
00:42:26,917 --> 00:42:29,044
Someone else pays the bill,
you don't.

651
00:42:29,219 --> 00:42:30,652
Would you make that bet?

652
00:42:30,821 --> 00:42:34,132
Most people on Wall Street said,
"Sure, I'd make that bet."

653
00:43:17,400 --> 00:43:18,890
It never was enough.

654
00:43:19,068 --> 00:43:22,333
They don't wanna own one home,
they wanna own five homes.

655
00:43:22,505 --> 00:43:25,303
And they wanna have
an expensive penthouse

656
00:43:25,474 --> 00:43:27,601
on Park Avenue.

657
00:43:28,177 --> 00:43:31,044
And they wanna have
their own private jet.

658
00:43:31,213 --> 00:43:34,080
You think this
is an industry where high...?

659
00:43:34,250 --> 00:43:36,480
Very high compensation levels
are justified?

660
00:43:36,652 --> 00:43:39,348
I think I would take caution,
or take heed,

661
00:43:39,522 --> 00:43:42,719
or take exception to your word
"very high." It's relative.

662
00:43:42,892 --> 00:43:45,258
You have a 14-million-dollar home
in Florida.

663
00:43:45,428 --> 00:43:48,329
You have a summer home
in Sun Valley, Idaho.

664
00:43:48,497 --> 00:43:51,933
An art collection filled
with million-dollar paintings.

665
00:43:52,101 --> 00:43:54,729
Richard Fuld never
appeared on the trading floor.

666
00:43:54,904 --> 00:43:57,202
There were art advisors there
all the time.

667
00:43:57,373 --> 00:43:58,965
He had a private elevator.

668
00:43:59,141 --> 00:44:01,701
He wanted to be disconnected.

669
00:44:01,877 --> 00:44:04,710
His elevator,
they hired technicians to program it

670
00:44:04,880 --> 00:44:07,644
so that his driver would call in
in the morning

671
00:44:07,817 --> 00:44:09,944
and a security guard
would hold it.

672
00:44:10,119 --> 00:44:14,579
There's only a three-second window
where he actually has to see people.

673
00:44:14,757 --> 00:44:17,783
And he hops into this elevator
and it goes straight to 31.

674
00:44:17,960 --> 00:44:20,258
Lehman owned corporate jets.

675
00:44:20,429 --> 00:44:22,454
You know about this?
Yes.

676
00:44:22,631 --> 00:44:23,941
How many were there?

677
00:44:23,966 --> 00:44:26,628
Well, there were
six, including the 767 s.

678
00:44:26,902 --> 00:44:28,563
They also had a helicopter.

679
00:44:28,738 --> 00:44:31,229
Isn't that kind
of a lot of planes to have?

680
00:44:34,110 --> 00:44:36,078
We're dealing with
type-A personalities.

681
00:44:36,278 --> 00:44:38,508
And type-A personalities know
everything in the world.

682
00:44:38,681 --> 00:44:41,013
Banking became a pissing contest.

683
00:44:41,183 --> 00:44:43,447
"Mine's bigger than yours."
That kind of stuff.

684
00:44:43,619 --> 00:44:45,780
It was all men that ran it,
incidentally.

685
00:44:45,955 --> 00:44:49,947
Fifty-billion-dollar deals weren't large
enough, so we'd do 100-billion deals.

686
00:44:50,125 --> 00:44:52,958
These people are risk-takers.
They're impulsive.

687
00:44:58,433 --> 00:45:01,561
It's part of their behavior.
It's part of their personality.

688
00:45:01,736 --> 00:45:04,796
And that manifests
outside of work as well.

689
00:45:04,973 --> 00:45:07,498
It was quite typical
for the guys to go out

690
00:45:07,675 --> 00:45:09,666
to go to strip bars, to use drugs.

691
00:45:09,844 --> 00:45:12,642
I see a lot of cocaine use,
use of prostitution.

692
00:45:19,754 --> 00:45:22,086
Recently, neuroscientists
have done experiments

693
00:45:22,257 --> 00:45:27,217
where they've taken individuals
and put them into an MRI machine,

694
00:45:27,395 --> 00:45:31,661
and they have them play a game
where the prize is money.

695
00:45:31,833 --> 00:45:35,428
And they noticed that when
the subjects earn money,

696
00:45:35,603 --> 00:45:37,901
the part of the brain
that gets stimulated

697
00:45:38,073 --> 00:45:40,439
is the same part
that cocaine stimulates.

698
00:45:40,608 --> 00:45:44,271
A lot of people feel that they
need to participate in that behavior

699
00:45:44,446 --> 00:45:46,880
to make it, to get promoted,
get recognized.

700
00:45:47,048 --> 00:45:50,108
According to a Bloomberg
article, business entertainment

701
00:45:50,285 --> 00:45:53,618
represents 5 percent of revenue
for derivatives brokers

702
00:45:53,788 --> 00:45:58,122
and often includes strip clubs,
prostitution and drugs.

703
00:45:58,293 --> 00:46:01,956
A New York broker filed a lawsuit
in 2007 against his firm

704
00:46:02,530 --> 00:46:07,331
alleging he was required to retain
prostitutes to entertain traders.

705
00:46:07,502 --> 00:46:09,367
There's just a blatant disregard

706
00:46:09,537 --> 00:46:14,201
for the impact that their actions
might have on society, on family.

707
00:46:14,375 --> 00:46:17,606
They have no problem
using a prostitute

708
00:46:17,779 --> 00:46:20,009
and going home to their wife.

709
00:46:29,022 --> 00:46:30,922
How many customers?

710
00:46:31,091 --> 00:46:33,389
About 10,000
at that point in time.

711
00:46:37,531 --> 00:46:39,692
What fraction
were from Wall Street?

712
00:46:39,867 --> 00:46:44,327
Of the higher-end clients,
probably 40 to 50 percent.

713
00:46:44,505 --> 00:46:46,945
Were all the major
Wall Street firms represented?

714
00:46:47,107 --> 00:46:48,131
Goldman Sachs?

715
00:46:48,308 --> 00:46:51,243
Lehman Brothers.
They're all in there.

716
00:46:51,411 --> 00:46:55,211
Morgan Stanley was
a little less of that.

717
00:46:55,382 --> 00:46:58,408
I think Goldman was
pretty, pretty big with that.

718
00:46:58,719 --> 00:47:00,152
Clients would call and say:

719
00:47:00,320 --> 00:47:03,084
"Can you get me a Lamborghini
for the girl?"

720
00:47:03,257 --> 00:47:05,555
These guys were spending
corporate money.

721
00:47:05,726 --> 00:47:10,095
I had many black cards from,
you know, the various financial firms.

722
00:47:10,597 --> 00:47:13,998
What's happening is
services are being charged

723
00:47:14,168 --> 00:47:15,931
to computer repair.

724
00:47:16,270 --> 00:47:20,434
Trading research, you know,
consulting for market compliance.

725
00:47:20,607 --> 00:47:23,872
Just gave them letterhead and said,
"Make your own invoice."

726
00:47:24,044 --> 00:47:27,207
This behavior extends to
the senior management of the firm?

727
00:47:27,381 --> 00:47:29,008
Absolutely does. Yeah.

728
00:47:29,183 --> 00:47:31,276
I know for a fact that it does.

729
00:47:31,451 --> 00:47:34,215
It extends to the very top.

730
00:47:37,691 --> 00:47:41,855
A friend of mine in a company that
has a big financial presence said:

731
00:47:42,029 --> 00:47:45,988
"It's about time you learned
about subprime mortgages."

732
00:47:46,166 --> 00:47:49,932
So he set up a session
with his trading desk and me.

733
00:47:50,337 --> 00:47:53,966
And the techie who did all this
gets very excited,

734
00:47:54,141 --> 00:47:57,632
runs to his computer,
pulls up in about three seconds

735
00:47:57,810 --> 00:48:00,836
this Goldman Sachs
issue of securities.

736
00:48:01,013 --> 00:48:02,446
It was a complete disaster.

737
00:48:02,815 --> 00:48:08,185
Borrowers had borrowed, on average,
99.3 percent of the price of the house.

738
00:48:08,354 --> 00:48:10,254
They have no money
in the house.

739
00:48:10,423 --> 00:48:13,654
If anything goes wrong,
they walk away from the mortgage.

740
00:48:13,826 --> 00:48:16,590
This is not a loan
you'd really make, right?

741
00:48:16,762 --> 00:48:18,195
You've gotta be crazy.

742
00:48:18,364 --> 00:48:21,492
But somehow,
you took 8000 of these loans,

743
00:48:21,667 --> 00:48:23,862
and by the time
the guys were done

744
00:48:24,036 --> 00:48:26,834
at Goldman Sachs
and the rating agencies,

745
00:48:27,006 --> 00:48:29,440
two-thirds of the loans
were rated triple-A.

746
00:48:29,609 --> 00:48:32,476
They were rated as safe
as government securities.

747
00:48:32,645 --> 00:48:34,169
It's utterly mad.

748
00:48:35,047 --> 00:48:38,608
Goldman Sachs sold at least $3.
1 billion worth

749
00:48:38,784 --> 00:48:42,550
of these toxic CDOs
in the first half of 2006.

750
00:48:42,955 --> 00:48:46,891
The CEO of Goldman Sachs
at this time was Henry Paulson,

751
00:48:47,059 --> 00:48:49,550
the highest paid CEO
on Wall Street.

752
00:48:52,231 --> 00:48:54,461
Good morning.
I'm pleased to announce

753
00:48:54,634 --> 00:48:58,502
that I will nominate Henry Paulson
to be the Secretary of the Treasury.

754
00:48:58,671 --> 00:49:00,400
He has a lifetime of experience.

755
00:49:00,573 --> 00:49:02,734
He has knowledge
of financial markets.

756
00:49:02,908 --> 00:49:05,809
He's earned a reputation
for candor and integrity.

757
00:49:06,312 --> 00:49:08,177
You might think it would be hard

758
00:49:08,347 --> 00:49:10,907
to adjust to a meager
government salary.

759
00:49:11,083 --> 00:49:13,313
But taking the job
as Treasury secretary

760
00:49:13,486 --> 00:49:16,478
was the best
financial decision of his life.

761
00:49:16,656 --> 00:49:20,990
Paulson had to sell his $485 million
of Goldman stock

762
00:49:21,160 --> 00:49:23,321
when he went to work
for the government.

763
00:49:23,496 --> 00:49:26,522
But because of a law passed
by the first President Bush,

764
00:49:26,699 --> 00:49:28,860
he didn't have to pay
any taxes on it.

765
00:49:29,035 --> 00:49:32,060
It saved him $50 million.

766
00:49:38,843 --> 00:49:42,472
The article came
out in October of 2007.

767
00:49:42,814 --> 00:49:46,341
Already, a third of
the mortgages defaulted.

768
00:49:46,518 --> 00:49:48,952
Now most of them are going.

769
00:49:51,189 --> 00:49:54,420
One group that had purchased
these now worthless securities

770
00:49:54,592 --> 00:49:58,084
was the Public Employees'
Retirement System of Mississippi,

771
00:49:58,263 --> 00:50:01,790
which provides monthly benefits
to over 80,000 retirees.

772
00:50:02,734 --> 00:50:07,535
They lost millions of dollars
and are now suing Goldman Sachs.

773
00:50:21,519 --> 00:50:25,853
By late 2006, Goldman had
taken things a step further.

774
00:50:26,024 --> 00:50:28,515
It didn't just sell toxic CDOs,

775
00:50:28,693 --> 00:50:32,857
it started betting against them at the
