same time it was telling customers

776
00:50:33,031 --> 00:50:35,761
that they were
high-quality investments.

777
00:50:36,668 --> 00:50:39,933
By purchasing credit default swaps
from AIG,

778
00:50:40,105 --> 00:50:43,074
Goldman could bet against
CDOs it didn't own

779
00:50:43,241 --> 00:50:46,472
and get paid
when the CDOs failed.

780
00:50:47,445 --> 00:50:51,643
I asked if anybody
called the customers and said:

781
00:50:51,816 --> 00:50:54,614
"We don't really like this kind
of mortgage anymore,

782
00:50:54,786 --> 00:50:56,947
and we thought
you ought to know."

783
00:50:57,122 --> 00:51:01,650
They didn't say anything, but you could
feel the laughter over the phone.

784
00:51:02,927 --> 00:51:05,793
Goldman Sachs bought
at least $22 billion

785
00:51:05,963 --> 00:51:08,557
of credit default swaps from AIG.

786
00:51:08,732 --> 00:51:13,635
It was so much that Goldman realized
that AIG itself might go bankrupt.

787
00:51:13,804 --> 00:51:16,773
So they spent $ 150 million
insuring themselves

788
00:51:16,940 --> 00:51:19,738
against AIG's potential collapse.

789
00:51:19,910 --> 00:51:23,505
Then in 2007,
Goldman went even further.

790
00:51:23,680 --> 00:51:26,376
They started selling CDOs
specifically designed

791
00:51:26,550 --> 00:51:29,075
so that the more money
their customers lost,

792
00:51:29,253 --> 00:51:31,655
the more money
Goldman Sachs made.

793
00:51:38,061 --> 00:51:43,089
Six hundred million dollars of
Timberwolf securities is what you sold.

794
00:51:43,267 --> 00:51:45,895
Before you sold them,

795
00:51:46,069 --> 00:51:49,402
this is what your sales team
were telling to each other:

796
00:51:50,207 --> 00:51:53,904
"Boy, that Timberwolf
was one shitty deal."

797
00:51:54,077 --> 00:51:59,174
This was an e-mail to me in late
June, after the transaction.

798
00:51:59,349 --> 00:52:02,648
No, no. You sold Timberwolf
after as well.

799
00:52:02,820 --> 00:52:05,050
We did trades after that.
Yeah. Okay.

800
00:52:05,322 --> 00:52:08,553
The next e-mail...
Take a look. July 1, '07.

801
00:52:08,725 --> 00:52:11,888
Tells the sales force,
"The top priority is Timberwolf."

802
00:52:12,162 --> 00:52:15,495
Your top priority to sell
is that shitty deal.

803
00:52:15,666 --> 00:52:17,930
If you have an adverse interest
to your client,

804
00:52:18,101 --> 00:52:19,932
do you have the duty
to disclose it?

805
00:52:20,103 --> 00:52:22,435
To tell that client
of your adverse interest?

806
00:52:22,606 --> 00:52:25,097
That's my question.
I'm trying to understand...

807
00:52:25,275 --> 00:52:27,766
I think you understand.
You don't wanna answer.

808
00:52:27,945 --> 00:52:30,243
Do you believe you have a duty

809
00:52:30,414 --> 00:52:34,180
to act in your clients'
best interest?

810
00:52:35,552 --> 00:52:40,420
I repeat, we have a duty
to serve our clients

811
00:52:40,590 --> 00:52:45,050
by showing prices on transactions
that they ask us to show prices for.

812
00:52:45,228 --> 00:52:47,992
What do you think
about selling securities

813
00:52:48,164 --> 00:52:51,292
which your own people think
are crap?

814
00:52:51,467 --> 00:52:53,230
Does that bother you?

815
00:52:53,402 --> 00:52:55,666
I think they would.

816
00:52:55,872 --> 00:52:58,636
- As a hypothetical?
- No, this is real.

817
00:52:58,808 --> 00:53:01,208
- Well, then I don't know...
- We heard it today.

818
00:53:01,377 --> 00:53:04,437
We heard it today. "This is a
shitty deal." "This is crap."

819
00:53:04,614 --> 00:53:06,639
I heard nothing today

820
00:53:06,816 --> 00:53:10,582
that makes me think
anything went wrong.

821
00:53:10,753 --> 00:53:14,814
Is there not a conflict when you
sell something to somebody

822
00:53:14,991 --> 00:53:20,395
and then are determined
to bet against that same security,

823
00:53:20,563 --> 00:53:24,158
and you don't disclose that
to the person you're selling it to?

824
00:53:24,333 --> 00:53:25,357
You see a problem?

825
00:53:25,535 --> 00:53:28,629
In the context of market making,
that is not a conflict.

826
00:53:28,804 --> 00:53:31,898
When you heard your
employees in e-mails said,

827
00:53:32,074 --> 00:53:35,635
"What a shitty deal,"
"What a piece of crap,"

828
00:53:35,811 --> 00:53:37,176
did you feel anything?

829
00:53:37,346 --> 00:53:39,507
That's very unfortunate
to have on e-mail.

830
00:53:39,682 --> 00:53:40,706
Are you embar...?

831
00:53:42,385 --> 00:53:44,182
And very unfortunate...
I don't... I don't...

832
00:53:44,353 --> 00:53:47,083
"On e-mail"? How
about feeling that way?

833
00:53:47,256 --> 00:53:50,657
It's very unfortunate for anyone
to have said that in any form.

834
00:53:50,826 --> 00:53:55,422
Are your competitors engaged
in similar activities?

835
00:53:55,598 --> 00:53:59,830
Yes, and to a greater extent
than us in most cases.

836
00:54:00,202 --> 00:54:03,660
Hedge fund manager
John Paulson made $ 12 billion

837
00:54:03,839 --> 00:54:05,864
betting against
the mortgage market.

838
00:54:06,042 --> 00:54:09,239
When Paulson ran out of
mortgage securities to bet against,

839
00:54:09,412 --> 00:54:13,872
he worked with Goldman Sachs
and Deutsche Bank to create more.

840
00:54:14,282 --> 00:54:15,874
Morgan Stanley was also selling

841
00:54:16,051 --> 00:54:19,782
mortgage securities it was betting
against, and it's now being sued by

842
00:54:19,955 --> 00:54:23,447
the Government Employees' Retirement
Fund of the Virgin Islands

843
00:54:23,625 --> 00:54:24,853
for fraud.

844
00:54:25,026 --> 00:54:27,460
The lawsuit alleges
that Morgan Stanley knew

845
00:54:27,629 --> 00:54:29,256
that the CDOs were junk.

846
00:54:29,431 --> 00:54:31,365
Although they were rated triple-A,

847
00:54:31,533 --> 00:54:34,161
Morgan Stanley
was betting they would fail.

848
00:54:34,336 --> 00:54:38,534
A year later, Morgan Stanley had made
hundreds of millions of dollars,

849
00:54:38,707 --> 00:54:42,643
while the investors
had lost almost all of their money.

850
00:54:58,660 --> 00:55:01,424
You would have thought
pension funds would have said:

851
00:55:01,596 --> 00:55:05,123
"Those are subprime.
Why am I buying them?"

852
00:55:05,834 --> 00:55:08,826
They had these guys at Moody's
and Standard & Poor's

853
00:55:09,004 --> 00:55:10,733
who said, "That's a triple-A."

854
00:55:10,905 --> 00:55:16,935
No securities got issued without the
seal of approval of the rating agencies.

855
00:55:17,112 --> 00:55:21,845
The three rating agencies,
Moody's, S&P and Fitch,

856
00:55:22,017 --> 00:55:25,680
made billions of dollars giving
high ratings to risky securities.

857
00:55:26,488 --> 00:55:30,322
Moody's, the largest rating agency,
quadrupled it's profits

858
00:55:30,492 --> 00:55:33,757
between 2000 and 2007.

859
00:55:34,162 --> 00:55:37,757
Moody's and S&P get compensated
based on putting out ratings reports.

860
00:55:37,932 --> 00:55:41,561
And the more structured securities
they gave a triple-A rating to,

861
00:55:41,736 --> 00:55:43,533
the higher their earnings were.

862
00:55:43,705 --> 00:55:45,502
Imagine going to
The Times saying:

863
00:55:45,674 --> 00:55:48,108
"Write a positive story,
I'll pay you $500,000.

864
00:55:48,276 --> 00:55:50,243
If you don't,
I'll give you nothing."

865
00:55:50,411 --> 00:55:52,242
Rating agencies could have
stopped the party and said:

866
00:55:52,413 --> 00:55:55,849
"Sorry. We're gonna tighten
our standards,"

867
00:55:56,016 --> 00:56:01,147
and immediately cut off
the funding to risky borrowers.

868
00:56:01,321 --> 00:56:03,721
Triple-A-rated instruments

869
00:56:04,458 --> 00:56:10,795
mushroomed from just a handful
to thousands and thousands.

870
00:56:11,331 --> 00:56:15,768
Hundreds of billions of dollars
were being rated, you know, and...

871
00:56:15,936 --> 00:56:17,801
Per year?
Per year. Oh, yeah.

872
00:56:17,971 --> 00:56:21,031
I've now testified before
both houses of Congress

873
00:56:21,208 --> 00:56:24,473
on the credit rating agency issue,

874
00:56:24,645 --> 00:56:29,105
and both times they trot out very
prominent First Amendment lawyers

875
00:56:29,283 --> 00:56:33,447
and argue that, "When we say
something is rated triple-A",

876
00:56:33,620 --> 00:56:37,249
that is merely our 'opinion.'
You shouldn't rely on it."

877
00:56:37,424 --> 00:56:39,585
S&P's ratings express our opinion.

878
00:56:39,760 --> 00:56:42,991
Our ratings are our opinions.
They're opinions.

879
00:56:43,230 --> 00:56:45,425
Opinions.
And they are just opinions.

880
00:56:45,599 --> 00:56:50,036
I think we are emphasizing the fact
that our ratings are opinions.

881
00:56:56,343 --> 00:56:59,141
They do not speak
to the market value of a security,

882
00:56:59,313 --> 00:57:03,951
the volatility of it's price,
or it's suitability as an investment.

883
00:57:22,436 --> 00:57:24,960
We have many
economists saying:

884
00:57:25,138 --> 00:57:27,402
"Oh. This is a bubble,
it's going to burst.

885
00:57:27,573 --> 00:57:29,973
This is going to be
an issue for the economy."

886
00:57:30,143 --> 00:57:33,010
Some say it could even 'cause
a recession at some point.

887
00:57:33,179 --> 00:57:37,115
What is the worst-case scenario
if, in fact, we were to see prices

888
00:57:37,283 --> 00:57:40,047
come down substantially
across the country?

889
00:57:40,219 --> 00:57:43,347
I don't buy your premise.
It's an unlikely possibility.

890
00:57:43,523 --> 00:57:47,892
We've never had a decline in house
prices on a nationwide basis.

891
00:57:48,060 --> 00:57:50,505
Ben Bernanke became
chairman of the Federal Reserve

892
00:57:50,530 --> 00:57:52,555
in February 2006,

893
00:57:52,732 --> 00:57:55,633
the top year for subprime lending.

894
00:57:56,068 --> 00:57:58,229
But despite numerous warnings,

895
00:57:58,404 --> 00:58:01,532
Bernanke and the
Federal Reserve Board did nothing.

896
00:58:06,112 --> 00:58:09,479
Robert Gnaizda met with Bernanke
and the Federal Reserve Board

897
00:58:09,649 --> 00:58:12,777
three times after
Bernanke became chairman.

898
00:58:12,952 --> 00:58:17,912
Only at the last meeting did he
suggest that there was a problem

899
00:58:18,090 --> 00:58:20,388
and that the government
ought to look into it.

900
00:58:20,560 --> 00:58:22,357
When? When was that? What year?

901
00:58:22,528 --> 00:58:25,656
It's 2009, March 11 th, in D.C.

902
00:58:25,832 --> 00:58:27,629
This year?
This year we met, yes.

903
00:58:27,800 --> 00:58:30,325
And so for the two previous years
you met him.

904
00:58:30,503 --> 00:58:33,131
Even in 2008?
Yes.

905
00:58:33,306 --> 00:58:37,140
One of the six Federal Reserve Board
governors serving under Bernanke

906
00:58:37,310 --> 00:58:38,743
was Frederic Mishkin,

907
00:58:38,911 --> 00:58:42,347
who was appointed
by President Bush in 2006.

908
00:58:42,515 --> 00:58:46,611
Did you participate
in the meetings Robert Gnaizda

909
00:58:46,786 --> 00:58:49,584
and Greenlining had
with the Federal Reserve Board?

910
00:58:49,755 --> 00:58:52,622
Yes, I did. I was on the
committee that was involved

911
00:58:52,792 --> 00:58:55,352
with the Consumer Community
Affairs Committee.

912
00:58:55,528 --> 00:58:59,361
He warned, in an extremely
explicit manner, about what was going on.

913
00:58:59,531 --> 00:59:02,830
He came to the Federal Reserve
Board with loan documentation

914
00:59:03,001 --> 00:59:05,936
of the kind of loans
that were frequently being made.

915
00:59:06,104 --> 00:59:08,902
And he was listened to politely,
and nothing was done.

916
00:59:09,074 --> 00:59:14,637
So again, I don't know the details
in terms of, um...

917
00:59:15,080 --> 00:59:17,776
In fact, I just don't... l...

918
00:59:17,949 --> 00:59:21,680
Whatever information he provided,
I'm not sure exactly.

919
00:59:22,053 --> 00:59:25,511
To be honest with you, I can't
remember this kind of discussion,

920
00:59:25,690 --> 00:59:30,525
but certainly there were issues
that were coming up.

921
00:59:30,695 --> 00:59:32,993
The question is,
how pervasive are they?

922
00:59:33,164 --> 00:59:34,495
Why didn't you try looking?

923
00:59:34,666 --> 00:59:36,293
I think that people did.

924
00:59:36,468 --> 00:59:38,026
We had people looking at...

925
00:59:38,203 --> 00:59:41,434
Excuse me. You can't be
serious. You would have found things.

926
00:59:41,606 --> 00:59:45,975
That's very easy to always say
that you can always find it.

927
00:59:46,144 --> 00:59:47,839
As early as 2004,

928
00:59:48,013 --> 00:59:52,313
the FBI was already warning about
an epidemic of mortgage fraud.

929
00:59:52,484 --> 00:59:54,748
They reported inflated appraisals,

930
00:59:54,920 --> 00:59:58,549
doctored loan documentation
and other fraudulent activity.

931
00:59:59,691 --> 01:00:03,923
In 2005, the IMF's chief economist,
Raghuram Rajan,

932
01:00:04,095 --> 01:00:07,724
warned that dangerous incentives
could lead to a crisis.

933
01:00:08,266 --> 01:00:11,827
Then came Nouriel Roubini's
warnings in 2006,

934
01:00:12,003 --> 01:00:14,494
Allan Sloan's articles
in Fortune magazine

935
01:00:14,673 --> 01:00:16,732
and The Washington Post
in 2007,

936
01:00:17,275 --> 01:00:19,709
and repeated warnings
from the IMF.

937
01:00:19,878 --> 01:00:22,073
I said,
and on behalf of the institution,

938
01:00:22,247 --> 01:00:25,648
the crisis in front of us
is a huge crisis.

939
01:00:25,817 --> 01:00:26,875
Who did you talk to?

940
01:00:27,052 --> 01:00:29,213
The government, Treasury,
Fed, everybody.

941
01:00:29,387 --> 01:00:35,222
In May of 2007, hedge fund manager
Bill Ackman circulated a presentation,

942
01:00:35,392 --> 01:00:37,019
"Who is Holding the Bag?"

943
01:00:37,194 --> 01:00:40,027
Which described
how the bubble would unravel.

944
01:00:40,564 --> 01:00:43,829
And in early 2008,
Charles Morris published his book

945
01:00:44,001 --> 01:00:46,299
about the impending crisis.

946
01:00:48,405 --> 01:00:50,635
You're not sure. What do you do?

947
01:00:50,808 --> 01:00:54,972
You might have some suspicions that
underwriting standards are weakened.

948
01:00:55,145 --> 01:00:58,603
But then the question is,
should you do anything about it?

949
01:01:00,050 --> 01:01:03,713
By 2008, home foreclosures
were skyrocketing

950
01:01:03,887 --> 01:01:07,050
and the securitization food chain
imploded.

951
01:01:07,224 --> 01:01:10,660
Lenders could no longer sell
their loans to the investment banks.

952
01:01:10,828 --> 01:01:15,060
And as the loans went bad,
dozens of lenders failed.

953
01:01:15,699 --> 01:01:20,432
Chuck Prince of Citibank
famously said

954
01:01:21,605 --> 01:01:24,506
that we have to dance
until the music stops.

955
01:01:24,675 --> 01:01:27,974
Actually, the music had stopped
already when he said that.

956
01:01:28,145 --> 01:01:30,613
The market for CDOs collapsed,

957
01:01:30,781 --> 01:01:34,114
leaving investment banks holding
hundreds of billions of dollars

958
01:01:34,284 --> 01:01:38,482
in loans, CDOs, and real estate
they couldn't sell.

959
01:01:38,655 --> 01:01:42,216
When the crisis started,
both the Bush administration

960
01:01:42,393 --> 01:01:46,762
and the Federal Reserve
were totally behind the curve.

961
01:01:46,930 --> 01:01:49,262
They did not understand
the extent of it.

962
01:01:49,500 --> 01:01:53,493
At what point do you
remember thinking for the first time:

963
01:01:53,670 --> 01:01:56,002
"This is dangerous, this is bad"?

964
01:01:56,173 --> 01:02:00,337
I remember very well one...
I think it was a G 7 meeting

965
01:02:00,511 --> 01:02:02,502
of February, 2008.

966
01:02:02,679 --> 01:02:06,580
And I remember discussing
the issue with Hank Paulson.

967
01:02:06,749 --> 01:02:09,809
And I clearly remember
telling Hank:

968
01:02:09,986 --> 01:02:12,978
"We are watching
this Tsunami coming,"

969
01:02:13,156 --> 01:02:16,887
and you're just proposing
that we ask

970
01:02:17,060 --> 01:02:19,654
"which swimming costume
we're going to put on."

971
01:02:19,829 --> 01:02:22,161
What was his response?
What was his feeling?

972
01:02:22,331 --> 01:02:23,730
"Things are under control."

973
01:02:23,900 --> 01:02:27,859
Yes, we are looking
at this situation carefully,

974
01:02:28,037 --> 01:02:31,473
"and, yeah, it's under control."

975
01:02:32,175 --> 01:02:36,703
We're gonna keep growing. Okay?
And, obviously, I'll say it:

976
01:02:36,879 --> 01:02:39,473
If you're growing,
you're not in recession, right?

977
01:02:39,649 --> 01:02:41,640
I mean, we all know that.

978
01:02:46,856 --> 01:02:48,881
One of the pillars of Wall Street...

979
01:02:49,058 --> 01:02:53,324
In March 2008, the investment
bank Bear Stearns ran out of cash

980
01:02:53,963 --> 01:02:57,694
and was acquired for $2 a share
by JPMorgan Chase.

981
01:02:57,867 --> 01:03:01,530
The deal was backed by $30 billion
in emergency guarantees

982
01:03:01,704 --> 01:03:03,171
from the Federal Reserve.

983
01:03:04,707 --> 01:03:07,642
That was when the administration
could have come in

984
01:03:07,810 --> 01:03:13,407
and put in place various measures
to reduce system risk.

985
01:03:13,583 --> 01:03:18,452
The information I'm receiving
is the end is not here,

986
01:03:18,621 --> 01:03:20,816
that there are other shoes to fall.

987
01:03:20,990 --> 01:03:23,515
Well, I've seen
those investment banks,

988
01:03:23,693 --> 01:03:27,288
working with the Fed
and the SEC,

989
01:03:27,463 --> 01:03:33,527
strengthen their liquidity,
strengthen their capital positions.

990
01:03:33,703 --> 01:03:37,764
I get reports all the time.
Our regulators are very vigilant.

991
01:03:38,441 --> 01:03:40,340
On September 7 th, 2008,

992
01:03:40,509 --> 01:03:43,103
Henry Paulson announced
the federal takeover

993
01:03:43,278 --> 01:03:47,840
of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, giant
lenders on the brink of collapse.

994
01:03:48,016 --> 01:03:52,248
Nothing about our actions today
reflects a changed view

995
01:03:52,420 --> 01:03:54,047
of the housing correction

996
01:03:54,222 --> 01:03:57,248
or the strength
of other U.S. Financial institutions.

997
01:03:57,492 --> 01:03:58,516
Two days later,

998
01:03:58,693 --> 01:04:02,356
Lehman Brothers announced
record losses of $3.2 billion,

999
01:04:02,531 --> 01:04:04,829
and it's stock collapsed.

1000
01:04:05,634 --> 01:04:10,071
The effects of Lehman and AIG
in September still came as a surprise.

1001
01:04:10,238 --> 01:04:13,674
I mean, this is even after July
and Fannie and Freddie.

1002
01:04:13,842 --> 01:04:18,711
So clearly there was stuff that,
as of September,

1003
01:04:18,880 --> 01:04:22,782
major stuff,
that nobody knew about.

1004
01:04:22,951 --> 01:04:25,146
I think that's... I think that's fair.

1005
01:04:25,320 --> 01:04:27,191
Bear Stearns
was rated triple-A

1006
01:04:27,204 --> 01:04:29,086
like a month before
it went bankrupt?

1007
01:04:29,257 --> 01:04:31,919
More likely A2.
A2?

1008
01:04:32,093 --> 01:04:33,185
Yeah.
Okay.

1009
01:04:33,361 --> 01:04:35,124
A2 is still not bankrupt.

1010
01:04:35,297 --> 01:04:38,789
No, that's a high investment grade.
Solid investment grade rating.

1011
01:04:38,967 --> 01:04:42,027
Lehman Brothers,
A2 within days of failing.

1012
01:04:42,204 --> 01:04:47,005
AIG, double-A
within days of being bailed out.

1013
01:04:47,876 --> 01:04:51,812
Fannie Mae and Freddie Macwere
triple-A when they were rescued.

1014
01:04:51,980 --> 01:04:55,916
Citigroup, Merrill, all of them
had investment-grade ratings.

1015
01:04:56,084 --> 01:04:58,644
How can that be?
Well, that's a good question.

1016
01:05:00,722 --> 01:05:01,984
That's a great question.

1017
01:05:02,157 --> 01:05:03,488
At no point did the administration

1018
01:05:03,658 --> 01:05:07,059
ever go to
all the major institutions and say:

1019
01:05:07,229 --> 01:05:10,130
"This is serious.
Tell us what your positions are.

1020
01:05:10,298 --> 01:05:14,165
You know, no bullshit.
Where are you?"

1021
01:05:14,635 --> 01:05:18,366
Well, first, that's what the regulators...
That's their job, right?

1022
01:05:18,539 --> 01:05:22,635
Their job is to understand the
exposure across these institutions.

1023
01:05:22,810 --> 01:05:25,711
And they have
a very refined understanding

1024
01:05:25,879 --> 01:05:30,282
that I think became more respon... More
refined as the crisis proceeded. So...

1025
01:05:30,451 --> 01:05:33,113
Forgive me, but
that's clearly not true.

1026
01:05:33,287 --> 01:05:35,152
What do you mean, that's not true?

1027
01:05:35,322 --> 01:05:36,755
In August of 2008,

1028
01:05:36,924 --> 01:05:42,419
were you aware of the credit ratings
held by Lehman Brothers,

1029
01:05:42,596 --> 01:05:44,291
Merrill Lynch, AIG,

1030
01:05:44,465 --> 01:05:46,933
and did you think
that they were accurate?

1031
01:05:47,101 --> 01:05:50,093
Well, certainly by that time,

1032
01:05:50,271 --> 01:05:53,172
it was clear earlier credit ratings
weren't accurate.

1033
01:05:53,340 --> 01:05:56,002
- They had been downgraded.
- No, they hadn't.

1034
01:05:56,176 --> 01:06:00,272
There was downgrading in terms
of the industry and concerns of the...

1035
01:06:00,447 --> 01:06:02,813
All those firms were rated
at least A2

1036
01:06:02,983 --> 01:06:05,747
until a couple of days
before they were rescued.

1037
01:06:05,919 --> 01:06:10,515
The answer is I don't know enough to
answer your question on this issue.

1038
01:06:10,691 --> 01:06:14,058
Governor Fred Mishkin is resigning,
effective August 31.

1039
01:06:14,228 --> 01:06:18,164
He plans to return to Columbia's
Graduate School of Business.

1040
01:06:18,332 --> 01:06:21,358
Why did you leave the
Federal Reserve in August of 2008

1041
01:06:21,535 --> 01:06:24,299
in the middle
of the worst financial crisis?

1042
01:06:24,471 --> 01:06:28,601
So that...
I had to revise a textbook.

1043
01:06:28,776 --> 01:06:32,542
His departure leaves the board
with three of it's seven seats vacant

1044
01:06:32,713 --> 01:06:34,874
just when the economy
needs it most.

1045
01:06:35,049 --> 01:06:36,971
I'm sure
your textbook is

1046
01:06:36,984 --> 01:06:38,917
important and widely read,
but in August 2008,

1047
01:06:39,086 --> 01:06:43,182
some more important things were going
on in the world, don't you think?

1048
01:06:43,724 --> 01:06:45,692
By Friday, September 12th,

1049
01:06:45,859 --> 01:06:47,986
Lehman Brothers had
run out of cash

1050
01:06:48,162 --> 01:06:51,858
and the entire investment-banking
industry was sinking fast.

1051
01:06:52,031 --> 01:06:55,694
The stability of the global
financial system was in jeopardy.

1052
01:06:56,903 --> 01:06:59,701
That weekend, Henry Paulson
and Timothy Geithner

1053
01:06:59,872 --> 01:07:02,306
president of
the New York Federal Reserve,

1054
01:07:02,475 --> 01:07:05,933
called an emergency meeting
with the CEOs of the major banks

1055
01:07:06,112 --> 01:07:07,636
in an effort to rescue Lehman.

1056
01:07:08,448 --> 01:07:09,972
But Lehman wasn't alone.

1057
01:07:10,383 --> 01:07:15,184
Merrill Lynch was also
on the brink of failure.

1058
01:07:15,355 --> 01:07:19,155
And that Sunday,
it was acquired by Bank of America.

1059
01:07:19,325 --> 01:07:24,388
The only bank interested in buying
Lehman was the British firm Barclays.

1060
01:07:24,564 --> 01:07:28,432
But British regulators demanded
a financial guarantee from the U.S.

1061
01:07:28,968 --> 01:07:30,993
Paulson refused.

1062
01:07:35,541 --> 01:07:40,808
We got in a cab and went
to the Federal Reserve Bank.

1063
01:07:42,548 --> 01:07:45,847
They wanted the bankruptcy case
commenced before midnight

1064
01:07:46,018 --> 01:07:48,009
of September 14.

1065
01:07:48,187 --> 01:07:54,456
We kept pressing
that this would be a terrible event,

1066
01:07:54,627 --> 01:07:57,221
and at some point
I used the word Armageddon,

1067
01:07:57,397 --> 01:08:02,027
and they consider the consequences
of what they were proposing.

1068
01:08:02,201 --> 01:08:04,726
The effect on the market
would be extraordinary.

1069
01:08:04,904 --> 01:08:06,701
You said this?
Yes.

1070
01:08:06,873 --> 01:08:11,970
They just said they had considered
all of the comments we had made,

1071
01:08:12,145 --> 01:08:17,583
and they were still of the belief
that in order to calm the markets

1072
01:08:17,750 --> 01:08:21,481
and move forward, it was necessary
for Lehman to go into bankruptcy.

1073
01:08:21,654 --> 01:08:23,094
"Calm the markets"?
Yes.

1074
01:08:23,422 --> 01:08:27,791
When were you first told that
Lehman, in fact, was going to go bankrupt?

1075
01:08:28,593 --> 01:08:31,687
After the fact.
After the fact?

1076
01:08:32,798 --> 01:08:36,063
Wow. Okay. Um...

1077
01:08:36,234 --> 01:08:41,262
And what was your reaction
when you learned of it?

1078
01:08:41,873 --> 01:08:43,650
"Holy cow."

1079
01:08:43,675 --> 01:08:47,008
Paulson and Bernanke had
not consulted with other governments

1080
01:08:47,179 --> 01:08:50,148
and didn't know the consequences
of foreign bankruptcy laws.

1081
01:08:50,315 --> 01:08:53,284
Lehman Brothers London
continue to empty their desks.

1082
01:08:53,452 --> 01:08:54,680
Under British law,

1083
01:08:54,853 --> 01:08:58,186
Lehman's London office
had to be closed immediately.

1084
01:08:58,356 --> 01:09:02,554
All transactions came to a halt, and
there are thousands of transactions.

1085
01:09:02,727 --> 01:09:06,094
The hedge funds who had had
assets with Lehman in London

1086
01:09:06,264 --> 01:09:09,062
discovered overnight,
to their complete horror,

1087
01:09:09,234 --> 01:09:11,327
they couldn't get
those assets back.

1088
01:09:11,503 --> 01:09:14,267
One of the points of the hub failed.

1089
01:09:14,439 --> 01:09:17,567
And that had huge knock-on effects
around the system.

1090
01:09:17,742 --> 01:09:19,733
The oldest money market fund
in the nation

1091
01:09:19,911 --> 01:09:24,041
wrote off three-quarters
of a billion dollars in bad debt

1092
01:09:24,216 --> 01:09:26,207
issued by now-bankrupt
Lehman Brothers.

1093
01:09:26,384 --> 01:09:29,979
Lehman's failure caused a
collapse in the commercial paper market,

1094
01:09:30,155 --> 01:09:33,454
which many companies depend on
to pay for expenses

1095
01:09:33,625 --> 01:09:34,956
such as payroll.

1096
01:09:35,126 --> 01:09:38,095
That means they have to lay off
employees, they can't buy parts.

1097
01:09:38,263 --> 01:09:40,060
It stops business in it's tracks.

1098
01:09:40,232 --> 01:09:43,099
People stood and said,
"Listen, what can we believe in?

1099
01:09:43,268 --> 01:09:45,236
There's nothing
we can trust anymore."

1100
01:09:45,403 --> 01:09:48,964
That same week,
AIG owed $ 13 billion

1101
01:09:49,140 --> 01:09:53,008
to holders of credit default swaps,
and it didn't have the money.

1102
01:09:53,178 --> 01:09:55,146
AIG was another hub.

1103
01:09:55,313 --> 01:09:59,408
If AIG had stopped, you know,
all planes may have to stop flying.

1104
01:09:59,583 --> 01:10:02,984
On September 17 th, AIG is
taken over by the government.

1105
01:10:03,654 --> 01:10:07,090
One day later, Paulson
and Bernanke ask Congress

1106
01:10:07,258 --> 01:10:09,692
for $700 billion
to bail out the banks.

1107
01:10:09,860 --> 01:10:11,191
We're coming together.

1108
01:10:11,362 --> 01:10:15,765
They warned that the alternative
would be a catastrophic collapse.

1109
01:10:15,933 --> 01:10:18,595
It was scary. You know,
the entire system froze up.

1110
01:10:18,769 --> 01:10:22,535
Every part of the financial system,
every part of the credit system.

1111
01:10:22,706 --> 01:10:24,435
Nobody could borrow money.

1112
01:10:24,608 --> 01:10:27,771
It was like a cardiac arrest
of the global financial system.

1113
01:10:27,945 --> 01:10:29,879
I'm playing the hand dealt me.

1114
01:10:30,047 --> 01:10:32,481
A lot of what I'm dealing with...

1115
01:10:32,650 --> 01:10:37,087
I'm dealing with the consequences
of things that were done years ago.

1116
01:10:37,254 --> 01:10:39,265
Secretary Paulson
spoke through the fall.

1117
01:10:39,290 --> 01:10:42,316
All the potential root causes of this,
and there are plenty,

1118
01:10:42,493 --> 01:10:44,552
he called them. I'm not sure...

1119
01:10:44,728 --> 01:10:46,127
You're not being serious about that.

1120
01:10:46,297 --> 01:10:48,993
I am being serious.
What would you have expected?

1121
01:10:49,166 --> 01:10:51,566
What were you looking for
that you didn't see?

1122
01:10:51,735 --> 01:10:54,533
He was the senior advocate

1123
01:10:54,705 --> 01:10:59,074
for prohibiting the regulation
of credit default swaps

1124
01:10:59,243 --> 01:11:02,838
and also lifting the leverage limits
on the investment banks.

1125
01:11:03,013 --> 01:11:04,037
So again, what...?

1126
01:11:04,214 --> 01:11:07,672
He mentioned those things? I never
heard him mention those things.

1127
01:11:07,851 --> 01:11:10,547
Could we turn this off for a second?

1128
01:11:15,359 --> 01:11:16,986
When AIG was bailed out,

1129
01:11:17,161 --> 01:11:19,129
the owners of
it's credit default swaps,

1130
01:11:19,296 --> 01:11:21,958
the most prominent of which
was Goldman Sachs,

1131
01:11:22,132 --> 01:11:25,693
were paid $61 billion
the next day.

1132
01:11:25,869 --> 01:11:27,996
Paulson, Bernanke
and Tim Geithner

1133
01:11:28,172 --> 01:11:31,368
forced AIG to pay 100 cents
on the dollar

1134
01:11:31,541 --> 01:11:34,305
rather than negotiate
lower prices.

1135
01:11:34,477 --> 01:11:40,643
Eventually, the AIG bailout
cost taxpayers over $ 150 billion.

1136
01:11:40,817 --> 01:11:44,218
A hundred and sixty billion dollars
went through AIG.

1137
01:11:44,387 --> 01:11:47,185
Fourteen billion went
to Goldman Sachs.

1138
01:11:47,357 --> 01:11:50,554
At the same time,
Paulson and Geithner forced AIG

1139
01:11:50,727 --> 01:11:54,629
to surrender it's right to sue Goldman
and the other banks for fraud.

1140
01:11:54,797 --> 01:11:57,334
Isn't there
a problem when the

1141
01:11:57,347 --> 01:11:59,894
person in charge of
dealing with this crisis

1142
01:12:00,069 --> 01:12:02,230
is the former CEO
of Goldman Sachs?

1143
01:12:02,405 --> 01:12:05,966
Someone who had a major role
in causing it.

1144
01:12:06,142 --> 01:12:08,872
It's fair to say
that the financial markets today

1145
01:12:09,045 --> 01:12:10,842
are incredibly complicated.

1146
01:12:11,014 --> 01:12:12,743
And supply
urgently needed money.

1147
01:12:12,915 --> 01:12:15,145
On October 4th, 2008,

1148
01:12:15,318 --> 01:12:19,345
President Bush signs
a 700-billion-dollar bailout bill.

1149
01:12:19,522 --> 01:12:21,854
But world stock markets
continue to fall

1150
01:12:22,025 --> 01:12:24,892
amid fears that a global recession
is now underway.

1151
01:12:30,199 --> 01:12:33,498
The bailout legislation does nothing
to stem the tide of layoffs

1152
01:12:33,670 --> 01:12:35,467
and foreclosures.

1153
01:12:35,638 --> 01:12:40,735
Unemployment in the United States
and Europe rises to 10 percent.

1154
01:12:40,910 --> 01:12:44,243
The recession accelerates
and spreads globally.

1155
01:12:48,051 --> 01:12:52,317
I began to get really scared
because I hadn't foreseen

1156
01:12:52,488 --> 01:12:57,050
the whole world going down
at the same rate at the same time.

1157
01:12:57,760 --> 01:12:59,591
By December of 2008,

1158
01:12:59,762 --> 01:13:03,254
General Motors and Chrysler
are facing bankruptcy.

1159
01:13:03,599 --> 01:13:06,328
And as U.S. Consumers cut back
on spending,

1160
01:13:06,501 --> 01:13:10,028
Chinese manufacturers
see sales plummet.

1161
01:13:11,106 --> 01:13:15,566
Over 10 million migrant workers
in China lose their jobs.

1162
01:13:16,044 --> 01:13:20,606
At the end of the day, the
poorest, as always, pay the most.

1163
01:13:26,088 --> 01:13:28,079
Here, you can earn a lot of money.

1164
01:13:28,256 --> 01:13:34,217
Like 70, 80 U.S. Dollars per month.

1165
01:13:35,430 --> 01:13:40,299
As a farmer in the countryside,
you cannot earn as much money.

1166
01:13:40,469 --> 01:13:44,530
The workers, they just wire
their salary to their hometown

1167
01:13:44,706 --> 01:13:47,436
to give to their families.

1168
01:13:47,843 --> 01:13:50,710
The crisis started in America.

1169
01:13:50,879 --> 01:13:54,610
We all know it will be coming
to China.

1170
01:13:59,054 --> 01:14:02,114
Some of the factories try
to cut off some workers.

1171
01:14:03,625 --> 01:14:06,890
And some people will get poor
because they'll lose their jobs.

1172
01:14:08,263 --> 01:14:09,696
Life gets harder.

1173
01:14:18,240 --> 01:14:20,800
We were growing
at about 20 percent.

1174
01:14:21,576 --> 01:14:23,976
It was a super year.

1175
01:14:24,146 --> 01:14:28,048
Then we suddenly went
to minus-nine this quarter.

1176
01:14:28,216 --> 01:14:32,949
Exports collapsed,
and we're talking like 30 percent.

1177
01:14:33,755 --> 01:14:37,384
So we just took a hit, you know.
Fell off a cliff. Boomp.

1178
01:14:37,559 --> 01:14:41,654
Even as the crisis unfolded, we didn't
know how wide it was going to spread

1179
01:14:41,829 --> 01:14:43,694
or how severe it was going to be.

1180
01:14:43,864 --> 01:14:46,458
We were still hoping
that there would be some way

1181
01:14:46,634 --> 01:14:51,628
for us to have a shelter
and be less battered by the storm.

1182
01:14:51,806 --> 01:14:53,000
But it's not possible.

1183
01:14:53,474 --> 01:14:55,203
It's a very globalized world.

1184
01:14:55,376 --> 01:14:58,174
The economies
are all linked together.

1185
01:15:29,777 --> 01:15:32,211
Every time a home
goes into foreclosure,

1186
01:15:32,379 --> 01:15:34,711
it affects everyone
who lives around that house.

1187
01:15:34,882 --> 01:15:38,045
When that house goes on the market,
it'll be sold at a lower price.

1188
01:15:38,219 --> 01:15:41,552
Maybe before it goes on the market,
it won't be well-maintained.

1189
01:15:41,722 --> 01:15:45,055
We estimate another 9 million
homeowners will lose their homes.

1190
01:15:51,665 --> 01:15:56,693
We went out on a weekend
to see what houses were for sale.

1191
01:15:56,871 --> 01:15:58,429
We saw one we liked.

1192
01:15:58,606 --> 01:16:01,837
The payment
was going to be $3200.

1193
01:16:13,420 --> 01:16:16,081
Everything was beautiful,
the house was very pretty.

1194
01:16:16,256 --> 01:16:18,315
The payment low.
Everything was...

1195
01:16:18,491 --> 01:16:20,186
We won the lottery.

1196
01:16:20,360 --> 01:16:23,261
But the reality was when
the first payment arrived.

1197
01:16:28,034 --> 01:16:32,733
I felt very bad
for my husband

1198
01:16:33,840 --> 01:16:40,143
because he works too much.
And we have three children.

1199
01:16:49,656 --> 01:16:53,490
The majority I've seen are
people hurt by the economy.

1200
01:16:53,660 --> 01:16:56,652
They were living day to day,
paycheck to paycheck,

1201
01:16:56,829 --> 01:16:58,057
and that ran out.

1202
01:16:58,231 --> 01:17:01,564
Unemployment won't pay a mortgage.
It won't pay a car bill.

1203
01:17:02,168 --> 01:17:03,897
I was a log truck driver.

1204
01:17:04,070 --> 01:17:08,905
They shut down the logging systems,
shut down the sawmills.

1205
01:17:09,075 --> 01:17:11,543
So I moved down here
on a construction job.

1206
01:17:11,711 --> 01:17:14,578
And the construction jobs
got shut down too, so...

1207
01:17:14,747 --> 01:17:17,272
Things are so tough.
There's a lot of people out there.

1208
01:17:17,450 --> 01:17:19,850
Soon you're gonna be seeing
more camps like this

1209
01:17:20,019 --> 01:17:22,180
because there's just no jobs
right now.

1210
01:17:28,494 --> 01:17:33,090
When the company did well,
we did well.

1211
01:17:33,266 --> 01:17:37,066
When the company did not do well,
sir, we did not do well.

1212
01:17:37,470 --> 01:17:39,495
The men who
destroyed their own companies

1213
01:17:39,672 --> 01:17:41,435
and plunged the world
into crisis

1214
01:17:41,607 --> 01:17:44,940
walked away from the wreckage
with their fortunes intact.

1215
01:17:45,111 --> 01:17:48,705
The top five executives at Lehman
Brothers made over a billion dollars

1216
01:17:48,880 --> 01:17:51,610
between 2000 and 2007.

1217
01:17:51,783 --> 01:17:55,583
And when the firm went bankrupt,
they got to keep all the money.

1218
01:17:55,754 --> 01:17:57,346
The system worked.

1219
01:17:57,522 --> 01:18:00,457
It doesn't make sense to make
a failing loan because we lose.

1220
01:18:00,625 --> 01:18:04,527
The borrower loses, the
community loses and we lose.

1221
01:18:04,696 --> 01:18:07,028
Countrywide's CEO,
Angelo Mozilo,

1222
01:18:07,199 --> 01:18:11,568
made $470 million
between 2003 and 2008.

1223
01:18:11,937 --> 01:18:15,566
One hundred forty million came from
dumping his Countrywide stock

1224
01:18:15,741 --> 01:18:18,471
in the 12 months
before the company collapsed.

1225
01:18:18,643 --> 01:18:21,305
I hold the board accountable
when a business fails.

1226
01:18:21,480 --> 01:18:24,176
They're responsible
for hiring and firing the CEO

1227
01:18:24,349 --> 01:18:26,510
and overseeing
big strategic decisions.

1228
01:18:26,685 --> 01:18:29,677
The problem with boards in America
is the way boards are elected.

1229
01:18:29,855 --> 01:18:33,382
You know, the boards are pretty much,
in many cases, picked by the CEO.

1230
01:18:33,558 --> 01:18:36,049
The board of directors
and compensation committees

1231
01:18:36,228 --> 01:18:41,325
are the two bodies best situated
to determine pay for executives.

1232
01:18:41,500 --> 01:18:44,111
How do you think they've
done over the past 10 years?

1233
01:18:44,136 --> 01:18:49,506
Well, I think that if you look at those...
I would give about a B, because...

1234
01:18:49,674 --> 01:18:50,698
A B?
A B, yes.

1235
01:18:50,876 --> 01:18:52,605
Not an F?
Not an F, not an F.

1236
01:18:52,911 --> 01:18:55,607
Stan O'neal, the
CEO of Merrill Lynch,

1237
01:18:55,781 --> 01:19:00,218
received $90 million
in 2006 and 2007 alone.

1238
01:19:00,385 --> 01:19:02,546
After driving his firm
into the ground,

1239
01:19:02,721 --> 01:19:05,315
the board of directors
allowed him to resign,

1240
01:19:05,490 --> 01:19:09,449
and he collected $ 161 million
in severance.

1241
01:19:09,795 --> 01:19:13,822
Instead of being fired,
Stan O'neal is allowed to resign

1242
01:19:13,999 --> 01:19:17,196
and takes away $ 151 million.

1243
01:19:17,369 --> 01:19:19,837
That's a decision that
that board of directors made.

1244
01:19:20,005 --> 01:19:21,836
What grade
do you give that decision?

1245
01:19:22,007 --> 01:19:24,873
That's a tougher one. I don't
know if I'd give it a B as well.

1246
01:19:25,409 --> 01:19:31,473
O'neal's successor, John Thain,
was paid $87 million in 2007.

1247
01:19:31,649 --> 01:19:33,241
And in December of 2008,

1248
01:19:33,417 --> 01:19:37,114
two months after Merrill
was bailed out by U.S. Taxpayers,

1249
01:19:37,288 --> 01:19:41,520
Thain and Merrill's board
handed out billions in bonuses.

1250
01:19:42,259 --> 01:19:46,252
In March of 2008,
AIG's Financial Products division

1251
01:19:46,430 --> 01:19:48,728
lost $ 11 billion.

1252
01:19:48,899 --> 01:19:53,199
Instead of being fired,
Joseph Cassano, head of AIGFP,

1253
01:19:53,571 --> 01:19:57,473
was kept on as a consultant
for a million dollars a month.

1254
01:19:57,641 --> 01:20:03,136
You wanna make sure key players
and key employees within AIGFP,

1255
01:20:03,314 --> 01:20:05,475
we retain
that intellectual knowledge.

1256
01:20:05,649 --> 01:20:07,617
I attended
a very interesting dinner

1257
01:20:07,785 --> 01:20:11,448
organized by Hank Paulson
a little more than one year ago

1258
01:20:11,622 --> 01:20:14,250
with some officials
and a couple of CEOs

1259
01:20:14,425 --> 01:20:16,689
from the biggest banks
in the U.S.

1260
01:20:16,861 --> 01:20:21,161
And surprisingly enough,
all these gentlemen were arguing:

1261
01:20:21,332 --> 01:20:25,632
"We were too greedy, so we have
part of the responsibility." Fine.

1262
01:20:25,803 --> 01:20:27,430
Then they were turning
to the treasurer,

1263
01:20:27,605 --> 01:20:29,300
Secretary of the Treasury,
and saying:

1264
01:20:29,473 --> 01:20:32,636
"You should regulate more. We're
too greedy, we can't avoid it.

1265
01:20:32,810 --> 01:20:35,779
The only way to avoid this
is to have more regulation."

1266
01:20:35,946 --> 01:20:38,847
I have spoken to
many bankers about this question,

1267
01:20:39,016 --> 01:20:40,950
including very senior ones.

1268
01:20:41,118 --> 01:20:45,919
And this is the first time
that I've ever heard anybody say

1269
01:20:46,090 --> 01:20:49,116
they wanted their compensation
to be regulated in any way.

1270
01:20:49,293 --> 01:20:52,490
Yeah, because it was at the
moment where they were afraid.

1271
01:20:52,663 --> 01:20:56,962
And after, when solution
to the crisis began to appear,

1272
01:20:57,133 --> 01:20:59,397
then probably
they changed their mind.

1273
01:21:01,804 --> 01:21:05,638
In the U.S., the banks
are now bigger, more powerful

1274
01:21:05,808 --> 01:21:08,868
and more concentrated
than ever before.

1275
01:21:09,045 --> 01:21:10,910
There are fewer competitors.

1276
01:21:11,080 --> 01:21:15,039
A lot of smaller banks have been
taken over by big ones.

1277
01:21:15,218 --> 01:21:17,652
J.P. Morgan is even bigger
than it was before.

1278
01:21:17,820 --> 01:21:21,779
J.P. Morgan took over first
Bear Stearns and then WaMu.

1279
01:21:21,958 --> 01:21:25,792
Bank of America took over
Countrywide and Merrill Lynch.

1280
01:21:25,962 --> 01:21:28,453
Wells Fargo took over Wachovia.

1281
01:21:28,631 --> 01:21:30,929
After the crisis,
the financial industry,

1282
01:21:31,100 --> 01:21:33,898
including the
Financial Services Roundtable,

1283
01:21:34,070 --> 01:21:36,595
worked harder than ever
to fight reform.

1284
01:21:36,773 --> 01:21:39,435
The financial sector
employs 3000 lobbyists,

1285
01:21:39,976 --> 01:21:43,412
more than five
for each member of Congress.

1286
01:21:43,913 --> 01:21:46,057
You think the
financial services industry

1287
01:21:46,082 --> 01:21:48,744
has excessive political influence
in the United States?

1288
01:21:48,918 --> 01:21:53,355
No. I think that every
person in the country

1289
01:21:53,523 --> 01:21:55,320
is represented
here in Washington.

1290
01:21:55,491 --> 01:21:59,222
And you think that
all segments of American society

1291
01:21:59,395 --> 01:22:02,728
have equal and fair access
to the system?

1292
01:22:02,899 --> 01:22:07,768
That you can walk into any hearing
room that you would like. Yes, I do.

1293
01:22:08,037 --> 01:22:11,234
One can walk into any
hearing room. One cannot necessarily

1294
01:22:11,407 --> 01:22:14,240
write the lobbying checks
that your industry writes

1295
01:22:14,410 --> 01:22:18,314
or engage in the level of political
contributions your industry engages in.

1296
01:22:18,514 --> 01:22:21,381
Between 1998 and 2008,

1297
01:22:21,551 --> 01:22:24,486
the financial industry
spent over $5 billion

1298
01:22:24,654 --> 01:22:27,145
on lobbying
and campaign contributions.

1299
01:22:27,323 --> 01:22:30,190
And since the crisis,
they're spending even more money.

1300
01:22:31,927 --> 01:22:34,395
The financial industry
also exerts it's influence

1301
01:22:34,563 --> 01:22:38,499
in a more subtle way, one that
most Americans don't know about.

1302
01:22:40,102 --> 01:22:43,697
It has corrupted the study
of economics itself.

1303
01:22:44,172 --> 01:22:50,202
Deregulation had tremendous
financial and intellectual support

1304
01:22:50,379 --> 01:22:54,816
because people argued it
for their own benefit.

1305
01:22:54,983 --> 01:22:59,647
The economics profession was
the main source of that illusion.

1306
01:22:59,988 --> 01:23:03,048
Since the 1980s,
academic economists

1307
01:23:03,225 --> 01:23:05,659
have been major advocates
of deregulation

1308
01:23:05,827 --> 01:23:09,228
and played powerful roles
in shaping U.S. Government policy.

1309
01:23:09,798 --> 01:23:13,564
Very few of these economic experts
warned about the crisis.

1310
01:23:13,735 --> 01:23:18,263
And even after the crisis,
many of them opposed reform.

1311
01:23:18,540 --> 01:23:22,408
The guys who taught these things
tended to get paid a lot of money

1312
01:23:22,577 --> 01:23:24,670
being consultants.

1313
01:23:24,846 --> 01:23:29,442
Business school professors
don't live on a faculty salary.

1314
01:23:30,519 --> 01:23:33,215
They do very, very well.

1315
01:23:33,655 --> 01:23:36,647
Over the last decade,
the financial services industries

1316
01:23:36,825 --> 01:23:42,821
made about $5 billion worth of
political contributions in the U.S.

1317
01:23:43,899 --> 01:23:46,197
That's kind of a lot of money.

1318
01:23:46,702 --> 01:23:49,364
That doesn't bother you?
No.

1319
01:23:49,538 --> 01:23:52,063
Martin Feldstein
is a Professor at Harvard

1320
01:23:52,240 --> 01:23:54,640
and one of the world's
most prominent economists.

1321
01:23:55,010 --> 01:23:57,808
As President Reagan's
chief economic advisor,

1322
01:23:57,979 --> 01:24:00,413
he was a major architect
of deregulation.

1323
01:24:00,582 --> 01:24:03,608
And from 1988 until 2009,

1324
01:24:03,919 --> 01:24:07,012
he was on the board of directors
of both AIG

1325
01:24:07,188 --> 01:24:09,156
and AIG Financial Products,

1326
01:24:09,323 --> 01:24:11,553
which paid him millions of dollars.

1327
01:24:11,826 --> 01:24:14,693
You have any regrets
about having been on AIG's board?

1328
01:24:14,862 --> 01:24:18,525
I have no comments. No, I have no
regrets about being on AIG's board.

1329
01:24:18,699 --> 01:24:22,135
None?
That I can say. Absolutely none.

1330
01:24:22,303 --> 01:24:23,736
Okay.

1331
01:24:26,173 --> 01:24:30,872
You have any regrets
about AIG's decisions?

1332
01:24:31,045 --> 01:24:33,809
I cannot say anything more
about AIG.

1333
01:24:33,981 --> 01:24:38,042
I've taught at Northwestern in
Chicago, Harvard and Columbia.

1334
01:24:38,219 --> 01:24:41,154
Glenn Hubbard is the
Dean of Columbia Business School

1335
01:24:41,322 --> 01:24:44,018
and was chairman
of the Council of Economic Advisers

1336
01:24:44,191 --> 01:24:46,182
under George W. Bush.

1337
01:24:46,360 --> 01:24:48,637
Do you think the
financial services industry

1338
01:24:48,662 --> 01:24:52,063
has too much political power
in the United States?

1339
01:24:52,533 --> 01:24:56,663
I don't think so. No. You certainly
wouldn't get that impression

1340
01:24:56,837 --> 01:25:00,637
by the drubbing that they
regularly get in Washington.

1341
01:25:00,808 --> 01:25:03,641
Many prominent academics
quietly make fortunes

1342
01:25:03,811 --> 01:25:08,612
helping the financial industry shape
public debate and government policy.

1343
01:25:08,783 --> 01:25:12,048
The Analysis Group,
Charles River Associates,

1344
01:25:12,219 --> 01:25:13,550
Compass Lexecon

1345
01:25:13,721 --> 01:25:15,985
and the Law and Economics
Consulting Group

1346
01:25:16,157 --> 01:25:18,352
manage a multibillion-dollar
industry

1347
01:25:18,526 --> 01:25:21,825
that provides academic experts
for hire.

1348
01:25:21,996 --> 01:25:23,987
Two bankers
who used these services

1349
01:25:24,165 --> 01:25:27,191
were Ralph Cioffi
and Matthew Tannin,

1350
01:25:27,368 --> 01:25:31,327
Bear Stearns hedge fund managers
prosecuted for securities fraud.

1351
01:25:31,505 --> 01:25:34,633
After hiring the Analysis Group,
both were acquitted.

1352
01:25:35,009 --> 01:25:40,241
Glenn Hubbard was paid $ 100,000
to testify in their defense.

1353
01:25:40,914 --> 01:25:43,872
Do you
think the economics

1354
01:25:43,885 --> 01:25:46,853
discipline has a
conflict-of-interest problem?

1355
01:25:47,787 --> 01:25:49,379
I'm not sure
I know what you mean.

1356
01:25:49,556 --> 01:25:53,822
Do you think a significant fraction of
the economics discipline, economists,

1357
01:25:53,993 --> 01:25:59,192
have financial conflicts of interest that
might call into question or color...?

1358
01:25:59,365 --> 01:26:01,333
I see what you're saying.
I doubt it.

1359
01:26:01,501 --> 01:26:06,666
Most academic economists
aren't wealthy business people.

1360
01:26:06,840 --> 01:26:11,038
Hubbard makes $250,000 a year
as a board member of MetLife

1361
01:26:11,211 --> 01:26:13,611
and was formerly
on the board of Capmark,

1362
01:26:13,780 --> 01:26:16,806
a major commercial
mortgage lender during the bubble,

1363
01:26:16,983 --> 01:26:19,042
which went bankrupt in 2009.

1364
01:26:19,219 --> 01:26:21,585
He has also advised
Nomura Securities,

1365
01:26:21,754 --> 01:26:26,157
KKR Financial Corporation
and many other financial firms.

1366
01:26:27,460 --> 01:26:30,588
Laura Tyson, who declined
to be interviewed for this film,

1367
01:26:30,763 --> 01:26:34,529
is a Professor at the
University of California, Berkeley.

1368
01:26:34,701 --> 01:26:37,932
She was the chair of
the Council of Economic Advisers,

1369
01:26:38,104 --> 01:26:41,562
then director of the National
Economic Council under Clinton.

1370
01:26:41,741 --> 01:26:45,404
After leaving government, she joined
the board of Morgan Stanley,

1371
01:26:45,578 --> 01:26:49,105
which pays her $350,000 a year.

1372
01:26:49,282 --> 01:26:51,773
Ruth Simmons,
president of Brown University,

1373
01:26:51,951 --> 01:26:57,014
makes over $300,000 a year
on the board of Goldman Sachs.

1374
01:26:57,257 --> 01:27:00,283
Larry Summers, who, as Treasury
secretary, played a role

1375
01:27:00,460 --> 01:27:05,796
in the deregulation of derivatives,
became president of Harvard in 2001.

1376
01:27:06,132 --> 01:27:09,465
While at Harvard, he made millions
consulting to hedge funds

1377
01:27:09,636 --> 01:27:14,004
and millions more in speaking fees,
much of it from investment banks.

1378
01:27:16,742 --> 01:27:20,143
According to his federal disclosure
report, Summers' net worth

1379
01:27:20,312 --> 01:27:25,340
is between $ 16.5 million
and $39.5 million.

1380
01:27:26,118 --> 01:27:28,916
Frederic Mishkin, who returned
to Columbia Business School

1381
01:27:29,087 --> 01:27:33,217
after leaving the Federal Reserve,
reported on his disclosure report

1382
01:27:33,392 --> 01:27:37,761
that his net worth was between
$6 million and $ 17 million.

1383
01:27:38,230 --> 01:27:42,667
In 2006, you coauthored a
study of Iceland's financial system.

1384
01:27:42,868 --> 01:27:44,665
"Iceland is an advanced country"

1385
01:27:44,836 --> 01:27:48,033
with excellent institutions,
low corruption, rule of law.

1386
01:27:48,206 --> 01:27:51,198
The economy has adjusted
to financial liberalization

1387
01:27:51,376 --> 01:27:55,608
"while prudential regulation and
supervision is generally quite strong."

1388
01:27:55,781 --> 01:27:58,511
And that was the mistake,
that it turns out

1389
01:27:58,684 --> 01:28:02,142
prudential regulation and supervision
was not strong in Iceland

1390
01:28:02,321 --> 01:28:05,188
during this period...
What led you to think it was?

1391
01:28:05,357 --> 01:28:07,621
You're going with
the information you had

1392
01:28:07,793 --> 01:28:13,322
and generally, the view was that
Iceland had very good institutions.

1393
01:28:13,498 --> 01:28:15,966
It was an advanced country...
Who told you that?

1394
01:28:16,134 --> 01:28:18,568
What research did you do?
You talk to people.

1395
01:28:18,737 --> 01:28:23,299
You have faith in the central bank, which
actually did fall down on the job.

1396
01:28:23,475 --> 01:28:25,943
That clearly it... This...

1397
01:28:26,111 --> 01:28:29,672
Why have faith in a central bank?
Well, that faith... You try...

1398
01:28:29,848 --> 01:28:32,009
Because you go with
the information you have.

1399
01:28:32,184 --> 01:28:34,778
How much were you paid to write it?
I was paid...

1400
01:28:34,953 --> 01:28:37,353
I think the number...
It's public information.

1401
01:28:44,930 --> 01:28:48,023
On your CV, the title
of this report has been changed

1402
01:28:48,199 --> 01:28:52,329
from "Financial Stability in Iceland"
to "Financial Instability in Iceland."

1403
01:28:52,503 --> 01:28:57,065
Well, I don't know. Whatever it is...
If there's a typo, there's a typo.

1404
01:28:57,241 --> 01:28:59,106
What should be publicly available

1405
01:28:59,276 --> 01:29:01,710
is whenever anybody
does research on a topic

1406
01:29:01,879 --> 01:29:06,578
that they disclose if they have any
financial conflict with that research.

1407
01:29:06,751 --> 01:29:10,744
But if I recall, there
is no policy to that effect.

1408
01:29:11,288 --> 01:29:16,749
I can't imagine anybody not doing that in
terms of putting it in a paper. You...

1409
01:29:16,927 --> 01:29:20,522
There would be significant professional
sanction for failure to do that.

1410
01:29:20,698 --> 01:29:25,328
I didn't see any place in the
study where you indicated you'd been paid

1411
01:29:25,503 --> 01:29:28,802
by the Icelandic Chamber
of Commerce to produce it.

1412
01:29:28,973 --> 01:29:31,771
No, I don't... You know.
Okay.

1413
01:29:32,143 --> 01:29:35,135
Richard Portes, the
most famous economist in Britain

1414
01:29:35,312 --> 01:29:37,439
and a Professor at
London Business School,

1415
01:29:37,615 --> 01:29:41,676
was also commissioned by the
Icelandic Chamber of Commerce

1416
01:29:41,852 --> 01:29:45,879
to write a report which praised
the Icelandic financial sector.

1417
01:29:46,457 --> 01:29:48,322
The banks themselves
are highly liquid.

1418
01:29:48,492 --> 01:29:51,290
They've made money
on the fall of the Icelandic krona.

1419
01:29:51,462 --> 01:29:52,861
These are strong banks.

1420
01:29:53,030 --> 01:29:56,295
Their market funding is assured
for the coming year.

1421
01:29:56,467 --> 01:29:58,435
- These are well-run banks.
- Thank you.

1422
01:29:58,602 --> 01:30:01,935
Like Mishkin, Portes' report
didn't disclose his payment

1423
01:30:02,106 --> 01:30:04,597
from the Icelandic
Chamber of Commerce.

1424
01:30:04,775 --> 01:30:07,243
Does Harvard
require disclosures

1425
01:30:07,256 --> 01:30:09,735
of financial conflict
of interest?

1426
01:30:10,715 --> 01:30:12,148
Not to my knowledge.

1427
01:30:12,316 --> 01:30:15,342
Do you require people
to report the compensation

1428
01:30:15,519 --> 01:30:18,044
received from outside activities?
No.

1429
01:30:18,222 --> 01:30:19,917
Don't you think that's a problem?

1430
01:30:20,091 --> 01:30:21,353
I don't see why.

1431
01:30:21,525 --> 01:30:24,186
Martin Feldstein
being on the board of AIG,

1432
01:30:24,360 --> 01:30:26,260
Laura Tyson at Morgan Stanley,

1433
01:30:26,429 --> 01:30:31,264
Larry Summers making $ 10 million
consulting to financial services firms.

1434
01:30:31,434 --> 01:30:32,492
Irrelevant?

1435
01:30:32,669 --> 01:30:33,966
Hm. Yeah.

1436
01:30:34,137 --> 01:30:35,627
Yeah. Basically irrelevant.

1437
01:30:36,439 --> 01:30:41,274
You've written many
articles about a wide array of subjects.

1438
01:30:41,444 --> 01:30:44,208
You never saw fit
to investigate the risks

1439
01:30:44,380 --> 01:30:47,713
of unregulated
credit default swaps?

1440
01:30:47,984 --> 01:30:49,611
I never did.

1441
01:30:49,786 --> 01:30:53,552
Same question with regard
to executive compensation?

1442
01:30:53,723 --> 01:30:55,714
The regulation
of corporate governance?

1443
01:30:55,892 --> 01:30:58,224
The effect of political contributions?

1444
01:30:58,394 --> 01:31:02,353
I don't know that I would have
anything to add to those discussions.

1445
01:31:02,532 --> 01:31:04,591
I'm looking at your resume now.

1446
01:31:04,768 --> 01:31:09,569
It looks to me as if the majority
of your outside activities

1447
01:31:09,739 --> 01:31:12,572
are consulting
and directorship arrangements

1448
01:31:12,742 --> 01:31:14,835
with the financial services
industry.

1449
01:31:15,011 --> 01:31:17,172
Would you not agree
with that characterization?

1450
01:31:17,347 --> 01:31:20,612
To my knowledge, I don't think my
consulting clients are on my CV.

1451
01:31:20,784 --> 01:31:23,582
So I wouldn't know.
Who are your consulting clients?

1452
01:31:23,753 --> 01:31:25,744
I don't believe I have to
discuss that with you.

1453
01:31:25,922 --> 01:31:27,355
Okay.

1454
01:31:27,957 --> 01:31:31,893
In fact, you have a few more
minutes and the interview's over.

1455
01:31:32,061 --> 01:31:34,655
Do you consult for
any financial services firms?

1456
01:31:34,831 --> 01:31:37,391
The answer is I do.
And?

1457
01:31:37,567 --> 01:31:40,730
And... But I do not wanna go
into details about that.

1458
01:31:40,904 --> 01:31:43,702
Do they include
other financial services firms?

1459
01:31:43,873 --> 01:31:45,033
Possibly.

1460
01:31:45,208 --> 01:31:46,869
You don't remember?

1461
01:31:47,043 --> 01:31:50,274
This isn't a deposition, sir. I was
polite enough to give you time.

1462
01:31:50,446 --> 01:31:54,143
Foolishly, I now see. But you
have three more minutes.

1463
01:31:54,317 --> 01:31:56,148
Give it your best shot.

1464
01:31:56,319 --> 01:31:58,946
In 2004, at the
height of the bubble,

1465
01:31:59,121 --> 01:32:02,955
Glenn Hubbard coauthored a widely
read paper with William C. Dudley,

1466
01:32:03,125 --> 01:32:05,923
the chief economist
of Goldman Sachs.

1467
01:32:06,094 --> 01:32:08,654
In the paper,
Hubbard praised credit derivatives

1468
01:32:08,831 --> 01:32:10,628
and the securitization chain,

1469
01:32:10,799 --> 01:32:13,393
stating they had improved
allocation of capital

1470
01:32:13,569 --> 01:32:16,037
and were enhancing
financial stability.

1471
01:32:16,205 --> 01:32:18,730
He cited reduced volatility
in the economy

1472
01:32:18,907 --> 01:32:23,537
and stated that recessions had
become less frequent and milder.

1473
01:32:23,712 --> 01:32:26,738
Credit derivatives were
protecting banks against losses

1474
01:32:26,915 --> 01:32:29,383
and helping to distribute risk.

1475
01:32:31,053 --> 01:32:34,022
A medical researcher
writes an article, saying:

1476
01:32:34,189 --> 01:32:38,751
"To treat this disease,
you should prescribe this drug."

1477
01:32:39,027 --> 01:32:42,087
Turns out doctor makes 80 percent
of personal income

1478
01:32:42,264 --> 01:32:45,427
from manufacture of this drug.
Does not bother you?

1479
01:32:45,601 --> 01:32:50,800
I think it's certainly important
to disclose the, um...

1480
01:32:50,973 --> 01:32:53,339
The, um...

1481
01:32:55,644 --> 01:32:57,805
Well, I think that's also
a little different

1482
01:32:57,980 --> 01:33:02,508
from cases that we're talking
about here because, um...

1483
01:33:17,266 --> 01:33:21,498
So, what do you think this
says about the economics discipline?

1484
01:33:21,670 --> 01:33:25,629
Well, I mean, it has no
relevance to anything, really.

1485
01:33:25,807 --> 01:33:29,709
And, indeed,
I think it's a part of the...

1486
01:33:29,878 --> 01:33:33,881
It's an important part
of the problem.

1487
01:33:48,496 --> 01:33:51,727
The rising power of the U.S.
Financial sector

1488
01:33:51,899 --> 01:33:54,663
was part of a wider change
in America.

1489
01:33:55,036 --> 01:33:59,632
Since the 1980s, the United States
has become a more unequal society,

1490
01:34:00,207 --> 01:34:03,608
and it's economic dominance
has declined.

1491
01:34:03,911 --> 01:34:08,371
Companies like General Motors,
Chrysler and U.S. Steel,

1492
01:34:08,549 --> 01:34:11,109
formerly the core
of the U.S. Economy,

1493
01:34:11,285 --> 01:34:15,881
were poorly managed and falling
behind their foreign competitors.

1494
01:34:16,691 --> 01:34:19,751
And as countries like China
opened their economies,

1495
01:34:19,927 --> 01:34:24,091
American companies
sent jobs overseas to save money.

1496
01:34:26,067 --> 01:34:29,400
For many, many years,
the 660 million people

1497
01:34:29,570 --> 01:34:31,868
in the developed world
were sheltered

1498
01:34:32,039 --> 01:34:35,907
from all of this additional labor
that existed on the planet.

1499
01:34:36,077 --> 01:34:38,944
Suddenly the Bamboo Curtain
and the Iron Curtain are lifted

1500
01:34:39,113 --> 01:34:42,276
and you have 2.5 billion
additional people.

1501
01:34:42,984 --> 01:34:46,977
American factory workers were laid
off by the tens of thousands.

1502
01:34:47,154 --> 01:34:49,782
Our manufacturing base
was destroyed, literally,

1503
01:34:49,957 --> 01:34:51,254
over a few years.

1504
01:34:51,425 --> 01:34:55,725
As manufacturing declined,
other industries rose.

1505
01:34:55,896 --> 01:34:59,127
The United States leads the world
in information technology,

1506
01:34:59,300 --> 01:35:02,360
where high-paying jobs
are easy to find.

1507
01:35:02,536 --> 01:35:04,697
But those jobs
require an education.

1508
01:35:05,006 --> 01:35:09,874
And for average Americans,
college is increasingly out of reach.

1509
01:35:10,210 --> 01:35:15,341
While universities like Harvard have
billions of dollars in endowments,

1510
01:35:15,515 --> 01:35:19,815
funding for public universities
is shrinking and tuition is rising.

1511
01:35:20,787 --> 01:35:23,255
Tuition for California's
public universities

1512
01:35:23,423 --> 01:35:29,760
rose from $650 in the 1970s
to over $ 10,000 in 2010.

1513
01:35:30,797 --> 01:35:35,063
The most important determinant
of whether Americans go to college

1514
01:35:35,235 --> 01:35:38,227
is whether they can find
the money to pay for it.

1515
01:35:38,505 --> 01:35:43,465
Meanwhile, American tax policy
shifted to favor the wealthy.

1516
01:35:43,643 --> 01:35:48,842
When I first came to office, I thought
taxes were too high, and they were.

1517
01:35:49,015 --> 01:35:51,813
The most dramatic change
was a series of tax cuts

1518
01:35:51,985 --> 01:35:54,613
designed by Glenn Hubbard,
who was serving

1519
01:35:54,788 --> 01:35:58,087
as President Bush's
chief economic advisor.

1520
01:35:58,825 --> 01:36:02,454
The Bush administration sharply
reduced taxes on investment gains,

1521
01:36:02,629 --> 01:36:05,621
stock dividends,
and eliminated the estate tax.

1522
01:36:05,799 --> 01:36:08,927
We had a comprehensive plan
that when acted

1523
01:36:09,102 --> 01:36:12,868
has left nearly $ 1.1 trillion
in the hands of American workers,

1524
01:36:13,039 --> 01:36:15,633
families, investors
and small-business owners.

1525
01:36:15,809 --> 01:36:21,611
Most benefits of these cuts went to the
wealthiest 1 percent of Americans.

1526
01:36:22,148 --> 01:36:24,412
And by the way,
it was the cornerstone

1527
01:36:24,584 --> 01:36:26,950
in many ways,
of our economic recovery policy.

1528
01:36:27,420 --> 01:36:29,945
Inequality of wealth
in the United States

1529
01:36:30,123 --> 01:36:33,524
is now higher
than in any other developed country.

1530
01:36:34,127 --> 01:36:36,891
American families responded
to these changes in two ways:

1531
01:36:38,331 --> 01:36:42,892
By working longer hours
and by going into debt.

1532
01:36:43,068 --> 01:36:46,663
As the middle class falls
further and further behind,

1533
01:36:46,839 --> 01:36:50,707
there is a political urge
to respond

1534
01:36:50,876 --> 01:36:54,209
by making it easier to get credit.

1535
01:36:54,379 --> 01:36:56,870
You don't have to have
a lousy home.

1536
01:36:57,049 --> 01:37:02,646
The low-income home buyer can have
just as nice a house as anybody else.

1537
01:37:03,188 --> 01:37:07,591
American families borrowed
to finance their homes, their cars,

1538
01:37:07,759 --> 01:37:11,525
their healthcare,
and their children's educations.

1539
01:37:11,897 --> 01:37:14,559
People in the bottom 90 percent

1540
01:37:15,033 --> 01:37:19,595
lost ground
between 1980 and 2007.

1541
01:37:19,771 --> 01:37:24,504
It all went to the top 1 percent.

1542
01:37:26,478 --> 01:37:29,379
For the first time in history,
average Americans

1543
01:37:29,548 --> 01:37:34,315
have less education and are less
prosperous than their parents.

1544
01:37:36,488 --> 01:37:39,719
The era of greed and irresponsibility

1545
01:37:39,892 --> 01:37:43,191
on Wall Street and in Washington

1546
01:37:43,362 --> 01:37:45,421
has led us to a financial crisis

1547
01:37:45,597 --> 01:37:49,294
as serious as any that we've faced
since the Great Depression.

1548
01:37:49,468 --> 01:37:52,733
When the financial crisis
struck before the 2008 election,

1549
01:37:53,172 --> 01:37:55,436
Barack Obama pointed
to Wall Street greed

1550
01:37:55,607 --> 01:37:59,907
and regulatory failures as examples
of the need for change in America.

1551
01:38:00,078 --> 01:38:02,774
A lack of oversight in Washington
and on Wall Street

1552
01:38:02,948 --> 01:38:05,940
is exactly what got us
into this mess.

1553
01:38:06,552 --> 01:38:10,852
After taking office, Obama spoke
of the need to reform the industry.

1554
01:38:11,023 --> 01:38:14,321
We want a risk regulator,
increased capital requirements.

1555
01:38:14,492 --> 01:38:17,120
We need a consumer financial
protection agency.

1556
01:38:17,295 --> 01:38:19,126
We need to change
Wall Street's culture.

1557
01:38:19,764 --> 01:38:22,699
But when finally enacted
in mid-2010,

1558
01:38:22,867 --> 01:38:25,631
the administration's
financial reforms were weak.

1559
01:38:25,803 --> 01:38:29,239
And in some critical areas,
including the rating agencies,

1560
01:38:29,407 --> 01:38:31,671
lobbying and compensation,

1561
01:38:31,842 --> 01:38:34,811
nothing significant
was even proposed.

1562
01:38:34,979 --> 01:38:38,471
Addressing Obama and,
quote, "regulatory reform,"

1563
01:38:38,649 --> 01:38:42,847
my response, if it was
one word, would be "ha."

1564
01:38:43,654 --> 01:38:46,088
There's very little reform.

1565
01:38:46,257 --> 01:38:47,815
How come?

1566
01:38:48,926 --> 01:38:51,087
It's a Wall Street government.

1567
01:38:53,564 --> 01:38:57,091
Obama chose Timothy
Geithner as Treasury secretary.

1568
01:38:57,268 --> 01:39:00,032
Geithner was president
of the New York Federal Reserve

1569
01:39:00,204 --> 01:39:03,071
during the crisis,
and a key player in the decision

1570
01:39:03,241 --> 01:39:05,835
to pay Goldman Sachs
100 cents on the dollar

1571
01:39:06,010 --> 01:39:07,910
for it's bets against mortgages.

1572
01:39:08,079 --> 01:39:11,071
When Tim Geithner
was testifying

1573
01:39:11,249 --> 01:39:13,479
to be confirmed
as Treasury secretary

1574
01:39:13,651 --> 01:39:16,711
he said,
"I have never been a regulator."

1575
01:39:16,887 --> 01:39:19,481
That said to me
he did not understand his job

1576
01:39:19,657 --> 01:39:21,352
as President of the New York Fed.

1577
01:39:25,696 --> 01:39:28,893
The new President of the
New York Fed is William C. Dudley,

1578
01:39:29,066 --> 01:39:31,591
the former chief economist
of Goldman Sachs

1579
01:39:31,769 --> 01:39:34,932
whose paper with Glenn Hubbard
praised derivatives.

1580
01:39:35,106 --> 01:39:37,506
Geithner's chief of staff
is Mark Patterson,

1581
01:39:37,675 --> 01:39:39,734
a former lobbyist for Goldman.

1582
01:39:39,910 --> 01:39:42,435
And one of the senior advisors
is Lewis Sachs,

1583
01:39:42,613 --> 01:39:45,741
who oversaw Tricadia,
a company heavily involved

1584
01:39:45,916 --> 01:39:49,544
in betting against the mortgage
securities it was selling.

1585
01:39:49,886 --> 01:39:52,548
To head the Commodity Futures
Trading Commission,

1586
01:39:52,722 --> 01:39:56,488
Obama picked Gary Gensler,
a former Goldman Sachs executive

1587
01:39:56,660 --> 01:39:59,595
who had helped ban
the regulation of derivatives.

1588
01:39:59,763 --> 01:40:02,061
To run the Securities
and Exchange Commission,

1589
01:40:02,232 --> 01:40:06,168
Obama picked Mary Schapiro,
the former CEO of FINRA,

1590
01:40:06,336 --> 01:40:09,999
the investment banking industry's
self-regulation body.

1591
01:40:10,173 --> 01:40:12,539
Obama's chief of staff,
Rahm Emanuel,

1592
01:40:12,709 --> 01:40:17,271
made $320,000 serving
on the board of Freddie Mac.

1593
01:40:17,514 --> 01:40:20,108
Both Martin Feldstein
and Laura Tyson are members

1594
01:40:20,283 --> 01:40:23,878
of Obama's
Economic Recovery Advisory Board.

1595
01:40:24,187 --> 01:40:28,886
And Obama's chief economic
advisor is Larry Summers.

1596
01:40:29,426 --> 01:40:31,257
The most senior
economic advisors

1597
01:40:31,428 --> 01:40:33,988
are the ones who were there,
who built the structure.

1598
01:40:34,264 --> 01:40:36,824
When it was clear
that Summers and Geithner

1599
01:40:37,000 --> 01:40:41,437
were going to play major roles
as advisors,

1600
01:40:41,604 --> 01:40:44,140
I knew this was
going to be status quo.

1601
01:40:44,708 --> 01:40:48,405
The Obama administration
resisted regulation of bank compensation

1602
01:40:48,578 --> 01:40:51,240
even as foreign leaders
took action.

1603
01:40:51,414 --> 01:40:53,780
The financial industry
is a service industry.

1604
01:40:53,950 --> 01:40:57,317
It should serve others
before it serves itself.

1605
01:40:57,787 --> 01:41:00,779
In September of 2009,
Christine Lagarde

1606
01:41:00,957 --> 01:41:03,721
and the finance ministers
of Sweden, the Netherlands,

1607
01:41:03,893 --> 01:41:07,260
Luxembourg, Italy,
Spain and Germany

1608
01:41:07,430 --> 01:41:10,729
called for the G20 nations,
including the United States,

1609
01:41:10,900 --> 01:41:14,461
to impose strict regulations
on bank compensation.

1610
01:41:14,637 --> 01:41:16,605
And in July of 2010,

1611
01:41:16,773 --> 01:41:20,766
the European Parliament
enacted those very regulations.

1612
01:41:21,044 --> 01:41:24,274
The Obama administration
had no response.

1613
01:41:24,446 --> 01:41:28,473
Their view is it's a temporary blip
and things will go back to normal.

1614
01:41:28,984 --> 01:41:32,078
That is why I am reappointing him

1615
01:41:32,254 --> 01:41:35,246
as chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Thank you, Ben.

1616
01:41:35,424 --> 01:41:39,258
In 2009, Barack Obama
reappointed Ben Bernanke.

1617
01:41:39,428 --> 01:41:40,622
Thank you, Mr. President.

1618
01:41:42,064 --> 01:41:45,966
As of mid-2010, not a single
senior financial executive

1619
01:41:46,135 --> 01:41:49,127
had been criminally prosecuted,
or even arrested.

1620
01:41:49,304 --> 01:41:51,864
No special prosecutor
had been appointed.

1621
01:41:52,040 --> 01:41:54,838
Not a single firm had been
prosecuted criminally

1622
01:41:55,010 --> 01:41:58,002
for securities fraud
or accounting fraud.

1623
01:41:58,180 --> 01:42:00,705
The Obama administration
has made no attempt

1624
01:42:00,883 --> 01:42:02,680
to recover any compensation

1625
01:42:02,851 --> 01:42:05,877
given to financial executives
during the bubble.

1626
01:42:07,055 --> 01:42:10,388
I certainly would think
of criminal action

1627
01:42:10,559 --> 01:42:14,222
against some of Countrywide's
top leaders, like Mozilo.

1628
01:42:14,396 --> 01:42:17,729
I'd certainly look at Bear Stearns,
Goldman Sachs

1629
01:42:17,900 --> 01:42:20,164
and Lehman Brothers
and Merrill Lynch.

1630
01:42:20,335 --> 01:42:21,461
For criminal prosecutions?

1631
01:42:21,637 --> 01:42:22,797
Yes.

1632
01:42:22,971 --> 01:42:26,634
In regard to...
Yes. They'd be very hard to win,

1633
01:42:26,875 --> 01:42:32,370
but I think they could do it if they got
enough underlings to tell the truth.

1634
01:42:32,714 --> 01:42:35,547
In an industry
in which drug use, prostitution

1635
01:42:35,717 --> 01:42:38,686
and billing of prostitutes
as a business expense

1636
01:42:38,854 --> 01:42:40,685
occur on an industrial scale,

1637
01:42:40,856 --> 01:42:44,792
it wouldn't be hard to make
people talk if you really wanted to.

1638
01:42:45,227 --> 01:42:48,492
They gave me a plea bargain
and I took it.

1639
01:42:48,664 --> 01:42:50,757
They were not interested
in my records.

1640
01:42:50,933 --> 01:42:52,594
They weren't interested in anything.

1641
01:42:52,768 --> 01:42:54,065
Not interested in your records?

1642
01:42:54,236 --> 01:42:55,863
That's correct. Correct.

1643
01:42:56,038 --> 01:43:02,203
There's a sensibility that you
don't use people's personal vices

1644
01:43:02,376 --> 01:43:06,278
in the context of Wall Street cases,
necessarily, to get them to flip.

1645
01:43:06,447 --> 01:43:11,817
Maybe after the cataclysms that we've
been through, people will reevaluate.

1646
01:43:11,986 --> 01:43:15,945
I'm not the one to pass judgment
on that right now.

1647
01:43:29,270 --> 01:43:34,640
You come to us today telling
us, "We're sorry, we didn't mean it."

1648
01:43:34,809 --> 01:43:38,006
We won't do it again. Trust us."

1649
01:43:38,179 --> 01:43:41,114
Well, I have some people
in my constituency

1650
01:43:41,282 --> 01:43:43,978
that actually robbed
some of your banks.

1651
01:43:44,151 --> 01:43:46,085
And they say the same thing.

1652
01:43:46,254 --> 01:43:49,314
They're sorry. They didn't mean it.
They won't do it again.

1653
01:43:49,924 --> 01:43:54,793
In 2009, as unemployment hit
it's highest level in 17 years,

1654
01:43:54,962 --> 01:43:58,261
Morgan Stanley paid it's employees
over $ 14 billion,

1655
01:43:58,432 --> 01:44:01,595
and Goldman Sachs paid out
over $ 16 billion.

1656
01:44:01,769 --> 01:44:05,500
In 2010,
bonuses were even higher.

1657
01:44:05,673 --> 01:44:09,131
Why should a financial engineer
be paid

1658
01:44:09,310 --> 01:44:15,476
four times to 100 times more
than a real engineer?

1659
01:44:15,650 --> 01:44:17,811
A real engineer build Bridges.

1660
01:44:17,985 --> 01:44:21,318
A financial engineer build dreams.

1661
01:44:21,489 --> 01:44:25,084
And, you know, when those dreams
turn out to be nightmares,

1662
01:44:25,259 --> 01:44:26,988
other people pay for it.

1663
01:44:29,497 --> 01:44:30,589
For decades,

1664
01:44:30,764 --> 01:44:34,427
the American financial system
was stable and safe.

1665
01:44:34,834 --> 01:44:36,768
But then something changed.

1666
01:44:36,937 --> 01:44:40,270
The financial industry
turned it's back on society,

1667
01:44:40,440 --> 01:44:42,908
corrupted our political system

1668
01:44:43,343 --> 01:44:46,005
and plunged the world economy
into crisis.

1669
01:44:48,014 --> 01:44:50,949
At enormous cost,
we've avoided disaster

1670
01:44:51,251 --> 01:44:53,219
and are recovering.

1671
01:44:53,587 --> 01:44:57,421
But the men and institutions that
caused the crisis are still in power,

1672
01:44:57,591 --> 01:44:59,650
and that needs to change.

1673
01:45:00,760 --> 01:45:02,887
They will tell us
that we need them,

1674
01:45:03,063 --> 01:45:07,227
and that what they do is too
complicated for us to understand.

1675
01:45:08,034 --> 01:45:10,298
They will tell us
it won't happen again.

1676
01:45:10,704 --> 01:45:13,969
They will spend billions
fighting reform.

1677
01:45:14,374 --> 01:45:16,433
It won't be easy.

1678
01:45:17,744 --> 01:45:21,373
But some things
are worth fighting for.

title: MarginCall
script:
1
00:02:07,836 --> 00:02:09,338
Is that them?

2
00:02:12,507 --> 00:02:14,100
Jesus Christ.

3
00:02:14,176 --> 00:02:16,645
Are they going to do it right here?

4
00:02:22,476 --> 00:02:24,478
You guys ever been through this before?

5
00:02:25,103 --> 00:02:26,229
No.

6
00:02:27,064 --> 00:02:30,739
It's best to ignore it, keep your head down,
and go back to work.

7
00:02:30,734 --> 00:02:31,826
Go on.

8
00:02:38,659 --> 00:02:40,127
Don't watch.

9
00:02:59,763 --> 00:03:01,265
Timothy Singh?

10
00:03:01,848 --> 00:03:04,522
- Yes.
- I'm afraid we have to speak with you.

11
00:03:04,601 --> 00:03:05,693
Come.

12
00:03:20,867 --> 00:03:22,244
Eric Dale?

13
00:03:22,953 --> 00:03:24,125
Excuse me?

14
00:03:24,121 --> 00:03:25,338
Eric Dale?

15
00:03:26,665 --> 00:03:28,087
- No.
- Sorry?

16
00:03:28,709 --> 00:03:29,961
I'm not Eric Dale.

17
00:03:30,252 --> 00:03:32,175
I'm so sorry.

18
00:03:32,254 --> 00:03:33,380
He's my boss.

19
00:03:34,005 --> 00:03:35,723
He's down the hall.

20
00:03:35,799 --> 00:03:36,971
Thanks.

21
00:03:51,940 --> 00:03:54,318
Excuse me, Mr. Dale?

22
00:03:55,318 --> 00:03:56,615
This way.

23
00:04:05,370 --> 00:04:06,667
Okay.

24
00:04:46,369 --> 00:04:49,464
I am obviously sorry that we are here today.

25
00:04:49,539 --> 00:04:53,965
But these are extraordinary times,
as you very well must know.

26
00:04:54,711 --> 00:04:57,089
Look, I run Risk Management.

27
00:04:57,088 --> 00:05:00,433
I don't really see how that's a natural place
to start cutting jobs.

28
00:05:00,425 --> 00:05:02,894
We hope you understand
this is in no way personal.

29
00:05:02,886 --> 00:05:06,060
The majority of this floor
is being let go today.

30
00:05:08,600 --> 00:05:12,275
Ms. Bratberg is now going to run through
the details of what the firm is offering.

31
00:05:14,022 --> 00:05:15,319
Okay.

32
00:05:15,398 --> 00:05:19,904
Mr. Dale, the firm is offering you
a six-month severance at half your salary.

33
00:05:20,237 --> 00:05:23,912
You will keep all unvested options
that you currently hold.

34
00:05:23,907 --> 00:05:25,909
Health will be extended through that period.

35
00:05:25,992 --> 00:05:31,874
You have until tomorrow at 4:47
to either take the offer or it will be revoked.

36
00:05:32,415 --> 00:05:33,632
Do you understand?

37
00:05:35,210 --> 00:05:36,302
Yes.

38
00:05:37,003 --> 00:05:38,596
Unfortunately, Mr. Dale,

39
00:05:38,588 --> 00:05:41,182
due to the highly sensitive nature
of your work here,

40
00:05:41,258 --> 00:05:44,762
the firm has to take certain precautions
for security purposes

41
00:05:44,761 --> 00:05:48,482
that may seem punitive in nature.

42
00:05:48,473 --> 00:05:50,475
I hope, considering your

43
00:05:52,435 --> 00:05:54,984
over 19 years of service to the firm,

44
00:05:54,980 --> 00:05:58,325
you will understand that these measures
are in no way a reflection

45
00:05:58,316 --> 00:06:00,865
of the firm's feelings
towards your performance

46
00:06:01,319 --> 00:06:03,071
or your character.

47
00:06:03,864 --> 00:06:05,616
I don't understand.

48
00:06:06,533 --> 00:06:09,878
She's apologizing
for what's about to happen.

49
00:06:10,662 --> 00:06:14,542
Your company e-mail, access to the server,
access to the building,

50
00:06:14,624 --> 00:06:19,505
and your mobile data and phone service
will all be severed as of this meeting.

51
00:06:20,005 --> 00:06:23,475
And this gentleman
will take you to your office

52
00:06:23,550 --> 00:06:26,019
so you can clear out
your personal belongings.

53
00:06:29,931 --> 00:06:34,027
What about what I'm currently working on?
I'm in the middle of something that...

54
00:06:34,102 --> 00:06:38,858
The firm has worked out its transition plan
and is prepared to move forward.

55
00:06:38,940 --> 00:06:41,489
But we do appreciate your concern.

56
00:06:41,568 --> 00:06:45,789
We understand that this is difficult.
And here is my card.

57
00:06:46,448 --> 00:06:47,825
Please contact me in the next few weeks

58
00:06:47,824 --> 00:06:50,327
if you need any assistance
with this transition in your life.

59
00:06:56,791 --> 00:06:57,838
Sir.

60
00:07:04,883 --> 00:07:06,009
Okay.

61
00:07:07,510 --> 00:07:08,682
Okay.

62
00:07:10,555 --> 00:07:11,681
Okay.

63
00:07:38,249 --> 00:07:39,341
Hey.

64
00:07:45,006 --> 00:07:46,508
I'm sorry.

65
00:07:48,218 --> 00:07:50,596
- You still alive?
- For now.

66
00:07:51,388 --> 00:07:52,981
Congratulations.

67
00:07:54,307 --> 00:07:56,105
It was a bloodbath.

68
00:07:56,101 --> 00:07:57,353
I heard.

69
00:07:59,896 --> 00:08:01,398
Listen, Eric,

70
00:08:02,148 --> 00:08:04,446
if there was something I could have done,
I would have done it.

71
00:08:04,442 --> 00:08:05,568
- I know.
- All right?

72
00:08:05,568 --> 00:08:08,071
Yeah, I know. I know.

73
00:08:08,863 --> 00:08:10,035
Okay.

74
00:08:10,740 --> 00:08:11,832
Just tell me,

75
00:08:12,617 --> 00:08:13,743
who was it?

76
00:08:14,411 --> 00:08:16,630
- Come on, Eric.
- Come on, Will.

77
00:08:16,705 --> 00:08:18,423
- Rogers?
- I'm not going to say, you know.

78
00:08:18,498 --> 00:08:19,875
- You know me.
- Robertson?

79
