I'm the only friend
you've got.

1746
01:29:39,241 --> 01:29:41,577
I'm making you money.

1747
01:29:41,577 --> 01:29:44,179
Take the money.

1748
01:29:44,179 --> 01:29:46,081
Invest it somewhere else.

1749
01:29:47,149 --> 01:29:48,283
Maybe...

1750
01:29:48,283 --> 01:29:49,685
Maybe you'll get lucky,

1751
01:29:49,685 --> 01:29:51,887
And it'll be used
productively.

1752
01:29:51,887 --> 01:29:54,122
And if it is,

1753
01:29:54,122 --> 01:29:55,524
You'll create new jobs

1754
01:29:55,524 --> 01:29:57,526
And provide a service
for the economy

1755
01:29:57,526 --> 01:29:59,027
And, god forbid,

1756
01:29:59,027 --> 01:30:01,864
Even make a few bucks
for yourselves.

1757
01:30:01,864 --> 01:30:04,266
[Laughter]

1758
01:30:04,266 --> 01:30:06,535
And if anybody asks,

1759
01:30:06,535 --> 01:30:09,505
Tell 'em you gave
at the plant.

1760
01:30:09,505 --> 01:30:11,039
[Laughter]

1761
01:30:11,039 --> 01:30:12,407
And by the way,

1762
01:30:12,407 --> 01:30:16,144
It pleases me
that i am called

1763
01:30:16,144 --> 01:30:19,381
Larry the liquidator.

1764
01:30:19,381 --> 01:30:21,283
You know why,
fellow stockholders?

1765
01:30:21,283 --> 01:30:23,418
Because at my funeral,

1766
01:30:23,418 --> 01:30:25,688
You'll leave with
a smile on your face

1767
01:30:25,688 --> 01:30:28,691
And a few bucks
in your pocket.

1768
01:30:28,691 --> 01:30:31,426
Now, that's a funeral
worth having.

1769
01:30:45,908 --> 01:30:47,910
The ballots
will be marked

1770
01:30:47,910 --> 01:30:50,278
And deposited
in the ballot boxes

1771
01:30:50,278 --> 01:30:51,580
At the rear
of the hall.

1772
01:30:51,580 --> 01:30:52,781
Thank you.

1773
01:31:17,940 --> 01:31:18,941
Yeah.

1774
01:31:39,695 --> 01:31:43,298
Ladies and gentlemen,
please.

1775
01:31:44,132 --> 01:31:46,635
May i have
your attention, please?

1776
01:31:46,635 --> 01:31:48,604
I will now read

1777
01:31:48,604 --> 01:31:50,739
The results
of the balloting.

1778
01:32:02,517 --> 01:32:05,520
To retain
the present board--

1779
01:32:05,520 --> 01:32:10,559
1,741,416.

1780
01:32:10,559 --> 01:32:12,160
For the opposition--

1781
01:32:12,160 --> 01:32:16,398
2,219,901.

1782
01:32:16,398 --> 01:32:18,133
Not voting--

1783
01:32:18,133 --> 01:32:21,870
176,111.

1784
01:32:21,870 --> 01:32:24,707
Mr. Garfield,
your slate is elected.

1785
01:32:50,633 --> 01:32:52,267
Congratulations,
mr. Garfield.

1786
01:32:53,268 --> 01:32:55,270
Congratulations,
lawrence.

1787
01:34:39,808 --> 01:34:41,676
You ok, boss?

1788
01:34:45,948 --> 01:34:49,117
You want some chicken
soup or something?

1789
01:34:49,117 --> 01:34:51,153
Mmm.

1790
01:34:51,153 --> 01:34:52,554
Pie?

1791
01:34:52,554 --> 01:34:54,056
No.

1792
01:34:55,824 --> 01:34:57,692
How about some
of that carrot cake

1793
01:34:57,692 --> 01:34:59,127
You like so much?

1794
01:35:03,165 --> 01:35:04,432
No.

1795
01:35:53,581 --> 01:35:56,018
Well, carmen,
we did it again.

1796
01:35:56,018 --> 01:36:00,488
I can always
count on you, can't i?

1797
01:36:00,488 --> 01:36:03,291
Another barrelful of money.

1798
01:36:03,291 --> 01:36:06,761
Not bad for a kid
from the bronx.

1799
01:36:11,233 --> 01:36:12,835
I love money.

1800
01:36:14,402 --> 01:36:15,804
I love money.

1801
01:36:15,804 --> 01:36:17,405
[Intercom beeps]

1802
01:36:17,405 --> 01:36:18,240
Mr. Garfield,

1803
01:36:18,240 --> 01:36:21,009
Kate sullivan
is on the line.

1804
01:36:23,111 --> 01:36:26,314
Are you in or out,
mr. Garfield?

1805
01:36:28,250 --> 01:36:29,017
Hello?

1806
01:36:29,017 --> 01:36:30,986
You're a greedy,
arrogant,

1807
01:36:30,986 --> 01:36:33,388
Self-Absorbed,

1808
01:36:33,388 --> 01:36:34,389
Overbearing--

1809
01:36:34,389 --> 01:36:35,190
Avaricious?

1810
01:36:35,190 --> 01:36:37,492
I have a proposition
for you.

1811
01:36:37,492 --> 01:36:39,862
Are you ready,
lawrence?

1812
01:36:39,862 --> 01:36:41,363
Ready.

1813
01:36:42,730 --> 01:36:44,632
Air bags.

1814
01:36:44,632 --> 01:36:46,902
Air bags?

1815
01:36:46,902 --> 01:36:49,737
Every car in america
is about to have one.

1816
01:36:49,737 --> 01:36:51,239
Did you know
that air bags

1817
01:36:51,239 --> 01:36:53,675
Are made from
stainless steel wire cloth?

1818
01:36:53,675 --> 01:36:56,111
Did you dump bart?

1819
01:36:57,846 --> 01:37:00,082
The mitsushimi company
of japan

1820
01:37:00,082 --> 01:37:02,017
Is ready to make
a long-Term deal

1821
01:37:02,017 --> 01:37:04,152
With new england
wire and cable

1822
01:37:04,152 --> 01:37:05,753
For the production
of...

1823
01:37:05,753 --> 01:37:07,155
[Breathy voice]
air bags.

1824
01:37:07,155 --> 01:37:10,158
I love the sound
of your voice.

1825
01:37:10,158 --> 01:37:14,162
[Breathy] well, here comes
the best part, lawrence.

1826
01:37:14,162 --> 01:37:17,765
You sell wire and cable
back to the employees.

1827
01:37:17,765 --> 01:37:21,036
They modernize
and re-Equip the plant

1828
01:37:21,036 --> 01:37:23,571
And turn out
air bags.

1829
01:37:23,571 --> 01:37:25,773
What's in it for me?

1830
01:37:25,773 --> 01:37:28,911
They'll pay
28 bucks a share.

1831
01:37:29,711 --> 01:37:31,313
You like?

1832
01:37:32,380 --> 01:37:34,516
They'll go to 30.

1833
01:37:34,516 --> 01:37:37,252
30? You think so?

1834
01:37:37,252 --> 01:37:39,187
Why not? We'll talk
about it at dinner--

1835
01:37:39,187 --> 01:37:40,788
I'll see you in an hour.

1836
01:37:40,788 --> 01:37:43,892
Lunch. Tomorrow. 1:00.

1837
01:37:43,892 --> 01:37:45,493
You know where.

1838
01:37:45,493 --> 01:37:47,329
Strictly business.

1839
01:37:47,329 --> 01:37:49,464
Oh, yeah, yeah.
Strictly business.

1840
01:37:49,464 --> 01:37:50,265
Wow!

1841
01:37:50,265 --> 01:37:51,599
Did you hear that,
carmen?

1842
01:37:51,599 --> 01:37:54,802
Harriet! Call my manicurist,
call the barber,

1843
01:37:54,802 --> 01:37:56,204
Call the florist,

1844
01:37:56,204 --> 01:37:58,073
Call arthur, tell him i want
two tickets to the opera

1845
01:37:58,073 --> 01:37:59,607
Tomorrow night.
Puccini.

1846
01:37:59,607 --> 01:38:01,743
We're back in business!

1847
01:38:01,743 --> 01:38:03,178
Whoo-Hoo!

1848
01:38:05,813 --> 01:38:08,283
It's money that i love.

1849
01:38:09,952 --> 01:38:12,754
Captioning made possible by
warner bros.

1850
01:38:12,754 --> 01:38:16,391
Captioned by the national
captioning institute
--Www.Ncicap.Org--

title: RogueTrader
script:
1
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:18,516
(newsreader) ..denied reports the British
banking system is about to collapse.

2
00:00:18,600 --> 00:00:21,990
According to him, Barings' failure
is a unique situation,...

3
00:00:22,080 --> 00:00:25,959
..which he blames on the actions
of a rogue trader in Singapore.

4
00:00:26,040 --> 00:00:31,433
Estimates of potential losses range from
800 million to over one billion pounds.

5
00:00:31,520 --> 00:00:33,511
(bulletin continues)

6
00:00:39,640 --> 00:00:41,631
# Leftfield: ''Open Up''

7
00:00:52,360 --> 00:00:54,316
Look at that!

8
00:00:54,400 --> 00:00:56,391
Will you fuckin' look at that!

9
00:00:57,280 --> 00:00:59,430
- What, with the black guy?
- Yeah.

10
00:01:01,280 --> 00:01:03,714
lt's a shame. She looks well spoken for.

11
00:01:04,520 --> 00:01:06,909
Never know your luck, though. Eh, mate?

12
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:10,709
- Think l'll give her the treatment!
- No, Steve, no. Don't do that.

13
00:01:10,800 --> 00:01:13,712
- No, you're all right.
- Don't do that. Steve. Steve!

14
00:01:16,960 --> 00:01:19,554
Hello, love.
l've got something to show ya.

15
00:01:23,600 --> 00:01:26,717
Are you out of your mind or what?
You fuckin' little prick!

16
00:01:26,800 --> 00:01:28,756
And l mean little!

17
00:01:28,840 --> 00:01:31,229
Don't judge a book
by its cover, sweetheart.

18
00:01:31,320 --> 00:01:34,118
- You're out of your league, arsehole.
- Calm down.

19
00:01:34,200 --> 00:01:35,952
Fuck off or you're dead!

20
00:01:36,040 --> 00:01:38,838
- l want you out of here, now.
- He's really sorry.

21
00:01:38,920 --> 00:01:43,038
He's pissed. He meant no disrespect.
That's the last thing on anybody's mind.

22
00:01:43,120 --> 00:01:45,634
Tell him if he doesn't
put that thing away,...

23
00:01:45,720 --> 00:01:48,598
..l'll rip it off and shove it
down his fuckin' throat!

24
00:01:48,680 --> 00:01:52,229
Do your flies up, you fuckin' animal.
You almost gave me a heart attack.

25
00:01:53,720 --> 00:01:57,269
- (cackles)
- Just leave it. lt's not worth it!

26
00:01:57,360 --> 00:01:59,555
He's done it again. l had to pull him off!

27
00:01:59,640 --> 00:02:01,392
Fuckin' right laugh!

28
00:02:03,920 --> 00:02:07,071
Aagghh! Aagghh!

29
00:02:10,360 --> 00:02:12,316
Nick! Nick!

30
00:02:12,400 --> 00:02:14,391
You all right? Nick!

31
00:02:30,520 --> 00:02:34,069
lt was thanks to Maggie Thatcher
opening up the City of London...

32
00:02:34,160 --> 00:02:39,632
..that yours truly from Watford came to be
working for a posh outfit like Barings.

33
00:02:40,840 --> 00:02:45,311
That was me lying on the floor,
if you hadn't guessed. Nick Leeson.

34
00:02:45,400 --> 00:02:47,391
You've probably heard about me.

35
00:02:51,600 --> 00:02:54,319
Barings was the oldest
private bank in the world.

36
00:02:54,400 --> 00:02:58,951
They financed the Louisiana Purchase
back in eighteen hundred and something.

37
00:02:59,040 --> 00:03:02,112
They even had the Queen as a customer!

38
00:03:06,720 --> 00:03:08,676
l was just a humble clerk.

39
00:03:08,760 --> 00:03:10,671
But not for long, l hoped.

40
00:03:11,440 --> 00:03:13,317
Car crash.

41
00:03:13,400 --> 00:03:16,551
l hit my head on the back
of the seat and broke my nose.

42
00:03:16,640 --> 00:03:20,792
Everybody else was all right cos they
were wearing their, um... seat belts.

43
00:03:20,880 --> 00:03:22,871
Poor chap!

44
00:03:23,480 --> 00:03:28,838
Nick, l know you're keen to get out of the
back office and onto the trading floor,...

45
00:03:28,920 --> 00:03:31,912
..but in the meantime
something else has come up.

46
00:03:32,000 --> 00:03:34,514
We've got problems in our Jakarta office.

47
00:03:34,600 --> 00:03:37,672
We need someone to go out there
and sort things out.

48
00:03:37,760 --> 00:03:39,671
l thought that someone might be...

49
00:03:39,760 --> 00:03:41,273
..Nick Leeson?

50
00:03:47,040 --> 00:03:50,032
lndonesia was one of
the new ''tiger economies''...

51
00:03:50,120 --> 00:03:52,554
..everyone was getting so excited about.

52
00:03:52,640 --> 00:03:55,313
''Emerging markets''
they were calling them,...

53
00:03:55,400 --> 00:03:58,676
..and Barings was one of the first
to see their potential.

54
00:03:59,560 --> 00:04:02,313
The rewards were high.
But so were the risks.

55
00:04:04,000 --> 00:04:05,877
One hundred million pounds...

56
00:04:05,960 --> 00:04:07,632
..in bearer bonds.

57
00:04:07,720 --> 00:04:09,278
As good as cash.

58
00:04:09,360 --> 00:04:11,237
We could pick 'em up, walk out,...

59
00:04:11,320 --> 00:04:13,993
..come to some arrangement
with laughing boy...

60
00:04:14,080 --> 00:04:15,957
Customers refuse to pay for them.

61
00:04:16,040 --> 00:04:19,032
They say what's on them
doesn't match the original deal.

62
00:04:19,120 --> 00:04:22,556
The real reason: the market goes down,
they don't want any more.

63
00:04:22,640 --> 00:04:24,471
lt's a mess.

64
00:04:24,560 --> 00:04:29,270
You're absolutely 100 per cent right,
Susi. lt's one hell of a fuckin' mess.

65
00:04:36,000 --> 00:04:38,355
lt was my job to sort out
the certificates...

66
00:04:38,440 --> 00:04:41,716
..so customers wouldn't have
any more excuses not to pay.

67
00:04:41,800 --> 00:04:45,679
Until then, Barings had this bloody
great hole in their balance sheet.

68
00:04:45,760 --> 00:04:48,797
lt was boring work,
but l knew if l made a success of it...

69
00:04:48,880 --> 00:04:50,836
..then l could write my own ticket.

70
00:04:50,920 --> 00:04:53,798
All the certificates
are in the right denomination.

71
00:04:53,880 --> 00:04:57,634
l've sorted out all the documentation.
That's all in order now, so...

72
00:04:57,720 --> 00:04:59,438
..all l need from you...

73
00:04:59,520 --> 00:05:01,238
..is a cheque!

74
00:05:15,040 --> 00:05:17,031
Hello. l'm Lisa.

75
00:05:21,880 --> 00:05:23,996
l'm, um... Nick Leeson. Can l help you?

76
00:05:24,080 --> 00:05:26,594
Barings sent me
to help with the settlements.

77
00:05:26,680 --> 00:05:28,238
Didn't they tell you?

78
00:05:28,320 --> 00:05:33,713
Oh, of course! l've been on at them for so
long l never thought they'd get round to it.

79
00:05:33,800 --> 00:05:36,109
What do we do with that lot?
Build a bonfire?

80
00:05:42,040 --> 00:05:45,510
l'd never even heard of Barings
before l started working for 'em.

81
00:05:45,600 --> 00:05:47,909
lt's not like there's a Barings in Watford.

82
00:05:48,000 --> 00:05:51,595
You're a hero in London. They think
the sun shines out of your arse.

83
00:05:51,680 --> 00:05:55,753
Really? l was beginning to feel like
one of those Japanese soldiers.

84
00:05:55,840 --> 00:05:59,037
Still stuck out in the jungle
20 years after the war!

85
00:05:59,120 --> 00:06:02,317
What's it like here?
They tell me it's not safe at night.

86
00:06:02,400 --> 00:06:04,356
Bollocks. The locals are great.

87
00:06:04,440 --> 00:06:09,514
And it's not full of pompous ex-colonials
thinking they were born to rule the world.

88
00:06:09,600 --> 00:06:11,431
That's what l love about Asia.

89
00:06:12,240 --> 00:06:15,550
Anyone can make it.
Doesn't matter which school you went to.

90
00:06:15,640 --> 00:06:19,235
When they told me l was going to
Jakarta l had to look it up on the map.

91
00:06:20,520 --> 00:06:22,511
As a matter of fact, so did l.

92
00:06:24,040 --> 00:06:25,632
l really want to be a trader.

93
00:06:25,720 --> 00:06:28,678
lf Barings don't let me
on the floor after this, l'm off.

94
00:06:28,760 --> 00:06:32,594
- Not gonna be bloody clerking all my life.
- Ooh! Ambitious, aren't we?

95
00:06:32,680 --> 00:06:34,591
- ls that bad?
- lt's great.

96
00:06:34,680 --> 00:06:36,511
l just want to get on in life.

97
00:06:36,600 --> 00:06:40,559
l like to enjoy myself, don't get me wrong.
Work hard, play hard.

98
00:06:41,000 --> 00:06:42,991
Well, l think this is me.

99
00:06:44,560 --> 00:06:47,199
Well, night, Nick. That was fun.

100
00:06:48,240 --> 00:06:50,549
- Yeah, it was, wasn't it?
- (door bleeps)

101
00:06:50,640 --> 00:06:53,313
- OK. Night-night!
- See you tomorrow, then.

102
00:06:55,360 --> 00:06:57,316
Lisa was a stunner all right.

103
00:06:57,400 --> 00:06:59,356
Love at first sight.

104
00:06:59,440 --> 00:07:02,750
Together we made short work
of the rest of those bonds.

105
00:07:02,840 --> 00:07:07,118
Soon we cleared up most of Barings'
losses and it was time to go home.

106
00:07:07,200 --> 00:07:08,918
See you later, Lisa.

107
00:07:09,000 --> 00:07:11,036
Bye.

108
00:07:12,600 --> 00:07:14,591
(laughs)

109
00:07:32,080 --> 00:07:35,117
l think you'll agree that in Nick
Lisa has met her prince.

110
00:07:35,200 --> 00:07:36,792
(guests) Hear! Hear!

111
00:07:36,880 --> 00:07:40,316
Join me in wishing them well
in their new life in Singapore,...

112
00:07:40,400 --> 00:07:45,076
..where Nick is to be general manager of
the trading floor. Whatever that means.

113
00:07:45,160 --> 00:07:48,072
- lt impressed the hell out of me, but...
- (laughter)

114
00:07:48,160 --> 00:07:49,434
And, um...

115
00:07:49,520 --> 00:07:52,830
To you, Nick, l'm entrusting
the most precious of gifts.

116
00:07:52,920 --> 00:07:55,753
l know you're gonna look after her
and cherish her...

117
00:07:55,840 --> 00:07:58,400
..and all those other things.
And if you don't,...

118
00:08:00,320 --> 00:08:02,550
..l'll break your bloody legs, all right?

119
00:08:03,440 --> 00:08:04,953
(woman) He means it!

120
00:08:05,640 --> 00:08:07,596
l love you so much, Lisa Leeson.

121
00:08:07,680 --> 00:08:09,875
l love you too, Nick.

122
00:08:09,960 --> 00:08:11,951
(cheering)

123
00:08:16,480 --> 00:08:20,837
As a reward for Jakarta l'd been given the
far more important market of Singapore,...

124
00:08:20,920 --> 00:08:24,435
..with a brief to set
up my own trading operation.

125
00:08:25,280 --> 00:08:27,316
l was definitely on my way.

126
00:08:30,200 --> 00:08:32,191
# DJ Rap: ''Good To Be Alive''

127
00:08:36,600 --> 00:08:39,717
- And the kitchen...
- This is your department, darling.

128
00:08:39,800 --> 00:08:41,791
Since when? Cheeky!

129
00:08:43,280 --> 00:08:45,271
And the bedroom...

130
00:09:00,200 --> 00:09:02,953
- lf you need anything, call me.
- Right, thanks.

131
00:09:03,040 --> 00:09:04,996
- Have a nice day.
- Thanks. Bye.

132
00:09:05,080 --> 00:09:07,071
- Goodbye.
- (door shuts)

133
00:09:08,360 --> 00:09:10,920
Not bad for a chancer from Watford, eh?

134
00:09:11,000 --> 00:09:14,356
Well, um... l think we should
test out that mattress, big boy.

135
00:09:14,440 --> 00:09:16,431
- Oh, yeah?
- Yeah!

136
00:09:21,080 --> 00:09:23,071
(Lisa) Whoo!

137
00:09:40,000 --> 00:09:44,278
l can't see any problem in you
handling both sides of the operation.

138
00:09:44,360 --> 00:09:46,920
- At least until volumes increase.
- Right.

139
00:09:47,000 --> 00:09:49,798
You shouldn't need more than two
on the trading floor.

140
00:09:49,880 --> 00:09:51,791
A couple more in the back office.

141
00:09:51,880 --> 00:09:53,711
No need to pay top dollar.

142
00:09:53,800 --> 00:09:56,553
Get them young, get them hungry
and train them up.

143
00:09:56,640 --> 00:10:01,191
- l'm a bottom line kind of guy, Nick.
- Absolutely. That's my philosophy.

144
00:10:01,760 --> 00:10:04,718
l took him at his word.
My team were young, hungry...

145
00:10:04,800 --> 00:10:06,518
..and they didn't have a clue.

146
00:10:06,600 --> 00:10:11,390
A futures contract allows you to buy or
sell a specified amount of a commodity...

147
00:10:11,480 --> 00:10:13,869
..at a specified price at a future date.

148
00:10:17,360 --> 00:10:19,191
Right. Um...

149
00:10:19,280 --> 00:10:23,796
lt's like, if l agree to sell you this cup
of cappuccino, which l don't yet own,...

150
00:10:23,880 --> 00:10:25,916
..at 45 cents a month from now...

151
00:10:26,000 --> 00:10:30,198
lf l can buy the cappuccino at,
say, 43 cents, l make a profit.

152
00:10:30,280 --> 00:10:33,590
lf the price goes the other way
l have to pay more, and l lose.

153
00:10:33,680 --> 00:10:36,558
lt's timing - buying and selling
at the right moment.

154
00:10:36,640 --> 00:10:39,871
Sometimes espresso might be
the best deal, or salt, or pepper.

155
00:10:39,960 --> 00:10:42,030
So, we're running a supermarket?

156
00:10:44,240 --> 00:10:46,595
We're not buying and selling
anything real.

157
00:10:46,680 --> 00:10:50,195
lt's just numbers - contracts
based on the value of the Nikkei,...

158
00:10:50,280 --> 00:10:51,998
..the Tokyo stock market.

159
00:10:52,080 --> 00:10:55,436
- Er, we do this for the bank?
- No, no, for the customers.

160
00:10:55,520 --> 00:10:58,478
We are not allowed to trade
on behalf of the bank.

161
00:10:58,560 --> 00:11:00,994
Be sure you remember that, all right?

162
00:11:01,680 --> 00:11:05,719
Other dealers wear red jackets. All same.
Red is lucky Chinese colour.

163
00:11:05,800 --> 00:11:09,679
Well, we want to stand out. We're a
new operation. We need to be noticed.

164
00:11:09,760 --> 00:11:11,716
May be bad luck. Different colour.

165
00:11:11,800 --> 00:11:13,711
Bollocks. We make our own luck.

166
00:11:13,800 --> 00:11:17,076
Nick's right.
We're cool dudes, man. Whoo!

167
00:11:18,480 --> 00:11:20,471
(Nick chuckles)

168
00:11:21,680 --> 00:11:24,592
# Barrett Strong:
''Money (That's What l Want)''

169
00:11:28,160 --> 00:11:31,152
(roar of voices)

170
00:11:53,000 --> 00:11:55,560
Fernando. Anything happening in Tokyo?

171
00:11:55,640 --> 00:11:57,392
Nothin'. How's SlMEX?

172
00:11:58,640 --> 00:12:00,551
Same here. No one's playin'.

173
00:12:00,640 --> 00:12:02,631
590, and trading small.

174
00:12:02,720 --> 00:12:04,517
600, and thin too.

175
00:12:07,280 --> 00:12:10,955
580 here. There's a seller who wants
to trade in size. Shall l low-tick him?

176
00:12:11,040 --> 00:12:12,632
Yeah. Flush him out.

177
00:12:13,200 --> 00:12:16,078
- Squeeze the sucker.
- How many?

178
00:12:16,160 --> 00:12:17,479
200.

179
00:12:17,560 --> 00:12:19,232
Buy them... now.

180
00:12:20,000 --> 00:12:21,672
- Buy 'em!
- Filled!

181
00:12:22,800 --> 00:12:24,597
We paid 580 for 200.

182
00:12:24,680 --> 00:12:27,069
Way to go, Nick! l sold at 590.

183
00:12:27,800 --> 00:12:30,268
Fuck a duck! Just made 2,000 quid.

184
00:12:30,360 --> 00:12:31,998
Yes!

185
00:12:32,080 --> 00:12:34,071
# ''Money'' continues

186
00:12:38,800 --> 00:12:41,712
They were a good bunch
and they were keen to learn.

187
00:12:43,000 --> 00:12:47,073
lt looked like a madhouse with
all the traders waving and shouting,...

188
00:12:47,160 --> 00:12:50,038
..but it all made sense
once you got the hang of it.

189
00:12:50,120 --> 00:12:53,192
There were hiccups,
but that's normal in any operation,...

190
00:12:53,280 --> 00:12:55,953
..especially a new one like ours.

191
00:12:57,400 --> 00:13:00,790
The important thing was
we were picking up the business...

192
00:13:00,880 --> 00:13:02,871
..and the future looked rosy.

193
00:13:15,320 --> 00:13:19,996
Nick, what's the difference between
initial margin and variation margin?

194
00:13:20,080 --> 00:13:24,039
lnitial margin's a down payment
on each futures contract that we trade.

195
00:13:24,120 --> 00:13:26,395
We don't pay in full
until a contract matures.

196
00:13:26,480 --> 00:13:30,155
But in the meantime the value of
each contract may go up or down.

197
00:13:30,240 --> 00:13:33,391
So SlMEX calculate our positions
on a daily basis.

198
00:13:33,480 --> 00:13:37,712
They'll ask for more money if the market
goes against us. That's variation margin.

199
00:13:37,800 --> 00:13:40,189
Got it. l think!

200
00:13:43,360 --> 00:13:46,955
We need to open an errors account.
We've had a few mistakes.

201
00:13:47,040 --> 00:13:50,157
l need somewhere to put them
till l can write them out.

202
00:13:50,240 --> 00:13:52,834
Sure. What number shall l give it?

203
00:13:52,920 --> 00:13:56,754
- Well, what's your lucky number?
- Eight. lt is a very lucky Chinese number.

204
00:13:56,840 --> 00:13:59,274
And how many numbers do we need?

205
00:13:59,360 --> 00:14:00,509
Five.

206
00:14:00,600 --> 00:14:04,718
Then let's give it all the luck it can handle.
Call it the 88888 account.

207
00:14:26,320 --> 00:14:32,316
And now it gives me great pleasure to
welcome the chairman of Barings Bank,...

208
00:14:32,640 --> 00:14:34,631
..Peter Baring.

209
00:14:43,080 --> 00:14:45,799
We may be the oldest
merchant bank in the world,...

210
00:14:45,880 --> 00:14:49,839
..but that's no excuse for
not keeping up with the times.

211
00:14:49,920 --> 00:14:51,876
When l became chairman,...

212
00:14:51,960 --> 00:14:56,351
..l realised we couldn't go on running
Barings like a gentlemen's club.

213
00:14:56,440 --> 00:15:00,718
We had to look beyond
our traditional recruiting grounds,...

214
00:15:00,800 --> 00:15:02,870
..the old school tie,...

215
00:15:02,960 --> 00:15:06,032
..to seek out a new and hungrier breed.

216
00:15:07,000 --> 00:15:11,437
We're beginning to see the fruits
of those efforts, and l have to say,...

217
00:15:11,520 --> 00:15:17,311
..the recovery in profitability, since
the reorganisation, has been... amazing.

218
00:15:17,400 --> 00:15:22,030
To be frank, l've discovered
it's not actually terribly difficult...

219
00:15:22,120 --> 00:15:24,839
..to make money
in the securities business!

220
00:15:35,000 --> 00:15:36,228
Filled.

221
00:15:46,280 --> 00:15:48,271
Yeah, you paid 50 for 20.

222
00:15:49,680 --> 00:15:52,274
- (knock on door)
- Come in.

223
00:15:53,000 --> 00:15:55,195
Simon, er... l've got a slight problem.

224
00:15:55,280 --> 00:15:59,717
One of the girls sold 20 contracts
for Fuji Bank instead of buying.

225
00:15:59,800 --> 00:16:01,950
l can't do anything about it till Monday.

226
00:16:02,040 --> 00:16:03,519
What's the damage?

227
00:16:04,880 --> 00:16:06,871
20,000 at the close.

228
00:16:09,800 --> 00:16:12,553
Sack the cow.
She'll never work on SlMEX again.

229
00:16:13,200 --> 00:16:15,111
That's a bit hard, isn't it?

230
00:16:15,200 --> 00:16:17,236
Look, you handle it.

231
00:16:17,320 --> 00:16:21,472
Have a word with London,
but make sure you make that client good.

232
00:16:23,120 --> 00:16:25,350
All right.

233
00:16:30,120 --> 00:16:32,076
Hey! Have a beer, shithead!

234
00:16:32,160 --> 00:16:33,593
Cheers.

235
00:16:33,680 --> 00:16:35,591
Hi, darling.

236
00:16:35,680 --> 00:16:37,875
Anyone seen Kim?

237
00:16:37,960 --> 00:16:40,235
She was here a minute ago.

238
00:16:45,560 --> 00:16:47,551
Kim...

239
00:16:48,480 --> 00:16:50,436
Nick, Nick...

240
00:16:50,520 --> 00:16:52,511
l'm really sorry. l got so confused.

241
00:16:52,600 --> 00:16:55,592
- Everybody was shouting all at once.
- That's the job.

242
00:16:55,680 --> 00:16:58,638
That's what it's all about,
keeping a cool head.

243
00:16:58,720 --> 00:17:01,029
l'm so sorry! l'll pay you back the money.

244
00:17:01,120 --> 00:17:05,830
Sure, Kim. Four years' salary? And if
the market moves it could be even worse.

245
00:17:07,720 --> 00:17:09,358
Come on, come on.

246
00:17:09,440 --> 00:17:11,396
Come on, everyone makes mistakes.

247
00:17:12,760 --> 00:17:16,719
Look, with a bit of luck l can
trade out of it on Monday, all right?

248
00:17:17,720 --> 00:17:21,872
Nick, l've been waiting for you while
everyone else is having a good time.

249
00:17:21,960 --> 00:17:23,951
- l'm going home now.
- Kim!

250
00:17:25,440 --> 00:17:27,590
Kim...!

251
00:17:33,720 --> 00:17:36,154
- Everything all right?
- Never better.

252
00:17:37,720 --> 00:17:42,077
Why don't you let me come in and help?
l can't sit around all day doing nothing.

253
00:17:42,160 --> 00:17:44,151
lt's not a problem, Lisa.

254
00:17:44,760 --> 00:17:46,751
l can handle it.

255
00:17:52,600 --> 00:17:55,194
Fernando, how are
March futures looking?

256
00:17:55,280 --> 00:17:59,319
- l need 20 contracts at Friday's price.
- You won't get Friday's price!

257
00:17:59,400 --> 00:18:02,437
l should have closed off the position
and taken the loss.

258
00:18:02,520 --> 00:18:04,750
lnstead, l waited for the market to
change.

259
00:18:04,840 --> 00:18:07,274
lt changed all right,
but not the way l wanted.

260
00:18:07,360 --> 00:18:11,512
Now l was stuck with a bigger loss than
l could own up to. And it was all my fault.

261
00:18:11,600 --> 00:18:14,592
Nick! l hear your girl handed in her notice.

262
00:18:14,680 --> 00:18:17,148
Never came back.
She couldn't stand the pace.

263
00:18:17,240 --> 00:18:18,878
So much for loyalty!

264
00:18:18,960 --> 00:18:22,919
- Did you make the client good?
- Of course. Made a small profit, actually.

265
00:18:23,000 --> 00:18:24,991
Good man.

266
00:18:29,200 --> 00:18:31,873
(softly) This one's for
the five eights account.

267
00:18:31,960 --> 00:18:33,996
l bought the missing contracts.

268
00:18:34,080 --> 00:18:35,433
60,000?

269
00:18:35,520 --> 00:18:37,636
- Shh!
- lt was only 20 before.

270
00:18:37,720 --> 00:18:40,632
And the market went the wrong way.
l had to cut the loss.

271
00:18:40,720 --> 00:18:42,676
What did Simon Jones say?

272
00:18:42,760 --> 00:18:44,716
Are you serious?
He'd shut us down if he knew.

273
00:18:44,800 --> 00:18:48,509
lt'll be all right so long as we balance
the books by the end of the month.

274
00:18:48,600 --> 00:18:50,636
- How?
- We trade on our own account...

275
00:18:50,720 --> 00:18:54,793
..until we wipe out the losses, then
we use money from the client account...

276
00:18:54,880 --> 00:18:57,269
..and pay it back with
next month's profits.

277
00:18:57,360 --> 00:18:58,918
You mean, gamble?

278
00:18:59,760 --> 00:19:02,832
(whispers) Relax, Bonnie.
That's all the market is.

279
00:19:02,920 --> 00:19:05,115
One giant casino!

280
00:19:11,240 --> 00:19:12,798
George!

281
00:19:13,520 --> 00:19:17,752
l was counting on nobody looking at
the books until the end of each month.

282
00:19:17,840 --> 00:19:21,833
As long as the five eights account had a
nil balance on the last day of the month,...

283
00:19:21,920 --> 00:19:24,718
..no one would suspect
that anything was wrong.

284
00:19:24,800 --> 00:19:28,031
But instead of winning back
the position we made more losses,...

285
00:19:28,120 --> 00:19:31,999
..and l had to borrow more money
from the client account to hide them.

286
00:19:41,280 --> 00:19:45,592
Fuckin' hell, George,
what are you playing at? Get fuckin' out!

287
00:19:45,680 --> 00:19:47,671
Get fuckin' out! Now!

288
00:19:49,320 --> 00:19:52,551
What the hell are you playing at?
Out! Get out!

289
00:19:54,600 --> 00:19:56,591
Fuckin' hell!

290
00:19:59,200 --> 00:20:02,192
- Agh.
- God, you're tense. Stiff as a board.

291
00:20:02,280 --> 00:20:06,637
lf you only knew! All cos those bastards
won't let me hire proper staff.

292
00:20:06,720 --> 00:20:10,315
- l thought it was going so well.
- lt is. lt's going brilliant.

293
00:20:10,400 --> 00:20:13,836
l just spend most of my life
covering everybody else's arse.

294
00:20:13,920 --> 00:20:16,832
Well, why don't you let me
help with the back office?

295
00:20:16,920 --> 00:20:19,309
- l'm bored being a lady of leisure.
- No.

296
00:20:19,400 --> 00:20:23,632
Why not? lt's ridiculous, you having
to handle trading and settlements.

297
00:20:23,720 --> 00:20:25,631
You'll have a nervous breakdown.

298
00:20:25,720 --> 00:20:28,109
l don't want you interfering.
l can handle it.

299
00:20:28,200 --> 00:20:31,875
All right, keep your pants on!
No one's saying you can't.

300
00:20:32,640 --> 00:20:36,872
l'm not going back to being
a bloody clerk. l'd rather be a plasterer.

301
00:20:38,600 --> 00:20:41,717
My mum always used to say
l could be anything l wanted,...

302
00:20:41,800 --> 00:20:44,553
..so long as l took my chances -
and worked like a dog.

303
00:20:44,640 --> 00:20:47,916
Well, you have.
You've worked really hard and it paid off.

304
00:20:48,000 --> 00:20:49,797
She'd have been so proud of you.

305
00:20:49,880 --> 00:20:52,110
Do you really think so?

306
00:20:52,600 --> 00:20:54,318
Yeah.

307
00:20:54,400 --> 00:20:56,197
l know l am!

308
00:21:00,640 --> 00:21:04,872
That was the worst part -
Lisa thinking l was this brilliant success.

309
00:21:05,720 --> 00:21:08,917
lf she only knew
what a fuck-up l really was!

310
00:21:09,000 --> 00:21:11,434
When l wanted the market
to go up, it went down.

311
00:21:11,520 --> 00:21:13,590
lf l wanted it to go down, it went up.

312
00:21:14,000 --> 00:21:16,434
lt was hard not to take it personally.

313
00:21:25,880 --> 00:21:27,359
Nick?

314
00:21:27,440 --> 00:21:30,796
Nick! l just worked out the balance
in the eights account.

315
00:21:30,880 --> 00:21:34,634
- The losses are over $10 million!
- Keep your fuckin' voice down!

316
00:21:34,720 --> 00:21:36,711
Look, there's no need to panic.

317
00:21:37,800 --> 00:21:42,271
There's not enough in the client account
to make margin payments, Nick.

318
00:21:45,480 --> 00:21:47,072
(softly) Right.

319
00:21:49,960 --> 00:21:54,158
l need dollars. l need dollars
to cover the initial margin payment!

320
00:21:54,800 --> 00:21:59,510
l can get dollars from London to cover all
the client positions for the futures l buy!

321
00:21:59,600 --> 00:22:03,309
Nothing unusual about that.
But l'm gonna need yen.

322
00:22:03,400 --> 00:22:06,437
Gonna need yen to cover
the daily variation columns!

323
00:22:06,520 --> 00:22:09,717
Which'll leave a yen deficit
by the end of the month.

324
00:22:10,320 --> 00:22:13,073
Unless... unless l sell options.

325
00:22:13,560 --> 00:22:15,869
That'll generate commission in yen.

326
00:22:16,600 --> 00:22:20,559
And return the balance sheet
on the five eights account to zero!

327
00:22:23,440 --> 00:22:27,752
As long as London kept sending out
money to finance the client positions,...

328
00:22:27,840 --> 00:22:31,310
..l'd have enough cash to stay
on top of the margin payments.

329
00:22:32,000 --> 00:22:34,514
lt was like robbing Peter to pay Paul,...

330
00:22:35,120 --> 00:22:40,319
..but hopefully l'd end up making enough
to pay Peter back before he found out.

331
00:22:40,400 --> 00:22:45,030
Meanwhile l had to generate more and
more business to justify my cash calls,...

332
00:22:45,120 --> 00:22:47,270
..and for that l needed customers.

333
00:22:48,560 --> 00:22:50,551
The bigger the better.

334
00:22:59,120 --> 00:23:01,111
Mm-hm. Oui.

335
00:23:03,040 --> 00:23:04,996
Bon, tres bien.

336
00:23:05,080 --> 00:23:06,798
Mr Leeson.

337
00:23:06,880 --> 00:23:09,314
- l'm Pierre Beaumarchais.
- Nice to meet you.

338
00:23:09,400 --> 00:23:12,631
l work for the Geneva Banking Trust,
based in the Bahamas.

339
00:23:13,320 --> 00:23:16,710
l was speaking with Ang Swee Tian,
president of SlMEX.

340
00:23:16,800 --> 00:23:20,315
He's impressed by the amount of
business you've been generating.

341
00:23:20,400 --> 00:23:22,994
- There's a lot of opportunities here.
- Oh, yes.

342
00:23:24,040 --> 00:23:26,031
l do a lot of business on SlMEX.

343
00:23:26,600 --> 00:23:28,795
With the exception of George Soros,...

344
00:23:28,880 --> 00:23:31,792
..l probably trade in the Nikkei
more than anyone.

345
00:23:31,880 --> 00:23:34,952
Sometimes over 5,000 contracts in a day.

346
00:23:35,040 --> 00:23:38,476
That is a lot.
The whole market only does about 20.

347
00:23:39,760 --> 00:23:42,832
Could Barings handle
that amount of business?

348
00:23:46,200 --> 00:23:48,236
You bet we could!

349
00:23:48,320 --> 00:23:50,880
Beaumarchais was
the answer to my prayers.

350
00:23:50,960 --> 00:23:53,520
l'd be able to siphon off
enough commission...

351
00:23:53,600 --> 00:23:56,910
..to square the eights account
once and for all.

352
00:23:58,120 --> 00:24:00,315
- Hello?
- Pierre Beaumarchais.

353
00:24:00,400 --> 00:24:02,914
l want to buy 4,000 June contracts.

354
00:24:04,360 --> 00:24:07,158
l've... got a price of 350,
but this'll move it.

355
00:24:07,240 --> 00:24:09,754
Try not to pay more than 400.

356
00:24:09,840 --> 00:24:12,673
We gotta get them cheap.
Beaumarchais is a big player.

357
00:24:12,760 --> 00:24:15,354
lf we pull this off,
we get a shitload of business.

358
00:24:15,440 --> 00:24:18,000
- What's liquidity like?
- Tight as a flea's arse.

359
00:24:18,080 --> 00:24:20,753
We'll get away with 500,
then the price will move up.

360
00:24:20,840 --> 00:24:24,116
OK. But then we'll make the other
traders think we're sellers.

361
00:24:24,200 --> 00:24:26,509
And when the price drops... buy! All right?

362
00:24:26,600 --> 00:24:28,192
OK.

363
00:24:37,040 --> 00:24:39,156
Sell 250!

364
00:24:39,240 --> 00:24:40,958
Sell 250! Sell 250!

365
00:24:41,040 --> 00:24:42,792
Sell 240!

366
00:24:42,880 --> 00:24:45,394
Sell 240! Sell 240!

367
00:24:50,760 --> 00:24:52,955
Sell 200! Sell 200!

368
00:24:57,000 --> 00:24:59,309
- Buy 500 contracts!
- Sell 200!

369
00:25:00,400 --> 00:25:02,118
Buy? Buy?

370
00:25:02,200 --> 00:25:05,158
Buy at 200! Buy at 200! Buy at 210!

371
00:25:05,240 --> 00:25:07,231
Buy at 210! Buy at 220!

372
00:25:08,440 --> 00:25:10,635
Buy at 220! Buy at 230!

373
00:25:12,600 --> 00:25:14,238
Buy at 240!

374
00:25:14,320 --> 00:25:16,311
Buy at 240! Buy at 240!

375
00:25:19,960 --> 00:25:21,598
Filled!

376
00:25:25,760 --> 00:25:30,197
Nobody saw us coming! We swooped
on the first 1 500 like a Stealth bomber!

377
00:25:30,280 --> 00:25:32,111
4,000 contracts!

378
00:25:32,200 --> 00:25:35,192
Balls of steel, Fat Boy.
Balls of fuckin' steel!

379
00:25:42,840 --> 00:25:46,150
# Andy Williams:
''Can't Take My Eyes Off You''

380
00:25:52,720 --> 00:25:56,918
At last my luck had changed.
Suddenly l couldn't stop making money.

381
00:25:57,640 --> 00:26:01,792
l was long in the Nikkei - that meant
gambling on it going up - and up it went.

382
00:26:02,880 --> 00:26:04,871
Up and up and up.

383
00:26:10,240 --> 00:26:12,834
That's very good! Very good.

384
00:26:15,120 --> 00:26:17,111
Serves you right, Lisa!

385
00:26:30,080 --> 00:26:35,154
lf it went all the way up to 1 9,000, l stood
to make a killing on the options l'd sold.

386
00:26:38,560 --> 00:26:41,996
Come on, come on!
Come on, baby, you can do it. Come on.

387
00:26:43,640 --> 00:26:45,631
- Yes!
- Yes!

388
00:26:49,560 --> 00:26:53,030
Bonnie, we're on a fuckin' roll!

389
00:26:53,120 --> 00:26:55,111
Yes!

390
00:26:56,040 --> 00:26:57,996
Do you think we'll do it?

391
00:26:58,080 --> 00:27:00,071
(bell rings)

392
00:27:05,440 --> 00:27:08,113
lt's amazing!
You've made back all the losses.

393
00:27:08,200 --> 00:27:12,432
- Over $10 million.
- What did l tell you? Oh, ye of little faith!

394
00:27:12,520 --> 00:27:15,239
You keep doubling up,
and sooner or later...

395
00:27:15,320 --> 00:27:17,356
..you're bound to win.

396
00:27:20,760 --> 00:27:22,318
# ''Jingle Bells''

397
00:27:22,400 --> 00:27:25,358
The Nikkei has closed up
for the third day in a row,...

398
00:27:25,440 --> 00:27:28,876
..and the rally shows little sign
of running out of steam.

399
00:27:28,960 --> 00:27:32,430
Analysts are predicting
additional gains in the days ahead.

400
00:27:32,520 --> 00:27:34,511
(bulletin continues)

401
00:27:41,640 --> 00:27:43,596
- Happy?
- Yeah. Are you?

402
00:27:43,680 --> 00:27:45,511
Never better.

403
00:27:48,400 --> 00:27:52,359
l have been sailing a bit close to the wind.
l didn't want to worry you with it.

404
00:27:53,000 --> 00:27:55,150
- What do you mean?
- No, it's all right.

405
00:27:55,240 --> 00:27:58,755
The market turned round and a whole
load of my positions came good.

406
00:27:58,840 --> 00:28:00,717
l made it all back.

407
00:28:00,800 --> 00:28:02,791
What are you on about, Nick?

408
00:28:04,080 --> 00:28:08,358
Don't get your knickers in a twist, but we
made mistakes and ran up some losses.

409
00:28:08,440 --> 00:28:10,829
l went out on a limb
to get back the position.

410
00:28:10,920 --> 00:28:12,751
How big were the losses?

411
00:28:13,920 --> 00:28:16,354
- lt's about a million.
- A million quid?!

412
00:28:17,120 --> 00:28:19,111
For God's sake, Nick!

413
00:28:20,320 --> 00:28:23,471
No, it's all right. lt paid off.
l squared it up.

414
00:28:24,000 --> 00:28:25,991
l had to do it to protect the guys.

415
00:28:28,240 --> 00:28:30,754
Promise me that you'll
never do that again.

416
00:28:30,840 --> 00:28:33,400
- lt's not worth it, Nick.
- l promise.

417
00:28:35,200 --> 00:28:37,191
You will give me a heart attack.

418
00:28:38,400 --> 00:28:39,992
(they laugh)

419
00:28:42,000 --> 00:28:44,753
- Merry Christmas.
- Merry Christmas.

420
00:28:45,760 --> 00:28:47,751
(cheering)

421
00:28:52,560 --> 00:28:54,551
Fuck off!

422
00:28:56,640 --> 00:29:01,316
l really meant it. l was the number one
trader, and as the new year came in...

423
00:29:01,400 --> 00:29:04,756
..l was determined to kick
my addiction to the eights account.

424
00:29:04,840 --> 00:29:06,717
What will the market do? Long-term?

425
00:29:06,800 --> 00:29:09,473
No one thinks long-term,
they think nanoseconds!

426
00:29:09,560 --> 00:29:12,233
- Long-term's tomorrow morning.
- Tomorrow, then.

427
00:29:12,320 --> 00:29:16,074
- That would be telling.
- Leeson speaks, the market moves!

428
00:29:16,160 --> 00:29:18,151
You said it, mate.

429
00:29:19,440 --> 00:29:20,395
Pierre.

430
00:29:20,480 --> 00:29:24,792
l want to sell the 220 call options
and buy the 200 calls in December.

431
00:29:24,880 --> 00:29:27,917
l've got an offer of .1 38 for size.

432
00:29:28,000 --> 00:29:29,877
Can you do better?

433
00:29:29,960 --> 00:29:31,598
l'll get back to you.

434
00:29:31,680 --> 00:29:34,274
Quick as you can, Nick.
l have to move fast.

435
00:29:35,000 --> 00:29:36,991
Oui, oui, je suis toujours la.

436
00:29:38,240 --> 00:29:40,959
What the hell is he on about,
.1 38 for size?

437
00:29:41,040 --> 00:29:44,316
The market in 220 calls is down.
He wants to cut his losses.

438
00:29:44,400 --> 00:29:47,073
- Yeah, but why .1 38?
- lt's a ratio.

439
00:29:47,160 --> 00:29:49,435
The 200 calls are trading at 1 ,400.

440
00:29:49,520 --> 00:29:53,399
Divide 200 by 1 ,400, you get .1 43.

441
00:29:53,480 --> 00:29:55,869
All right. But not .1 38.

442
00:29:56,400 --> 00:30:00,313
Unless someone's offered him a discount.
Probably Societe Generale.

443
00:30:00,400 --> 00:30:03,153
We can't let those wankers
get our biggest client.

444
00:30:03,240 --> 00:30:05,708
- What are you gonna do?
- Just have to leg it.

445
00:30:05,800 --> 00:30:09,349
Buy the contracts from Pierre
and sell them when the market rises?

446
00:30:09,440 --> 00:30:12,432
l thought we were not supposed
to trade for the bank.

447
00:30:12,520 --> 00:30:14,476
Pierre? l can do it. What's the exact size?

448
00:30:14,560 --> 00:30:17,279
6,500? All right, leave it with me.
No problem.

449
00:30:18,000 --> 00:30:21,117
What if the market doesn't rise, uh?
What if it falls?

450
00:30:21,200 --> 00:30:24,590
l've gambled and won before.
l can gamble and win again.

451
00:30:24,680 --> 00:30:28,309
Balls of steel, me old mateys,
and you'd better believe it.

452
00:30:39,200 --> 00:30:42,192
Bonnie, l need you to
reopen the eights account.

453
00:30:43,200 --> 00:30:45,156
We got caned on
Beaumarchais' contracts.

454
00:30:45,240 --> 00:30:48,516
Now the bastard's gone back
to Societe Generale.

455
00:30:48,600 --> 00:30:52,878
Fax Brenda Granger in London. Ask her
for funds to cover the margin payments.

456
00:30:52,960 --> 00:30:54,951
Tell her it's for client positions.

457
00:30:55,040 --> 00:30:56,917
- (internal phone)
- Hello?

458
00:30:57,000 --> 00:30:59,116
lt's Simon.
Can you come into my office?

459
00:30:59,200 --> 00:31:00,679
Right away.

460
00:31:00,760 --> 00:31:04,912
Christ, l'd been rumbled!
The only surprise was it'd taken so long.

461
00:31:05,000 --> 00:31:08,072
What was l gonna tell Lisa?
She'd bloody murder me.

462
00:31:08,160 --> 00:31:10,151
- (knock on door)
- Come in.

463
00:31:16,000 --> 00:31:17,752
Congratulations, Nick.

464
00:31:17,840 --> 00:31:21,230
The '93 bonuses are in,
and you're down for 1 35 grand.

465
00:31:22,560 --> 00:31:24,790
1 35? That's fantastic!

466
00:31:24,880 --> 00:31:30,591
Your little operation generated profits of
over 10 million last year. You're a star!

467
00:31:32,000 --> 00:31:35,788
ln fact, your figures are so high
they're going to check up on you.

468
00:31:35,880 --> 00:31:37,757
Check up on me?

469
00:31:37,840 --> 00:31:40,798
They're sending Ash Lewis out
for the audit.

470
00:31:42,160 --> 00:31:44,958
Don't worry. lt's purely routine.

471
00:31:45,040 --> 00:31:46,996
Ash Lewis?

472
00:31:47,080 --> 00:31:49,833
She's meant to be
a right ball-breaker, isn't she?

473
00:31:57,440 --> 00:31:59,431
That's our booth.

474
00:32:01,400 --> 00:32:03,197
Filled! You paid 250.

475
00:32:03,280 --> 00:32:05,111
Hi, Nick.

476
00:32:05,200 --> 00:32:07,191
Ron Baker and Ash Lewis.

477
00:32:07,280 --> 00:32:09,669
Ron is head of Derivatives Trading
in London.

478
00:32:09,760 --> 00:32:11,796
Which l guess makes me your boss, Nick.

479
00:32:11,880 --> 00:32:14,713
- How do you, Mr Leeson?
- Very well, thank you.

480
00:32:14,800 --> 00:32:16,870
OK. Let's see the action!

481
00:32:18,960 --> 00:32:20,109
Henry!

482
00:32:20,200 --> 00:32:23,590
(Baker) Who's doing all the business?
We're the biggest, right?

483
00:32:23,680 --> 00:32:26,592
We do a lot of arbitrage,
so we do have a high volume.

484
00:32:26,680 --> 00:32:29,672
We signal orders in to George
in the pit - this is Henry -

485
00:32:29,760 --> 00:32:34,629
..and at the end of the day the girls in the
office log all the deals on to the computer.

486
00:32:34,720 --> 00:32:39,111
(Lewis) You manage the trading floor
and the settlements office, is that right?

487
00:32:39,200 --> 00:32:41,031
Yes, yes.

488
00:32:41,120 --> 00:32:45,113
That's a little unusual. Whatever
happened to checks and balances?

489
00:32:45,200 --> 00:32:49,113
- That's something we need to talk about.
- l'll be here for three weeks.

490
00:32:49,200 --> 00:32:53,079
This is going to be a thoroughly
comprehensive audit. No stone unturned.

491
00:32:53,160 --> 00:32:57,711
Absolutely. Anything l can do to help,
any stone needs turning, let me know.

492
00:32:57,800 --> 00:32:59,677
Are we filled? Good man, Henry.

493
00:32:59,760 --> 00:33:01,557
Nice to see you, Simon.

494
00:33:06,360 --> 00:33:08,555
Dad's seen this flat in Blackheath.

495
00:33:08,640 --> 00:33:11,916
Needs a bit of work, but him
and my granddad can fix it up.

496
00:33:12,000 --> 00:33:15,310
Think of it like an insurance policy
in case you get sacked,...

497
00:33:15,400 --> 00:33:19,188
..have to go back to England
and work as a plasterer! (laughs)

498
00:33:20,960 --> 00:33:23,030
What's up with you, misery-guts?

499
00:33:24,440 --> 00:33:28,353
What would you do, Lise?
What would you do if l did get the elbow?

500
00:33:28,440 --> 00:33:31,318
You've just been given
a ruddy great big bonus.

501
00:33:31,400 --> 00:33:35,359
But what if it all went wrong? What if
l'm not as clever as everyone thinks?

502
00:33:35,440 --> 00:33:37,271
Oh, of course you are!

503
00:33:38,000 --> 00:33:41,151
Anyway, it's you l love.
l don't give a toss about the money.

504
00:33:41,240 --> 00:33:45,950
lf it was up to me we'd jack it all in now,
go back to England and start a family.

505
00:33:47,000 --> 00:33:49,070
You're doing brilliantly, Nick.

506
00:33:50,120 --> 00:33:51,997
You're a bloody star.

507
00:34:04,880 --> 00:34:06,791
- Nick!
- (softly) Fuck!

508
00:34:06,880 --> 00:34:08,313
Simon!

509
00:34:08,400 --> 00:34:12,313
- You're looking disgustingly chirpy.
- Haven't you heard? Panic over.

510
00:34:12,400 --> 00:34:15,551
- Ash has been called back to London.
- You're kidding. Why?

511
00:34:15,640 --> 00:34:19,679
Office politics. Some turf battle
between Futures and Securities.

512
00:34:19,760 --> 00:34:24,276
- And what about the audit?
- They'll send Mark Taylor and Chris Carr.

513
00:34:24,360 --> 00:34:27,158
Compared to Ash
they're a couple of pussies.

514
00:34:27,240 --> 00:34:32,553
Pity. l was rather looking forward to
seeing the dreaded Ash Lewis in action!

515
00:34:35,080 --> 00:34:37,071
(whispers) Yes!

516
00:34:40,120 --> 00:34:42,076
No, l'm just leaving now.

517
00:34:42,160 --> 00:34:45,835
l'm gonna jump in the shower.
lf you get home first, put the oven on.

518
00:34:45,920 --> 00:34:49,629
- All right, sweetheart. l'll see you then.
- Bye, darling.

519
00:34:53,080 --> 00:34:55,071
(cackles)

520
00:34:55,800 --> 00:34:58,314
- Get in, you bastard!
- What the fuck is that?

521
00:34:58,400 --> 00:35:02,188
Sex on wheels.
lt's a Porsche, moron! Get in!

522
00:35:05,480 --> 00:35:07,436
l'll tell you what it is.

523
00:35:07,520 --> 00:35:09,511
lt's disgustin'.

524
00:35:10,000 --> 00:35:13,037
l'll tell you what it is.
lt's a great big hard-on!

525
00:35:14,600 --> 00:35:17,239
Got to think of something
to do with my bonus.

526
00:35:17,320 --> 00:35:19,914
You keep your eyes on the road,
you flash git!

527
00:35:21,600 --> 00:35:24,034
# Jerry Lee Lewis: ''Great Balls Of Fire''

528
00:35:25,600 --> 00:35:27,636
Whoo!

529
00:35:27,720 --> 00:35:30,518
- lt's a fuckin' one-way street, George.
- Whoops!

530
00:35:33,160 --> 00:35:36,948
Goodness, gracious, great balls of steel!

531
00:35:43,320 --> 00:35:46,676
- Whoo!
- Fuckin' George!

532
00:35:52,480 --> 00:35:54,710
Shit! There's that Reuters journalist.

533
00:35:54,800 --> 00:35:56,711
Nick! Nick!

534
00:35:56,800 --> 00:35:59,792
He's been bugging me
for weeks for an interview.

535
00:36:00,920 --> 00:36:02,911
- Hey, Nick!
- All right, mate?

536
00:36:05,600 --> 00:36:07,238
Nick, my man. What'll you have?

537
00:36:07,320 --> 00:36:10,835
Oh, a beer, please. You know
George Seow, one of my dealers?

538
00:36:10,920 --> 00:36:13,275
This is Danny
from lntercontinental Trading.

539
00:36:13,360 --> 00:36:17,512
- Just been sent from the London office.
- Nice to meet you. Heard a lot about you.

540
00:36:17,600 --> 00:36:21,229
l hear Barings have almost cornered
the market here, thanks to you.

541
00:36:21,320 --> 00:36:23,754
The rumours have been
greatly exaggerated.

542
00:36:23,840 --> 00:36:25,671
Don't be so modest.

543
00:36:25,760 --> 00:36:30,709
He's king of the exchange! Barings got an
award for all the business he's generated.

544
00:36:30,800 --> 00:36:32,950
- Do you want a beer?
- l'd love a beer.

545
00:36:35,680 --> 00:36:37,193
Aagghh!

546
00:36:38,080 --> 00:36:40,071
(canned laughter)

547
00:36:46,160 --> 00:36:48,151
(shouting, laughter)

548
00:36:49,680 --> 00:36:51,671
(music, drunken shouting)

549
00:36:54,040 --> 00:36:56,235
(Nick) Watch the Drambuie settle.

550
00:36:59,640 --> 00:37:01,756
And it's called depth charge.

551
00:37:01,840 --> 00:37:04,752
lt's guaranteed to blow
your fuckin' head off.

552
00:37:06,160 --> 00:37:08,116
Are you ready?

553
00:37:08,200 --> 00:37:10,350
Let's do it. Let's have it.

554
00:37:10,440 --> 00:37:11,759
One!

555
00:37:11,840 --> 00:37:13,637
And two!

556
00:37:13,720 --> 00:37:15,472
And three!

557
00:37:15,560 --> 00:37:17,551
- Bottoms up!
- Bottoms up!

558
00:37:30,720 --> 00:37:33,473
Hey! Pretty women!
What are you waiting for?

559
00:37:33,560 --> 00:37:35,152
Come on!

560
00:37:36,000 --> 00:37:37,831
- Come on!
- Tough shit, George.

561
00:37:37,920 --> 00:37:40,309
Your charm's just not working tonight.

562
00:37:40,400 --> 00:37:42,470
Stuck-up bitches!

563
00:37:42,560 --> 00:37:47,839
- l bet they're Singapore air hostesses.
- Flight lieutenants, if you don't mind!

564
00:37:47,920 --> 00:37:49,911
Chocks away!

565
00:37:50,720 --> 00:37:52,711
Flight lieutenants...!

566
00:37:55,360 --> 00:38:00,275
Help 'em to decide if they wanna come in
or if they don't wanna come in.

567
00:38:00,360 --> 00:38:02,430
Let's give 'em a hand and moon 'em!

568
00:38:04,360 --> 00:38:07,352
That should help 'em decide.
Come on, don't be shy!

569
00:38:07,440 --> 00:38:09,590
Your mother wasn't!

570
00:38:09,680 --> 00:38:11,557
l love this man.

571
00:38:11,640 --> 00:38:13,392
- On three?
- lt worked before.

572
00:38:13,480 --> 00:38:15,232
lt could work again. One...

573
00:38:16,680 --> 00:38:18,557
Two! Three!

574
00:38:18,640 --> 00:38:19,834
Bottoms up!

575
00:38:23,840 --> 00:38:25,592
That is disgusting!

576
00:38:25,680 --> 00:38:27,636
Whoo!

577
00:38:27,720 --> 00:38:29,995
(Danny) What'll it be, you old bastard?

578
00:38:30,080 --> 00:38:32,833
Absolutely brilliant, Nick!
Drinks are on me.

579
00:38:32,920 --> 00:38:35,593
Enough depth charges
to sink a battleship!

580
00:38:40,880 --> 00:38:42,950
- Fuck, what time is it?
- l don't know.

581
00:38:43,040 --> 00:38:45,474
Got to phone Lisa.

582
00:38:53,240 --> 00:38:55,356
Oh, you've got to be jokin'!

583
00:38:55,440 --> 00:38:57,476
No laughing matter.

584
00:38:57,560 --> 00:39:01,872
Outraging a lady's modesty...
very serious crime in Singapore.

585
00:39:06,280 --> 00:39:09,875
News of my disgrace reached London.
At the highest level.

586
00:39:11,400 --> 00:39:15,279
lt's slightly embarrassing,
but one of our traders got drunk...

587
00:39:15,360 --> 00:39:17,078
..and pulled a moon.

588
00:39:17,160 --> 00:39:19,037
What did you say?

589
00:39:19,120 --> 00:39:20,792
He exposed his bottom.

590
00:39:20,880 --> 00:39:22,438
(laughter)

591
00:39:22,520 --> 00:39:25,114
- Why?
- Playing silly buggers, l expect.

592
00:39:25,200 --> 00:39:28,749
Unfortunately, the law over there
takes rather a dim view.

593
00:39:28,840 --> 00:39:30,751
Maybe we should sack him.

594
00:39:30,840 --> 00:39:34,913
Sacking him would be...
awkward, to say the least.

595
00:39:35,000 --> 00:39:39,198
He generates a significant amount
of our profits in Southeast Asia.

596
00:39:39,280 --> 00:39:43,319
l, er... ought to mention we're getting
stick from the Bank of England...

597
00:39:43,400 --> 00:39:45,277
..about our funding over there.

598
00:39:45,360 --> 00:39:49,717
Technically we're in breach of regulations
on the ratio of lending to capital.

599
00:39:49,800 --> 00:39:53,315
Would you like me to have
a quiet word in their ear?

600
00:39:53,400 --> 00:39:55,356
Oh, we're not quite there yet.

601
00:39:55,440 --> 00:39:59,115
When l spoke to Andy Dixon
at the Bank, he said the matter was...

602
00:39:59,200 --> 00:40:02,272
..''buried reasonably deep in his in-tray''.

603
00:40:02,360 --> 00:40:04,112
Just flagging a concern.

604
00:40:04,200 --> 00:40:07,112
Quite right. lt's something
we should keep an eye on.

605
00:40:07,200 --> 00:40:09,236
Well... is that it? Any other business?

606
00:40:09,320 --> 00:40:13,871
Well, what about this chap Leeson?
He of the exhibitionist tendencies.

607
00:40:14,600 --> 00:40:18,673
l suppose it's something we should
leave to the Singapore authorities.

608
00:40:18,760 --> 00:40:22,070
l have to say... l'm inclined to agree.

609
00:40:27,640 --> 00:40:30,279
So, it was the profits that saved me.

610
00:40:30,360 --> 00:40:32,271
lf they only knew!

611
00:40:34,960 --> 00:40:35,915
Nick!

612
00:40:36,000 --> 00:40:38,798
That guy from Reuters again.
The second time today.

613
00:40:38,880 --> 00:40:40,871
Tell him l've...

614
00:40:40,960 --> 00:40:42,951
Oh, fuck it! Gimme the phone.

615
00:40:44,480 --> 00:40:46,869
Print me up a balance
on the eights account.

616
00:40:46,960 --> 00:40:48,154
Hi, Loy.

617
00:40:48,240 --> 00:40:50,754
Nick! You're a hard man to pin down.

618
00:40:50,840 --> 00:40:53,115
You know how it is.
What can l do you for?

619
00:40:53,200 --> 00:40:56,397
- Quite a position you've been buying.
- We're happy.

620
00:40:56,480 --> 00:40:58,789
l don't know how the client
wants to play it.

621
00:40:58,880 --> 00:41:02,668
Who is this mystery client, Nick?
He must have rather large balls.

622
00:41:02,760 --> 00:41:06,275
l'm sorry, mate.
Client confidentiality and all that.

623
00:41:06,360 --> 00:41:08,351
ls it Pierre Beaumarchais?

624
00:41:10,080 --> 00:41:13,789
Sorry, Loy, l... gotta go.
l'll speak to you later.

625
00:41:13,880 --> 00:41:15,871
Speak to you some other time.

626
00:41:17,400 --> 00:41:21,029
Jesus Christ, Bonnie. lt's 7.78 billion yen!

627
00:41:21,120 --> 00:41:25,159
- Do you want the dollar amount? lt's...
- Yeah, yeah, $77.8 million.

628
00:41:25,240 --> 00:41:27,515
Book me the following notional trade.

629
00:41:27,600 --> 00:41:32,913
Selling 1 ,000 December 21 ,500
put options at a price of... 7778.

630
00:41:33,000 --> 00:41:36,834
Then print me a new report after that
entry so it shows 7.78 billion yen...

631
00:41:36,920 --> 00:41:40,037
- ..as if it was owing to us from SlMEX.
- Sure, Nick.

632
00:41:40,600 --> 00:41:43,717
Then fax Brenda Granger in London,
asking for more funds.

633
00:41:43,800 --> 00:41:46,997
Say we've had a large margin call
on our client positions.

634
00:41:47,080 --> 00:41:48,399
How much?

635
00:41:48,480 --> 00:41:50,436
A million.

636
00:41:50,520 --> 00:41:52,033
Make it two.

637
00:41:55,040 --> 00:41:57,031
(phone rings)

638
00:42:00,400 --> 00:42:02,391
- Nick!
- Mm?

639
00:42:03,640 --> 00:42:05,631
Nick, it's the phone.

640
00:42:11,400 --> 00:42:14,597
- Hello?
- (Baker) l'm not disturbing you, am l?

641
00:42:14,680 --> 00:42:16,159
lt's 2am.

642
00:42:16,240 --> 00:42:18,310
Oh, Christ. Sorry, mate. Had no idea.

643
00:42:18,400 --> 00:42:22,712
The old farts are getting nervous. They
want you to unwind the position a little.

644
00:42:22,800 --> 00:42:27,078
That's easier said than done. Don't want
to send the wrong signal to the market.

645
00:42:27,160 --> 00:42:28,115
Yeah, yeah.

646
00:42:28,200 --> 00:42:32,478
Second, we need another 2 million profit
by next month to secure our bonuses.

647
00:42:32,560 --> 00:42:36,155
Two million? Ron, what planet
do you live on, mate?

648
00:42:36,240 --> 00:42:38,879
One minute you want me
to unwind the positions...

649
00:42:38,960 --> 00:42:40,916
Failure is not an option, mate.

650
00:42:41,000 --> 00:42:44,037
See you at the junket in London
in three weeks' time.

651
00:42:49,360 --> 00:42:50,315
2 million?

652
00:42:50,400 --> 00:42:53,472
Who do they think l am, George Soros?

653
00:42:56,480 --> 00:43:00,792
We were close to the end of another year
and l was deeper in the shit than ever.

654
00:43:00,880 --> 00:43:04,873
Barings wanted me to speak at their
annual group conference in London.

655
00:43:04,960 --> 00:43:09,078
l was their star trader, and they wanted
to know the secrets of my success.

656
00:43:09,160 --> 00:43:11,151
lt didn't bear thinking about.

657
00:43:11,240 --> 00:43:13,435
(TV on low)

658
00:43:13,520 --> 00:43:16,273
- ls Nan staying with Auntie Karen?
- Yeah.

659
00:43:16,360 --> 00:43:19,158
- lt's the best place she could be.
- Aww, poor thing.

660
00:43:19,240 --> 00:43:20,753
(phone rings)

661
00:43:20,840 --> 00:43:23,035
- Has she been crying?
- Mm.

662
00:43:23,120 --> 00:43:24,792
Has she?

663
00:43:25,600 --> 00:43:27,192
Hello?

664
00:43:27,960 --> 00:43:30,030
Nick! lt's for you.

665
00:43:30,120 --> 00:43:32,111
Ron Baker.

666
00:43:38,800 --> 00:43:42,076
Ron! Can't believe you
tracked me down already.

667
00:43:42,160 --> 00:43:46,312
Listen, with this conference you'll be
away from the trading floor a long time.

668
00:43:46,400 --> 00:43:49,233
l had to come back a week early
for this funeral.

669
00:43:49,320 --> 00:43:53,279
- l told you, Lisa's granddad passed away.
- l'm sorry about that, mate,...

670
00:43:53,360 --> 00:43:57,114
..but l'm fighting for your bonus.
You need to keep up those profits.

671
00:43:57,200 --> 00:44:00,317
- l couldn't miss this funeral.
- No one's asking you to!

672
00:44:00,400 --> 00:44:04,552
l'll issue you a pass so you can come in
on Sunday and trade through the night.

673
00:44:04,640 --> 00:44:06,596
You won't miss a thing!

674
00:44:06,680 --> 00:44:08,830
Get out the fuckin' way!

675
00:44:10,480 --> 00:44:13,950
lf he's working this hard
he's going to need his food.

676
00:44:14,040 --> 00:44:17,316
He wants me to go into the office
on Sunday night and trade.

677
00:44:17,400 --> 00:44:19,072
Well... no!

678
00:44:19,160 --> 00:44:22,755
That's completely out of order.
Let someone else make the profits!

679
00:44:22,840 --> 00:44:25,070
She's right, Nick. You're not a machine.

680
00:44:25,160 --> 00:44:28,709
lt's bonus time. lf l don't deliver,
then everybody loses out.

681
00:44:28,800 --> 00:44:33,237
lt's not fair, Nick. You carry on at this rate,
you're gonna be in a right old state.

682
00:44:33,320 --> 00:44:34,958
lt's gonna be your funeral next.

683
00:44:35,040 --> 00:44:38,112
For as much as it hath
pleased almighty God...

684
00:44:38,200 --> 00:44:40,760
..of his great mercy to take unto himself...

685
00:44:40,840 --> 00:44:43,559
..the soul of our dear brother
here departed,...

686
00:44:43,640 --> 00:44:46,598
..we therefore commit
his body to the ground.

687
00:44:47,920 --> 00:44:50,718
Earth to earth, ashes to ashes,...

688
00:44:51,680 --> 00:44:53,511
..dust to dust.

689
00:44:56,520 --> 00:44:59,956
Good to see you, son.
Sorry occasion, but there you go.

690
00:45:00,040 --> 00:45:02,952
- He had a good innings.
- That's the main thing.

691
00:45:03,760 --> 00:45:05,671
So how's it going over there?

692
00:45:05,760 --> 00:45:07,990
- Can't complain.
- We're all proud of you.

693
00:45:08,080 --> 00:45:10,310
- What you've achieved.
- lt's no big deal.

694
00:45:10,400 --> 00:45:12,231
Don't be so bloody modest!

695
00:45:12,320 --> 00:45:14,515
You a plasterer's son!

696
00:45:14,600 --> 00:45:17,637
l just wish your mum
could have been here to see it.

697
00:45:19,480 --> 00:45:21,471
So do l.

698
00:45:22,000 --> 00:45:24,878
(voice breaks)
l'll try not to let you all down, Dad.

699
00:45:24,960 --> 00:45:28,111
- What did you say?
- lt's OK, it's just jet lag.

700
00:45:28,200 --> 00:45:30,191
Don't pay any attention to me.

701
00:45:32,080 --> 00:45:33,752
(lift pings)

702
00:45:34,920 --> 00:45:36,876
l felt sick going into the office,...

703
00:45:36,960 --> 00:45:39,952
..seeing all the people
l'd been avoiding for months.

704
00:45:40,040 --> 00:45:45,068
lt was one thing to con people over the
phone, quite another to do it to their face.

705
00:45:45,160 --> 00:45:47,151
Nick? That's you, isn't it?

706
00:45:48,120 --> 00:45:50,554
Nick Leeson? l heard you were coming
in.

707
00:45:51,600 --> 00:45:54,831
You haven't the vaguest idea
who l am, have you?

708
00:45:55,480 --> 00:45:56,708
Brenda?

709
00:45:56,800 --> 00:46:01,555
- Of course. l'm sorry. How are you?
- So l finally get to put a face to the voice!

710
00:46:01,640 --> 00:46:05,428
- My God, you are so young!
- Well, ageing rapidly, l'm afraid.

711
00:46:05,520 --> 00:46:09,877
Can you come into my office? l really do
need to talk to you about the figures.

712
00:46:09,960 --> 00:46:12,394
l'm meeting Peter Norris in three minutes.

713
00:46:12,480 --> 00:46:14,675
Oh. Well, do come in right after, OK?

714
00:46:14,760 --> 00:46:17,558
Nobody out there can answer
our questions but you.

715
00:46:17,640 --> 00:46:20,837
And they just asked for
another ton of funding.

716
00:46:20,920 --> 00:46:22,911
- All right. This one?
- Yeah.

717
00:46:24,760 --> 00:46:26,716
Brenda was my cash lifeline.

718
00:46:26,800 --> 00:46:30,156
She was the last person l wanted
asking awkward questions.

719
00:46:31,440 --> 00:46:33,908
But first l had to deal with Peter Norris.

720
00:46:34,000 --> 00:46:37,470
He's such a red-hot trader
l'm having him come in overnight!

721
00:46:37,560 --> 00:46:39,198
Are you really?

722
00:46:39,280 --> 00:46:43,717
You can't keep Nick away from the floor.
He's the key man in Singapore.

723
00:46:43,800 --> 00:46:46,314
Sounds like you're the key man in Asia.

724
00:46:46,400 --> 00:46:49,039
He's insane! You should see
how he takes that market on.

725
00:46:49,120 --> 00:46:51,918
- Are you enjoying yourself?
- Yes, it's all right.

726
00:46:52,000 --> 00:46:53,991
(both) ''All right''?

727
00:46:55,040 --> 00:46:56,951
(they laugh)

728
00:46:57,040 --> 00:47:02,114
Now, we need to talk about merging the
sales areas in Asia. Nick has some views.

729
00:47:02,200 --> 00:47:05,590
lf we can replicate his success
in Hong Kong and Tokyo...

730
00:47:06,560 --> 00:47:08,516
What do you think, Nick?

731
00:47:08,600 --> 00:47:10,750
lt does make a lot of sense to merge.

732
00:47:11,600 --> 00:47:14,319
There would need to be
controls, of course,...

733
00:47:14,400 --> 00:47:19,997
..but the trading books can be used to
supplement a customer's requirements...

734
00:47:20,080 --> 00:47:22,389
..and increase information flows.

735
00:47:22,480 --> 00:47:24,516
Synergetically.

736
00:47:24,600 --> 00:47:26,431
Exactly. Synergy.

737
00:47:26,520 --> 00:47:28,636
So you see, Peter, Nick agrees.

738
00:47:28,720 --> 00:47:32,349
And he's been very successful
with his customers. They love him!

739
00:47:33,200 --> 00:47:35,919
Yes, excellent.
Well, keep up the good work,...

740
00:47:36,000 --> 00:47:39,072
..and Ron, you sort out
what you want with this merger.

741
00:47:39,160 --> 00:47:41,230
Now, gentlemen, l really have to...

742
00:47:41,320 --> 00:47:44,073
- Good to meet you.
- Nice to meet you. Cheers.

743
00:47:46,400 --> 00:47:49,597
l think that went well.
He seemed to go for the merger idea.

744
00:47:49,680 --> 00:47:53,719
- Oh, he did. He really went for it!
- This'll be good for you too, Nick.

745
00:47:53,800 --> 00:47:57,759
They'll give you some kind of
fancy new title! (chuckles)

746
00:47:57,840 --> 00:47:59,831
Uh... Nick!

747
00:48:00,720 --> 00:48:02,312
Nick!

748
00:48:02,400 --> 00:48:04,391
Ron!

749
00:48:10,000 --> 00:48:11,513
Being good...

750
00:48:11,600 --> 00:48:13,989
..is not good enough!

751
00:48:15,240 --> 00:48:20,951
Everyone must be connected to
our strategy, or we will find you...

752
00:48:21,040 --> 00:48:23,110
..and weed you out!

753
00:48:25,160 --> 00:48:28,630
lnformation arbitrage is our business.

754
00:48:28,720 --> 00:48:32,838
lf you don't know what an
information curve is, then find out!

755
00:48:33,480 --> 00:48:36,870
Position yourself in an information curve.

756
00:48:37,640 --> 00:48:39,870
Dominate the curve!

757
00:48:39,960 --> 00:48:44,670
Nick Leeson, who most of you know
and all of you have heard of,...

758
00:48:44,760 --> 00:48:46,955
..runs our operation in Singapore,...

759
00:48:47,040 --> 00:48:49,713
..which l want all of you to try to emulate.

760
00:48:50,640 --> 00:48:53,837
Now, you'll hear later from Nick
about how he does it,...

761
00:48:53,920 --> 00:48:57,276
..but l just want to
drive home to you guys...

762
00:48:57,360 --> 00:49:00,477
..that if you could all think about Nick...

763
00:49:00,560 --> 00:49:04,712
..and perhaps come up with ideas
to follow his footsteps,...

764
00:49:04,800 --> 00:49:07,314
..Barings will become...

765
00:49:07,400 --> 00:49:12,793
..one of the most successful operations
in the derivatives business.

766
00:49:12,880 --> 00:49:14,871
(retches)

767
00:49:17,720 --> 00:49:19,836
Oh, fuck!

768
00:49:20,320 --> 00:49:24,313
Oh, we are gonna make so much money!

769
00:49:25,520 --> 00:49:27,590
But more to the point,...

770
00:49:27,680 --> 00:49:29,989
..you are gonna make...

771
00:49:30,080 --> 00:49:31,149
..so...

772
00:49:31,240 --> 00:49:32,389
..much...

773
00:49:32,480 --> 00:49:33,629
..money.

774
00:49:54,400 --> 00:49:56,391
Oh, Nick!

775
00:49:57,280 --> 00:49:59,191
Nick... wake up.

776
00:49:59,280 --> 00:50:02,033
- Lisa...
- We're meant to be going to the dinner!

777
00:50:02,120 --> 00:50:05,078
l can't. l can't face it.
l can't take it any more.

778
00:50:05,160 --> 00:50:08,038
l'm not going back after Christmas.
You can't make me.

779
00:50:08,120 --> 00:50:11,237
What?! You're sitting next to
Peter Norris in the seat of honour!

780
00:50:11,320 --> 00:50:14,039
Don't tell me you missed
your presentation too.

781
00:50:14,120 --> 00:50:17,192
- l've been drinkin'.
- l never would have guessed(!)

782
00:50:17,280 --> 00:50:20,397
l think it's downright rude.
You can't let everybody down.

783
00:50:20,480 --> 00:50:22,630
You don't understand, Lisa.

784
00:50:22,720 --> 00:50:26,110
l'm sitting on a fuckin' volcano.
l can't go back!

785
00:50:26,200 --> 00:50:28,395
And what about your bonus?

786
00:50:28,480 --> 00:50:30,948
Now, stop babblin'
and get yourself dressed!

787
00:50:31,040 --> 00:50:33,918
l'll give you volcano, Nick Leeson -
right up your bum!

788
00:50:34,000 --> 00:50:35,353
Lisa... oi!

789
00:50:35,440 --> 00:50:37,396
ln you go! You stink!

790
00:50:37,480 --> 00:50:40,358
- Oh, Lisa...
- (cackles)

791
00:50:43,040 --> 00:50:45,031
You bitch!

792
00:50:46,200 --> 00:50:50,079
- l'm gonna kill you now!
- Look at you! What a disgusting sight!

793
00:50:51,080 --> 00:50:53,640
Aagh, no, you're gonna
get me all wet, Nick!

794
00:50:53,720 --> 00:50:55,711
Oh!

795
00:50:59,240 --> 00:51:01,231
(Lisa laughs)

796
00:51:01,680 --> 00:51:04,558
Nick. You've got to get dressed. Stop.

797
00:51:06,280 --> 00:51:08,510
You've got to get dressed! (laughs)

798
00:51:15,120 --> 00:51:17,554
Promise me you'll always love me, Lisa.

799
00:51:18,400 --> 00:51:21,119
That whatever happens,
you'll always love me.

800
00:51:21,200 --> 00:51:23,395
Oh, of course l will!

801
00:51:23,480 --> 00:51:25,471
You're my man, aren't you?

802
00:51:33,360 --> 00:51:37,956
lt was crazy going back. l couldn't hope
to survive the end-of-year audit.

803
00:51:38,040 --> 00:51:41,112
There was that little matter
of the 7.78 billion yen...

804
00:51:41,200 --> 00:51:44,875
..which l'd fabricated to plug
the hole in the five eights account.

805
00:51:44,960 --> 00:51:47,679
l should have told Lisa
when l had the chance,...

806
00:51:47,760 --> 00:51:49,671
..but this voice kept telling me...

807
00:51:49,760 --> 00:51:53,036
..l'd traded out of losses before -
l could trade out of them again.

808
00:51:54,440 --> 00:51:56,795
What's this letter all about?

809
00:51:59,000 --> 00:52:00,797
Well, it's from SlMEX.

810
00:52:00,880 --> 00:52:04,077
Yes, l know it's from SlMEX.
lt came while you were away.

811
00:52:04,160 --> 00:52:07,391
''lt appears that you have
financed the trading positions...

812
00:52:07,480 --> 00:52:09,436
..held by sub-account 88888.''

813
00:52:09,520 --> 00:52:12,717
''lf this is the case
you have violated SlMEX Rule 822,...

814
00:52:12,800 --> 00:52:17,078
..which bans members from financing
the trading margins of their customers.''

815
00:52:17,160 --> 00:52:20,436
They're just banging on about
our intra-day funding limits.

816
00:52:20,520 --> 00:52:22,590
Well, what is sub-account 88888 anyway?

817
00:52:22,680 --> 00:52:26,036
lt's a customer account.
We have umpteen trading accounts.

818
00:52:26,120 --> 00:52:28,190
l'd have to look into it.

819
00:52:28,280 --> 00:52:31,829
We're the number one trader,
and they're tying us up in red tape.

820
00:52:31,920 --> 00:52:34,559
Anyone would think
they didn't want us to trade.

821
00:52:34,640 --> 00:52:36,551
Er... l'll draft an answer for you.

822
00:52:36,640 --> 00:52:39,871
Yeah, do that, will you?
Get it on my desk by the morning.

823
00:52:39,960 --> 00:52:42,349
Of course, Simon.

824
00:52:50,440 --> 00:52:52,431
Lisa?

825
00:52:56,840 --> 00:52:58,398
Lisa?

826
00:53:07,480 --> 00:53:09,471
Lisa, what are you doing?

827
00:53:10,760 --> 00:53:12,716
l'm bleeding, Nick!

828
00:53:12,800 --> 00:53:15,030
(siren)

829
00:53:18,920 --> 00:53:21,150
Why didn't you tell me?

830
00:53:21,240 --> 00:53:23,231
Cos l was waiting till l was sure!

831
00:53:24,440 --> 00:53:28,399
- You're not angry with me, are you?
- Of course l'm not angry, my love.

832
00:53:28,480 --> 00:53:31,631
- You want the baby, don't you?
- l really want the baby.

833
00:53:31,720 --> 00:53:34,188
l want lots and lots of babies. All right?

834
00:53:34,280 --> 00:53:35,998
(whimpers) Yeah.

835
00:53:49,880 --> 00:53:52,110
Your wife is OK...

836
00:53:52,200 --> 00:53:54,191
l'm afraid she's lost the baby.

837
00:53:55,600 --> 00:53:57,591
l'm sorry.

838
00:54:03,800 --> 00:54:05,791
(roar of voices from the floor)

839
00:54:13,040 --> 00:54:14,996
That was the turning point.

840
00:54:15,080 --> 00:54:18,311
That was when l decided
l couldn't stand around any longer...

841
00:54:18,400 --> 00:54:21,119
..hoping the market
would move in my favour.

842
00:54:21,200 --> 00:54:22,997
l was gonna have to make it move.

843
00:54:23,960 --> 00:54:26,349
l didn't care how much money it took.

844
00:54:26,440 --> 00:54:28,510
l was gonna go for broke.

845
00:54:30,920 --> 00:54:35,914
The man is single-handedly generating
a fifth of the group's worldwide profits!

846
00:54:36,000 --> 00:54:40,391
l know. But $30 million in margin
payments? For one day's trading?

847
00:54:40,480 --> 00:54:43,711
You don't seem to understand.
The volumes are enormous!

848
00:54:43,800 --> 00:54:46,155
Nick's guy is the biggest
player on SlMEX!

849
00:54:48,680 --> 00:54:50,671
(phone rings)

850
00:54:51,280 --> 00:54:52,838
- Hello?
- Nick.

851
00:54:52,920 --> 00:54:54,876
lt's Brenda.

852
00:54:55,440 --> 00:54:59,274
Listen, buddy. This is putting
a terrible strain on our borrowing.

853
00:54:59,360 --> 00:55:02,193
Tony Hawes is all over me
about your cash calls.

854
00:55:02,280 --> 00:55:05,716
l hear you. But London is
the cash cow for the business here.

855
00:55:05,800 --> 00:55:08,394
We just don't have access
to any other funds.

856
00:55:10,800 --> 00:55:13,997
lf you keep hassling me
l've a good mind to stop trading.

857
00:55:15,440 --> 00:55:17,317
No, no, Nick. lt's OK. Listen...

858
00:55:17,400 --> 00:55:21,188
Just get back to me with
some meaningful figures, OK?

859
00:55:22,040 --> 00:55:24,031
(whispers) Fuck off.

860
00:55:26,360 --> 00:55:28,351
(phone rings)

861
00:55:30,960 --> 00:55:32,393
Hello?

862
00:55:32,480 --> 00:55:36,075
Thank goodness l caught you.
l know Brenda's giving you a hard time...

863
00:55:36,760 --> 00:55:39,832
l don't think any of you understand
how it works out here.

864
00:55:39,920 --> 00:55:42,593
You may be right, mate.
Anyway, consider it sorted.

865
00:55:42,680 --> 00:55:45,717
But you are gonna have to start
reducing these positions.

866
00:55:45,800 --> 00:55:48,758
Well, Ron, l'll see
what l can do, all right?

867
00:55:48,840 --> 00:55:51,229
While l've got you, about your bonus...

868
00:55:51,320 --> 00:55:55,950
The budget's tight. Though you've been
exceptional there's not much to go round.

869
00:55:56,040 --> 00:55:58,031
l thought we had a record year!

870
00:55:58,120 --> 00:56:02,591
Yeah. That said, l've put in a special plea
to Peter and he's agreed to go up to 350.

871
00:56:02,680 --> 00:56:04,398
350? That's ridiculous!

872
00:56:04,480 --> 00:56:07,153
l'm really pushing out
the boat for you, mate.

873
00:56:07,240 --> 00:56:10,516
l'm busting my balls here.
l made us the top house in SlMEX.

874
00:56:10,600 --> 00:56:13,592
We even got that award
for all the business we're doing!

875
00:56:13,680 --> 00:56:15,989
Yeah, l know that, Nick.

876
00:56:16,080 --> 00:56:18,071
Look, l'll see what l can do.

877
00:56:18,160 --> 00:56:20,913
l'll see if it can't start with a four, eh?

878
00:56:21,000 --> 00:56:22,956
(splashing from bathroom)

879
00:56:23,040 --> 00:56:24,951
That was their opening offer.

880
00:56:25,040 --> 00:56:29,113
He'd have thought something was wrong
if l'd accepted it straight away.

881
00:56:29,200 --> 00:56:31,475
Yeah, it's like winning the lottery.

882
00:56:31,560 --> 00:56:33,551
They must think the world of you.

883
00:56:39,240 --> 00:56:41,356
What's the matter, Lisa?

884
00:56:41,440 --> 00:56:44,159
What do you think's
the bloody matter, Nick?

885
00:56:44,240 --> 00:56:46,231
Everything's changed!

886
00:56:47,120 --> 00:56:50,396
l just wanna go home.
Get the hell out of here and go home.

887
00:56:50,480 --> 00:56:53,552
But... you wanted to come back.
What about the bonus?

888
00:56:53,640 --> 00:56:56,393
Well, can't you get the bonus in London?

889
00:56:56,480 --> 00:56:58,948
Please, Nick! l wanna get on with my life.

890
00:56:59,040 --> 00:57:02,555
l wanna start a family.
l'm going stir-crazy here all on my own!

891
00:57:02,640 --> 00:57:07,794
Calm down. Look, l just need a bit more
time to sort things out, turn things around.

892
00:57:07,880 --> 00:57:12,476
No! You're up at dawn and then you come
back at night and collapse into bed...

893
00:57:12,560 --> 00:57:15,870
How am l meant to get pregnant again
if we never make love?

894
00:57:15,960 --> 00:57:18,872
l know. But this could set us up for life!

895
00:57:20,000 --> 00:57:24,676
- When's bonus day?
- 24th of February. Just five weeks to go.

896
00:57:24,760 --> 00:57:27,320
Right, we're gonna leave on the 25th.

897
00:57:27,400 --> 00:57:30,676
l mean it. l'm calling
the furniture removers tomorrow.

898
00:57:30,760 --> 00:57:32,751
All right.

899
00:57:33,600 --> 00:57:35,591
All right.

900
00:57:36,440 --> 00:57:40,718
With everything else closing in on me,
l'd forgotten about the mooning charge.

901
00:57:40,800 --> 00:57:44,190
When it finally came up,
l was facing a possible jail sentence.

902
00:57:51,520 --> 00:57:54,273
The charge has been reduced
to a misdemeanour.

903
00:57:54,360 --> 00:57:58,512
The maximum penalty is a $200 fine.
l think we should plead guilty.

904
00:57:58,600 --> 00:58:00,556
Thank you very much.

905
00:58:00,640 --> 00:58:03,473
lt was uncanny.
l'd got away with it again!

906
00:58:03,560 --> 00:58:08,076
To the Singapore legal system,
a shining example to the free world!

907
00:58:08,160 --> 00:58:10,754
We bared our all for Barings.

908
00:58:10,840 --> 00:58:13,718
Bearer bonds takes on
a whole new meaning after this!

909
00:58:13,800 --> 00:58:15,199
(phone rings)

910
00:58:15,280 --> 00:58:18,317
Talk about a bear market!
Hello? Mooners Anonymous.

911
00:58:18,400 --> 00:58:21,312
This is Wei Wei from
Coopers & Lybrand. ls that Nick?

912
00:58:21,400 --> 00:58:22,833
Speaking.

913
00:58:22,920 --> 00:58:27,596
l'm compiling the end-of-year audit. There
seems to be a big hole in the accounts.

914
00:58:27,680 --> 00:58:30,194
l'm missing the 7.78 billion yen...

915
00:58:30,280 --> 00:58:32,271
..receivable from SlMEX.

916
00:58:36,560 --> 00:58:38,630
Nick, can you hear me?

917
00:58:38,720 --> 00:58:41,188
ls everything all right?

918
00:58:41,800 --> 00:58:44,360
lt's a little complicated.
What do you need?

919
00:58:44,440 --> 00:58:46,271
l can't find any paperwork.

920
00:58:47,680 --> 00:58:51,355
lt was an over-the-counter trade
between Speer, Leads and Kellagg...

921
00:58:51,440 --> 00:58:54,432
..and Barings London.
lt fell through the computer system.

922
00:58:54,520 --> 00:58:56,636
l'll have a word with
the systems manager.

923
00:58:56,720 --> 00:58:58,676
l need three bits of paper.

924
00:58:58,760 --> 00:59:02,275
One: confirmation from SLK
that the 7.78 billion yen will be paid.

925
00:59:02,360 --> 00:59:05,511
Two: sight of your bank balance
to show it's been received.

926
00:59:05,600 --> 00:59:10,754
And three: a note from Ron Baker saying
he's aware of the deal and approves it.

927
00:59:10,840 --> 00:59:12,831
(line goes dead)

928
00:59:14,040 --> 00:59:15,871
Well?

929
00:59:15,960 --> 00:59:17,757
Oh, it's just a computer glitch.

930
00:59:17,840 --> 00:59:20,400
They're doing their annual audit.

931
00:59:20,480 --> 00:59:22,948
(laughs)

932
01:00:41,080 --> 01:00:45,790
And so, with scissors and paste,
l created $78 million out of thin air.

933
01:00:47,080 --> 01:00:49,469
This was forgery, pure and simple,...

934
01:00:50,360 --> 01:00:52,590
..and there was no going back.

935
01:00:52,680 --> 01:00:54,636
- Nick!
- Simon.

936
01:00:54,720 --> 01:00:56,870
Jesus, you almost gave me a heart attack!

937
01:00:56,960 --> 01:01:00,794
- What's this missing seven billion yen?
- Oh, that's a nightmare.

938
01:01:00,880 --> 01:01:03,440
lt's an OTC trade
that was incorrectly booked.

939
01:01:03,520 --> 01:01:05,829
The auditors are really
on my case about it.

940
01:01:05,920 --> 01:01:08,878
lt's a pain in the arse,
but we've got to get it sorted.

941
01:01:08,960 --> 01:01:11,235
The point is, we're owed
the money by SLK.

942
01:01:11,320 --> 01:01:12,958
Who the hell are SLK?

943
01:01:13,040 --> 01:01:15,918
Speer, Leads and Kellagg.
lt's a brokerage house.

944
01:01:16,000 --> 01:01:19,356
Better send me a memo as soon as.
Get these auditors off my back.

945
01:01:19,440 --> 01:01:21,829
Sure, Simon. Don't worry, l'm onto it.

946
01:01:22,960 --> 01:01:24,951
(phone rings)

947
01:01:28,560 --> 01:01:32,109
Bonnie, it's Nick. Listen.
Listen very carefully.

948
01:01:32,200 --> 01:01:37,797
Transfer 7.78 billion yen from the client
account to the house account tomorrow.

949
01:01:37,880 --> 01:01:39,393
But it won't go!

950
01:01:39,480 --> 01:01:41,277
There isn't enough money.

951
01:01:41,360 --> 01:01:45,751
l know that, but then you can reverse it.
